CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX NEWS HOST: The EPA administrator Scott Pruitt under fire for months is finally out. He resigned a short time ago. We all found out about it from a presidential tweet. Tonight we have the details as we know them, and we'll tell you what it might mean for business and regulation.

Also tonight, President Trump gearing up to take on Democrats in states he won. He's about to speak at a campaign rally in Montana. Tonight, his target the Democratic Senator Jon Tester. We're live at that event in Montana when the president begins.

Plus, barring some sort of last minute reprieve, the trade war is on. We're now just hours away from $34 billion in U.S. tariffs going into effect on everything from Chinese machinery, to auto parts, to medical devices. China now saying it is ready to respond immediately.

It's money and politics, we deliver the debate behind tomorrow's headlines. I'm Connell McShane in for Elizabeth MacDonald. The Evening Edit starts right now.

On Wall Street today the Dow shaking off trade some of the war angst, ending a 180 plus points higher after the Fed minutes were released and ahead of the monthly jobs report out tomorrow, it's 182 gain by the time the day ended on Wall Street 24,357 for the Dow. More on that in just a moment.

But first, this breaking this evening. The EPA administrator, a man of many scandals has resigned. President Trump a short time ago, tweeting that he accepted Pruitt's resignation.

Edwards Lawrence, live for us in Washington with the very latest. Edward?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, Connell, the president accepted the resignation letter from Scott Pruitt about 3.30 this afternoon Eastern Time. The president announcing the resignation as you said on Twitter, then tweeting about what's next.

President Trump said that Andrew Wheeler will assume the acting administrator duties of the EPA. Saying, "I have no doubt that Andy will continue on with our great and lasting EPA agenda. We have made tremendous progress and the future of the EPA is very bright."

Now Pruitt steps down amid multiple allegations against him of abusing power, misusing taxpayer money. Some of the issues spending $43,000 on a sound-proof phone booth in his office spending more than $100,000 on at least one trip with private tours the Vatican in Europe, first class travel. It was on and on.

The reaction is coming in from Congress. Senator Bernie Sanders says, quote, "Scott Pruitt was the worse EPA administrator in the history of the agenda -- history of the agency not only has he acted time and time again, an unethical manner but he has lead the agency in the wrong direction."

Senator Chuck Grassley saying the president did the right thing in taking the resignation letter. Now in the resignation letter Pruitt says that it's effective tomorrow.

And he adds that "It is extremely difficult for me to see serving you in this role first because I count it a blessing to serve you in any capacity, but also because of the transformative work that is coming out. However, the unrelenting attacks on me personally, my family are unprecedented and have taken a sizable toll on us."

Several ethics investigation have been open into Pruitt. In fact, some lawmakers on Capitol Hill have even asked the inspector general to get involved. Now it's unclear what happens to all of those probes. Connell?

MCSHANE: That's the thing. I mean, it could be some legal issues down the line and the rest of it. Edward, thanks. Edward Lawrence in D.C.

Straight to Bush 43, deputy assistant Brad Blakeman joins us this evening. And we're looking as well at the countdown to midnight which I talk about it a few minutes on the trade war fears. But Brad, let's get straight now to the breaking news on the resignation of Scott Pruitt.

As Edward talked about, you know, there are all kinds of scandals, right, by some counts it could be a dozen or more of them. So the obvious first question would be, in a situation like this what took so long?

BRAD BLAKEMAN, FORMER PRESIDENT GEORGE W. BUSH'S DEPUTY ASSISTANT: Absolutely, this guy should have been gone a long time ago, but I'm glad the president cleaned the air at the EPA as far as administration is concerned. The good news is the acting administrator Wheeler will do a fantastic job. And we're not going to hear the baggage and the drama that came with Pruitt.

MCSHANE: Right.

BLAKEMAN: He is a guy who is well-known in Washington, very respected environment attorney and energy lobbyist. He is somebody with a long history while serving the nation and also serving the private sector. So I expect nothing will change. The president I think will have a better opportunity to pass his agenda without the -- without the constant headline.

MCSHANE: That's kind of what makes this all the more puzzling or intriguing or whatever you want to call it, is that you are probably right, nothing will change which goes back to the first question, what took so long. Because if the president knows that. I would presume he does, or that is indeed the case, you know, wouldn't you wanted to -- wouldn't you have wanted to do this much, much sooner at least put it behind you if the policies are going to remain the same. He probably will.

BLAKEMAN: Yes, I think that the president probably in case was loyal to a fault.

MCSHANE: Yes.

BLAKEMAN: He was maybe too loyal to somebody who didn't deserve it. But clearly it's the right decision now, and I think it will be welcomed within the EPA.

MCSHANE: Now the thing about this story for, you know, our audience, our business audience, to think matters the most is what does that mean for business, what does it mean for regulation.

You're making the point that Pruitt's deputy, the acting administrator will continue with the same policies. Anything down the line, you know, in terms of he's already been confirmed by the Senate, right. So he come to any type of hurdles that could come in to play here where the administration's, you know, policies come up against it or just status quo.

BLAKEMAN: Well, the question is, how long will he serve as an acting administrator. Will the president nominates somebody to replace him or will he be actually elevated to the administrator of the EPA.

My hope is that the president will elevate him. Because he's a known commodity, he's well-known, he's well-respected. And again, I think he is in tune with the president' feeling of deregulation and giving more power to the private sector. And if you want that done then I think this guy probably should be elevated.

MCSHANE: Right. Because the idea, and that's what, you know, Democrat like Bernie Sanders which was the statement was read by Edward that the -- that this was the worst administrator of all-time, that he'd been leading the agency in the wrong direction. I mean, that's a political point of view but that won't change because of this. I mean, this whole deregulatory agenda continues pretty much--

(CROSSTALK)

BLAKEMAN: Right. Bernie Sanders is against the guy, I can assure you he is probably doing the right thing, so we're not looking for any endorsements by Bernie Sanders.

MCSHANE: It's kind of interesting but again, the scandals some of them were downright silly, I think that, you know, that were brought up, but some of these other things that somebody in this position would allow themselves to have endured. I mean, the $40,000 phone both for one.

BLAKEMAN: Crazy.

MCSHANE: I mean, it doesn't make any sense, though. It would go on and on. And then the other thing that, and the president campaigned on this of draining the swamp. I mean, you got a guy in here, let's be honest, asking his own age allegedly to go out and help his wife get like a 200 grand a year job and all that kind of thing was going on, you know, that's not exactly draining the swamp.

BLAKEMAN: Well, there is an illness in Washington that can affect cabinet members and low level staffers, that is Potomac River.

MCSHANE: Yes.

BLAKEMAN: When you get it, it's deadly. I've seen it happen to people. And here Pruitt was an outsider, former attorney general of Oklahoma, he should know better but he came to Washington, and he caught it. And it's fatal.

MCSHANE: There's no -- right. There's no known cure that we know of.

BLAKEMAN: Nope.

MCSHANE: Other than getting out which he will now do. Now I want to get you on a couple of other topics, or at least this big one tonight. We have the countdown clock on, right, so midnight. And the U.S. is said to impose these tariffs. It's $34 billion on imported Chinese machinery, automakers, and medical devices.

And as we would expect the Chinese have said they are going to come right back at us respond immediately. So the markets we didn't see much today. I mean, there were some reports that trade deals might be worked with the Europeans might have help stocks a bit. But this is certainly an issue.

Our own Maria Bartiromo spoke about all of this with the president recently. Let's listen then we'll come back and talk about it. Here it is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We have -- we don't have a trade deal with China, we have a deal. Nobody bothered to make a deal, and they'll charge 25 percent for a car, and we use 2.5 percent. And you'll be using those numbers on your show so I don't want to bore people. But we have a -- some of the worst trade deals in the world. We are losing money with everybody.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: This might be the one area, Brad, immigration maybe as well. But this probably the one area that this president has really changed the thinking of the Republican Party certainly different than it was when you were serving in President Bush's administration. What do you make of the moves?

BLAKEMAN: I think the president is absolutely right, China is a schoolyard bully who has been, you know, knocking us around, and either you can take it or you can stand up to the bully. And we have $400 billion deficit with China. That is just crazy.

We're the strongest most powerful economy in the world, and we're letting China and others, friend and foe, take advantage of us. I think the president is smart. Now it may cause us a little pain initially, but the gains are going to be well worth what we'll have to go through.

China like most bullies I predict will back down. They can't afford to go to war with America.

MCSHANE: Right.

BLAKEMAN: Those countries can't. And look, I think the president is going to make the best deal he can for the American people, we should be dealing bilaterally not with through this multilateral negotiations because it erodes our power and leverage.

MCSHANE: To some extent though, Brad, the question is, say you are right that they do back down, the question is when, and how long are the Chinese willing to kind of let this play out for, because that to your point does, you know, lead us into a situation where we might have to deal with maybe more pain than many Americans know they're going to have to deal with now.

And many of those Americans by the way supported the president when he ran for office. Think about farmers, think about people he's speaking to tonight at this rally in Montano. These policies he is putting in place could hurt people that supported him, right.

BLAKEMAN: Well, we're getting screwed, to a tune of almost half a trillion dollars. That's unacceptable. And what is Trump trying to do is he's trying to stand up for American jobs. We have to be behind the president. This is thinking long-term.

You know, I have a new word that diagnosis America's problems, it's called a momentarium. Living in the moment. Great leaders provide for the moment but they plan for our future. Trump is not only looking to take care of us today but he's looking to safeguard us for tomorrow.

MCSHANE: We'll talk about it tomorrow literally because this go into effect tonight. Good to see you, Brad, as always. Thanks a lot.

BLAKEMAN: Pleasure.

MCSHANE: All right. Brad Blakeman. Let's get back and check in on those markets. We mention the Dow closing in the green today with that more than 180 point rally. Job growth continuing into the summer months. ADP announced that business added 177,000 jobs in the month of June. So that was one of the economic data points.

Our own Nicole Petallides, as usual on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with the wrap up. Nicole?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Up arrows across the board. The Dow gained 182 points. The NASDAQ up 1.1 percent. We heard from federal open market committee pretty much on pace for those for the rate hikes but some trade uncertainly and that weighed.

Also we saw movement in energy and oil as President Donald Trump tweeted his concerns about OPEC monopoly, and saying that gasoline prices on the rise up about 60 cents year-over-year.

And some doubts are growing pertaining to the Aramco IPO, will it ever happen. According to the Wall Street journal it was very hot, it could be the largest IPO, a $100 million. And the reports are that it has stalled. And the company is not making any comment. Back to you.

MCSHANE: All right, Nicole. Thank you, Nicole Petallides.

President Trump, meantime, moments away from speaking there. You are looking live at a campaign rally that's been set up in the state of Montano. Fox Business will bring you there live when the president arrives in Great Falls.

Coming up, in the meantime, growing concern over smart TV vacuuming people's data right out of their living room sometimes without their full malice. We have details on that story tonight.

Also Mark Zuckerberg's Facebook apologizing for flagging a Declaration of Independence post as hate speech.

Coming up, a guest who is not surprise by that. But first, the president is planning a three-day visit to the U.K. That will be in a few weeks. It comes as report out says the U.K. government told the president he can't meet with a certain member of the European parliament.

The Brexit architect Nigel Farage. Well, Nigel Farage is here with us. He'll react to that after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCSHANE: Well, President Trump moments away from speaking at this campaign rally that's been set up in Great Falls, Montana. As you look at the crowd that has filed in to this venue. Remember the idea that the president going to these states where he won the presidential election that are represented in the United States Senate by Democrats.

In this case, Jon Tester, they try to go after a senator like a Jon Tester, see if Republicans can take back that seat, but as always with this campaign style rallies anything can happen. We're going to carry it live here on Fox Business. Anything from the resignation of Scott Pruitt that we were talking about, to the tariffs on China that go into effect midnight.

Of course, the Supreme Court pick that's expected on Monday. Anything and everything usually can and does happen at this type of event. So we'll carry that.

Meantime, July 12, the president planning a three-day visit to the U.K., where he'll meet with Prime Minister Theresa May, he's also meet with the queen. But according to the U.K.'s Daily Telegraph, the U.K. government has told President Trump he should not meet with the European parliament member Nigel Farage during his visit. And you know it, Nigel Farage joins us right now. What do you know about that?

NIGEL FARAGE, MEMBER, BRITISH PARLIAMENT: You know, ever since I appeared on a campaign platform with Donald Trump in Mississippi back in August 16, the U.K. government has been paranoid about my relationship with the U.S. president, my broader relationship with the administration. They're embarrassed I think that I've got good relations with Donald Trump and with many others.

And they are trying to deny the fact that I even exist. It is frankly stupid. It is ludicrous. The truth is that relations between the U.K. government under Mrs. May and the American administration under Trump are not as good as they should be.

MCSHANE: Right.

FARAGE: And rather than banning me from meeting the president, and by the way, I'm not sure how well he'll take to being told who we should choose to be or not. What they should be doing is using as a bridge between the two. I'm not sure at the moment the U.K. government is bright enough to understand that.

MCSHANE: So a couple things, have you been told or have you been able to confirm the fact that this is true, that they have come out and banned you from, you know, or try to ban you from meeting with president. And number two, have you spoken with the president or anybody at the White House about it.

FARAGE: Well, in the last 18 months, ever since -- ever since the president tweeted--

MCSHANE: Right.

FARAGE: -- many people in Washington think Nigel Farage would make a good U.K. ambassador. The government in Downing Street have been climbing the walls, that they hate me.

MCSHANE: Right.

FARAGE: They hate me because I force Brexit upon them.

(CROSSTALK)

MCSHANE: So you met I know it's true. But you think, you have every reason to believe based on history that it is.

FARAGE: It is a completely consistent pattern of behavior. What I do know is the briefing that you've read, written up in a U.K. newspaper.

MCSHANE: Right.

FARAGE: Where I know for fact is that it came from the prime minister's office, so yes, it is true. I have not spoken with the president. I have spoken should I say to people close to him. Look, I don't' to embarrass him coming on this trip, if he wants to meet me, I'll meet him, but I won't force it.

MCSHANE: So you don't know whether that will happen.

FARAGE: Well, let's wait and see.

MCSHANE: Yes.

FARAGE: I don't know, you don't know. And the great thing about Donald Trump is, nobody ever, ever can, you know, predict.

MCSHANE: Well, that's true. That's definitely true. Like him or not, you don't know what is coming next.

FARAGE: Absolutely.

MCSHANE: Even at this rally in the next hour. Think about this trip, there's a lot of -- there's been a lot of back and forth about whether it would happen, how it would happen, would it be an official, this and that. And then this story is getting some attention.

The mayor of London approves a request from protesters. You're already taking in of this too. But to essentially, well here it is. To fly this blimp, it's a blimp that designed to look like an infant President Trump during the visit. So what do you make of that?

FARAGE: Look, in a free society, people are able to protest. They can hold up a placard, they can draw a cartoon.

MCSHANE: Right.

FARAGE: That is freedom of expression and speech and we all believe in that. But what is happening here is that in parliament square, you know, right in front of our ancient parliament. This blimp of Donald Trump as a baby will be flying 100 foot in the air. And do you know why? Because Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, has given permission for this to happen.

I think it makes my country look like a laughingstock, there is no country in the world that would insult the U.S. president in this way, and I would beg, I would plead with Fox viewers, and with all Americans, please, next Friday, when you see this ridiculous spectacle next to our parliament, don't judge the whole of my country by it, judge Mayor Sadiq Khan by it.

MCSHANE: Now I want to take on another issue while we have you here, Nigel on foreign policy.

FARAGE: Yes,

MCSHANE: Because this is important. You know, we've been talking about a lot of other things, but North Korea, you know, the Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will be in there in Pyongyang, he is set to arrive there and it will be the first time since the Singapore summit that we are going to get together between the U.S. and North Korea.

But there have been a lot of stories here in the last week or so, right, that have lead to some skepticism about whether Kim Jong-un really is going to abandon his nuclear arsenal or whether he's adding to it or he's hiding it or whatever the case might be. What do you make -- are skeptical now after maybe reading and hearing some of this, and what do you think Mike Pompeo can do about it?

FARAGE: Look, you know, you have been through years of Obama making big public declarations about things he would do, and then delivering nothing. That's what western world politics has been like. The point about this Trump administration is they don't just make big gestures, they try to actually do things.

Now look, the very fact that the meeting happened was great, but what everybody wants to see now is some action, the fact that Mike Pompeo is back there trying to make this happen shows the will of this regime to get a result, it doesn't guarantee a result--

MCSHANE: Right.

FARAGE: -- but I think Pompeo is doing exactly the right thing.

(CROSSTALK)

MCSHANE: When do you, real quick, Nigel. When do you walk away, how do you know when to walk away, you know, how do you know they are not playing you in a situation like this?

FARAGE: Well, all through history, you know, we've seen, you know, peace deals, accords, and people breaking them.

MCSHANE: Yes.

FARAGE: I -- you know. Winston Churchill once said, jaw-jaw is ready than war-war. And right at the moment America and North Korea are going through jaw-jaw. Let's keep that process going as long as we possibly can.

MCSHANE: All right, we'll continue to check in with you, Nigel.

FARAGE: Thank you.

MCSHANE: Maybe any update on the president's visit as well. Thank you for joining us this evening I appreciate it.

FARAGE: Thank you.

MCSHANE: OK. As we said, the president is moments away now from this rally, campaign style out in Montana. And it looks like the crowd is getting revved up as it usually does for events like this. We're going to bring it to you live, Fox Business, we'll show when you the president arrives and bring you the rally.

But first, Mark Zuckerberg Facebook now reinstating a Declaration of Independence post after it was flagged as hate speech, accidental of course, But the details on that and what it means after a quick break.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO AND CO-FOUNDER, FACEBOOK: -- voices calling for building walls and distancing people they label as others. Instead of building walls we can help people build bridges.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ZUCKERBERG: We didn't take a broad enough of our responsibility and that was a big mistake. And it was my mistake. And I'm sorry. I started Facebook. I run it. And I'm responsible for what happens here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: All right. Mark Zuckerberg, the Facebook CEO apologizing earlier this year over the platform sharing user's personal data. Now, Facebook apologizing to a Texas newspaper for part of the Declaration of Independence being labeled as hate speech.

Community newspaper called the Liberty County vindicator had been posting the whole declaration in just small daily chunks on its Facebook page for eight days, this was in a run up to the 4th of July. But the ninth excerpt was not posted on Monday. The paper getting an automated from Facebook, saying that the post, quote, "goes against our standard on hate speech."

Taking a look at the stock, the Facebook stock, it ended the day as most of the market did in the green, up by about 3 percent.

Let's go to the Daily Caller News Foundation editor in chief Chris Bedford. Good to see you, Chris. Thanks you for coming on. I appreciate it.

CHRISTOPHER BEDFORD, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, THE DAILY CALLER: Thanks for having me.

MCSHANE: All right. So the offending passages such as it was, was part of the bill of particulars and was, you know, written against King George of Britain and it said Thomas Jefferson using the phrase quote, "merciless Indian savages," that's what got flagged, "merciless Indian savages."

Vindicator's managing editor replied in an article about that, saying, quote, "Perhaps that Thomas Jefferson written it has Native Americans at a challenging stage of cultural development that would have been better."

So, a tongue and cheek there. Unfortunately, Jefferson like British columnist of his day did not hold an entirely friendly view of Native American. So your reaction to all this, Chris.

BEDFORD: It wasn't a friendly time on the frontier right then.

MCSHANE: Right.

BEDFORD: The British crown had been an exciting tribes in the frontier to attack what were the American revolutionaries are towns and villages trying cause trouble for the frontier. A lot of people actually putting up on the left would call the Declaration of Independence a hate document.

We heard things like people putting on Twitter that the independent state on a Wednesday which is going to make white nationalist everywhere, come to tears and that was from an editor of Teen Vogue, but this gets caught up in Facebook's larger machinelike algorithms.

MCSHANE: Right.

BEDFORD: And publishers I guess are told that they have to trust these algorithms. The problem is of course and so like kind of like the Coca-Cola secret formula we're not allowed to see it. We just have to take to take their word for it, but time and time again it seems like historical thing or conservative things get flagged as hate speech by people and shutdown and there is no transparency at all with the massive, massive--

(CROSSTALK)

MCSHANE: Zuckerberg talk a lot and, you know, during a Senate House appearance. It's about artificial intelligence, saying A.I. is going to be able to do a lot of this force but it does bring up that question about whether it should be doing all of it or whether human monitors would be better.

However, as I catch myself, he obviously would have bias with human monitors as well, right.

BEDFORD: Yes. And you look at who they eventually, who they hired to come on to decide what was actually going to be good news sources. And these were retired people from CNN and from New York Times they got a pretty strong liberal bed. There's not a single person on their news team where they hired that you would have said I actually might agree with them politically if you were on the conservative side of things.

And if Facebook wants to maintain the trust of a good half of the country they are going to have to figure out bring on some of these people that may be in Silicon Valley they view as knuckle draggers. They don't -- they don't -- I don't think there's a lot of sympathy for conservative sentiments over Silicon Valley.

MCSHANE: Well to that point, Ted Cruz obviously the Republican side of -- what after Mark Zuckerberg about bias -- political bias in particular during those hearings. Let's take a listen to that -- back in time, then we will talk about it. Here it is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There are great many Americans who I think are deeply concerned that Facebook and other tech companies are engaged in a pervasive pattern of bias and political censorship.

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO FACEBOOK: I understand where that concern is coming from, because Facebook and the tech industry are located in Silicon Valley which is an extremely left leaning place and this is actually a concern that I have, then I try to root out in the company is making sure that we don't have any bias in the work that we do. And I think it is a fair concern.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: The only thing in this particular case, Chris, I would say, those case we're talking about, this phrase, merciless Indian savages seems, it is just a filter maybe that was not turned on the right way or it needs to be readjusted in some ways as oppose to a political bias or maybe I am wrong. What do you think?

BEDFORD: Yes. It is basically trying to call out, they have a 25 page manual on what they define as hate speech, and one of them includes attacking a protected group, today and maybe back in 1776, it should had been like this. The American Indian Conservative was a protective group and Thomas Jefferson did not have kind thoughts about the Natives on the Frontier. It makes sense, it was a period of open of warfare between the groups. There was tribes versus colonist. That was a different time in the time of war. So, it is probably just caught by a computer in this case.

But Facebook problem is there used to be a message board, something that you could post anything you wanted to, and they were not responsible for it, and then after some terrorists started using it and then especially after Hillary Clinton lost and they blamed Facebook for it, people on left said we need to regulate this place and make it so that Hillary Clinton can never be disparage here again. People on the right said, well, you don't have a friend over here, because you have shown bias against Conservatives and right now they are in Washington D.C. without a friend.

MCSHANE: Right. It is interesting. It gives us a chance to talk about it again. Whether or not in this case it applauds or not they got to take a look at all of this issues. Good to see you, Chris. Thanks a lot.

BEDFORD: Thank you.

MCSHANE: Let us go back to Montana, the President getting set to speak at campaign rally this evening, as soon as he begins, let us look at the arena. We are going to bring it to you live, you know Scott Pruitt resignation obviously at the top of the headline tonight, sometimes the President gets to something like that when it breaks, night of other times, avoids it entirely, we'll see, Of course, Supreme Court and his appointment there and another thing a lot of people are thinking about. So we are watching that. First though, an Anti-Trump amend has been fired from his job, a video, emerged of him angrily ripping a hat "Make America Great Again hat off a head of young boy and throwing a drink at him as he was eating food, this happen in Texas, we are going to talk about that. Next, Trump 2020 campaign senior adviser, Katrina Pearson will be here, don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCSHANE: Breaking news just coming in to us, President Trump just arriving moments ago air force one touched at Great Falls International Airport. So, the President now will motorcade over once he gets out of the plane. As the plane is just out of our camera shot at the moment, but taxing on the tarmac there and then there will be a motorcade over to the arena in Great Falls where the president begins a rally at the top of the next hour. So, some 22, 23 minutes of from now we will expect that to begin usually the President is about on time, it appears to be just about on schedule right now with the touchdown in Montana.

Let's bring in Trump's 2020 campaign senior adviser, Katrina Pearson, as we wait for the president comments at the top of the hour. I said before the last break, Katrina that pretty much anything and everything could come up usually does at these rallies. The President made headlines tonight obviously with the acceptance of the resignation as EPA administrator Scott Pruitt has been under fire, do you think he talks something like that or is it more focus on other subjects? What do you expect tonight?

KATRINA PEARSON, TRUMP 2020 CAMPAIGN SENIOR ADVISER: Well, I think your initial thought are absolutely correct. The President could speak about anything tonight, he definitely has his written speech in the teleprompter, but if you ever have been to a Trump rally, the President is known to really just feel the energy in the room and talk about the things that he wants to talk about and the things in the current headlines this may come up, he is definitely going to talk about many accomplishments that he is making and how Democrats are failing miserably to block his agenda. And he is going to show support for his supporters who are constantly under attack now, because you have Democrat politicians encourages physical confrontation.

MCSHANE: Right. We'll talk about that in a second and -- you have covered enough of these rallies, to know usually what you expect going in is not necessarily the headline that you get coming out, because the president will go of on some other subjects. Maybe tonight, he gives a hint about his Supreme Court nominee. What do you think of that?

PEARSON: He may, you know, this is where the President is in his element, he is most comfortable with his supporters, as you know. Thousands of people attend these rallies, some of them waiting overnight, there will be thousands on the outside of these rallies. And so, he really want his supporters to really be the first to know many of these types of things, and what is really going on. He uses this opportunity to bypass the mainstream media to get away from those filters on some of those other cable news networks and talk to his supporters so they can hear directly from him, what is going on.

MCSHANE: You see the supporters are gathered there waiting for President in the next few minutes to make his way over to the arena there, to the venue. You mentioned some of these confrontations that had been going on. And certainly getting a lot of the headlines, I think one, you may have alluded to his video, it has gone viral, the guy comes up, rips a hat right off a young man's head. The Make America Great Again Trump hat, throwing soda on him and what not, so, we will talk about that, but let us watch it first. Here it is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: (BEEP) President. You ain't supporting -- (BEEP). There is no great (BEEP).

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: All right. The man has been identified, Keno Jimenez, a bartender work at in San Antonio, Texas at a bar there, they fired him. The bar, they fired him of his job. Here is the teenager that you see there responding to the incident. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I didn't think he would generate that amount like, not like what people are doing, like I was looking at comments to some people are like, of yes, this is uncalled for, and people are like, you know, with mixed opinions, but I did not think it would blow up to what it is right now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: Yes. It has Katrina, blown up to become quite a story. A controversy that the kind of thing you are referring to, right?

PEARSON: Oh, absolutely. I mean, this this case, this was a cowardly man, this was an adult, a 30-year-old man. Who attacked a teenager? Kids that ride skateboards and play video games, this is how low the left has gone. This is more liberal buffoonery on full display, and this is happening because you have many in the mainstream media who are constantly mischaracterizing the President and his agenda. Along with others politicians on the left pushing for confrontation. And now, there are children involved. But we should be surprised, because this is not the first time. This has been going on since the very beginning, if you followed 2016 campaign, you saw Trump supporters get attacked violently outside some of these rallies. And now the media and the politics making this worse.

MCSHANE: Now the President's detractor said that he plays some role in it, based on that during the campaign as well, this his language, insights people on the other side to be aggressive against people who disagree with him, you think, there are two sides on this or just one side?

PEARSON: Well, I think that, you can take anything that you don't like, any policy that maybe does not work in your favor call it whatever you like. The President never encouraged people to go out in publicly confront individuals, and if he was abrasive in any tone it was in defense of his own supporters that were being violently attacked. And so this kid in San Antonio, you know Brad Parscale is from San Antonio, he is the Trump campaign 2020 campaign manager and he tweeted today that he would like to send this young guy a signed hat, give him a brand new MAGA hat with President's signature, because we all stand with Trump supporters all across the country.

MCSHANE: Coming up lined up tonight in Montana, they will hear the President speak at the top of the hour. Katrina, good to see you, thank you for coming on tonight. We appreciate it.

PEARSON: Great to be here. Thank you.

MCSHANE: All right. With this rally set to begin, we will keep our eye on it. Of course, the warming up of the crowds seems to -- just about been completed. The motorcade will be on its way over to the venue in Great Falls, Montana. Live at the Fox Business Network when it begins.

Also tonight, growing concern over smart TV, this is going to vacuuming people's data right out of their living rooms. Sometimes it happens without their full knowledge, details on that story coming up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCSHANE: Breaking News in the State of Montana, left and right of the scree, Air Force One, obviously on the left side of the screen with the stairs out, the President set to leave the plane, and head to the motorcade, and then he will by the power of that beast motorcade make his way over to the arena in Great Falls where the presidential lectern is set up for him to begin this rally.

That is top of the hour, Fox Business live coverage, we'll keep an eye on both of those live pictures. And we will have the president's arrival and then we will have his remarks at the top of the hour as well.

Now, before last break we promised to talk about this crazy story involving smart TV's that might be keeping track of more than just what you are watching, there is some concern growing over personal data being misused by big tech giants, Facebook alike and also by the smartphone companies, but people's data is being taken right from their living room TV, and sometimes it happens without them knowing about it. Because what happens is, you have to opt in as user agreement, but the language is confusing. We have it up on the screen, right now. Reading in part, interact with your favorite TV shows, get recommendation base on the content you love, connect your devices for exclusive content special offers. Our Susan Li is here this evening with a little bit more on this, this is confusing. What is the company again that is doing this?

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESSES: Well, there are several companies. The largest one that we're focusing on is Samba TV.

MCSHANE: Samba TV, right.

LI: Samba, I know it sounds very festive.

MCSHANE: Yes.

LI: But really it is kind of different. But that policy is 4,000 words, can you believe that, the opt in is 6500 words, do you read through them.

MCSHANE: No. There are a lot of times in my (inaudible) as all kinds of things we sign our life away, you know, these contracts come up, agree, agree.

LI: Right. You just want to get it over with. Make your life a lot easier. But OK. This is what Samba TV does, you know, 45 percent of Americans have smart television. In their living rooms according to IHS. I have one, I am a little scared now. And so what Samba TV does is it vacuums the info off your smart television, and this era of the internet things, your TV connected to the internet, which is then connected to your speaker, possibly to your phone as well. So what Samba TV does, it takes pixel by pixel, it understands what you are watching second by second.

MCSHANE: And then, that could be used, you know, obviously, you know, privacy experts are concern about, but it could be used for good.

LI: OK. So they can't directly sell the data, so what they do is they see what you are watching whether it is conservative or even liberal media. That is something that they also keep track of, and then they use -- they target ads to your other devices.

MCSHANE: Just like what happens on the internet.

LI: So you are wondering, you are watching, let us say you are watching "Game of thrones."

MCSHANE: Right. What is that ad?

LI: And then all of the sudden something pops up on your Facebook thing. Where did that come from? How did they know where they listening?

MCSHANE: I mean, companies in TV have wanted to do this forever, they have been jealous of the internet for doing it, but now it is really happening, but at the same time obviously, the obvious concerns come up, people say, well, I did not know this is going on.

LI: Well, yes, so the thing is, the opt in rate for Samba TV, 90 percent according to one executive.

MCSHANE: Those people have no clue. They don't know what they are clicking on.

LI: And a big investors are getting involved with Samba TV, as well. Mark Cuban, putting in money, we also have Liberty Media, and Time Warner as well.

MCSHANE: Now you mentioned they can't sell, so what are the restriction, real quick.

LI: They can't directly sell the data, that is single restriction, but there are big companies are working with them, like Citi and JetBlue in the past, Expedia, Spell Advertisers with Samba TV, as well.

MCSHANE: Sad world.

LI: Yes, this is the world it is, you want to target ads, you want them to be effective, I mean, the one that get the right eyeballs.

MCSHANE: Yes, that is it. You have to give up something to get it I guess. Good to see you, Susan.

LI: Good to see you.

MCSHANE: Thanks, Susan Li.

All right. President Trump will be speaking here, just a few minutes really at this campaign rally, see the crowd gathered behind the lectern with the Presidential seal on it in Montana. Remember, he won big out there, 20 plus points in the election and the idea is you go in the state where you won if you are President Trump that represented by Democrats in this case John Tester, in the Senate and you target that state. Kayleigh Mcenany is here, she will weigh in on that more. Coming up next from the RNC.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCSHANE: News alert out in Montana. Once again, moments away from the president at this rally in a State carried by 20 plus points. Let's bring in Kayleigh Mcenany in from the RNC as we set you up for President's rally this evening. Good to see you, Kayleigh. A couple of things we are wondering about.

KAYLEIGH MCENANY, REPUBLICAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE SPOKESPERSON: Good to see you.

MCSHANE: Obviously about the Supreme Court, whether we will get any hint. The president spoke briefly on Air Force One on the reporters about that and some other topics. I think he has it down to three possibly two is what he is saying. But, your thoughts on some of these picks? I mean, we have Judge (inaudible), they are all appeals court judges. He is appointed by President Bush, await away 51 years old. You have two other picks Judge Kavanagh, again, kind of a lot of Gorsuch comparisons there for Judge Kavanaugh who is appointed by President Bush as well, so that is somebody that could be considered and there is supposedly one other person in the running as well, Judge Amy Coney. So, if those are the three picks, can't go wrong from your point of view or how do you view this?

MCENANY: that is right. You cannot go wrong it is important to remind everyone that these three individuals all come from that list of 25 Judges that was put together during the campaign that was a list put together by Trump in consultation with a guy name Leonard Leo, who is the head of the Federalist Society and a member of the Federalist Society during my time in Harvard law school This organization is all about finding strict constitutionalist to interpret the words on the page as they should mean and their original context when put together by the founders. All three of these judges, Kavanaugh, and Coney they all -- Barrett, I should say Coney Barrett, you know they all have pass this test at the Federalist Society, and I think that that you can't go wrong.

MCSHANE: I am sorry, the President made some sort of remark on Air Force One, that any of the 25 on his list would have been terrific. But to the point of view of conservatives that is probably true, because it is going to that mold that you are talking about, the Federalist Society Consultant on the entire list which we knew that going in.

MCENANY: That is right. Make no mistake, each and every one of these men and women on the list, will be demonized, the left right now is coming up with a playbook to attack all of them, it does not matter who the nominee is, they will say that they are going to overturn Roe v. Wade and they will say this is rolling back the civil rights it is nonsense, but it does not matter what the name is, you can imagine the same line of attack that are going to come.

MCSHANE: No doubt. Less of a minute left actually, this just came out, we just got pull a report from Air Force One, the President threatening another 300 billion in tariffs on the Chinese, with the 30 plus billion going into effect tonight, we're in a trade war here, Kayleigh, aren't we?

MCENANY: You know, I think trade war, we can use that term or we can used a grand negotiation is how I see it.

MCSHANE: OK.

MCENANY: Because I think, as the President has said China has more to lose than we do, in fact they are the ones with a trade surplus. We are the ones with the deficit. So, I hope there is an opening salvo of what will be a long negotiation and one that will be better off for the American worker in the long run.

MCSHANE: All right Kayleigh, we cut it short, I want to get the president on time at the top of the hour. Thanks a lot as always for coming on tonight, we appreciate it.

MCENANY: Thank you, Connell.

MCSHANE: All right Kayleigh Mcenany, from the RNC. The president's rally will be getting just moments from now, Great Falls, Montana. We'll come back and have it live for you on Fox Business in just a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCSHANE: As we wait for the President to begin this rally in Montana. We said it in a number of times this evening that anything can and will happen at this rallies. The President talked about the resignation of his EPA chief, Scott Pruitt on Air Force One, saying there is really no final straw when it came to Pruitt. He called him a terrific guy, but at the end he said it was his decision to resign. So, we will look for that and his comments on the Supreme Court. And all the other breaking news of the day, but we thank you for joining us this evening. It's Charles Payne now with "Making Money." Take it away Charles.

END

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX NEWS HOST: The EPA administrator Scott Pruitt under fire for months is finally out. He resigned a short time ago. We all found out about it from a presidential tweet. UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I didn't think he would generate that amount like, not like what people are doing, like I was looking at comments to some people are like, of yes, this is uncalled for, and people are like, you know, with mixed opinions, but I did not think it would blow up to what it is right now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: Yes. It has Katrina, blown up to become quite a story. A controversy that the kind of thing you are referring to, right?

PEARSON: Oh, absolutely. I mean, this this case, this was a cowardly man, this was an adult, a 30-year-old man. Who attacked a teenager? Kids that ride skateboards and play video games, this is how low the left has gone. This is more liberal buffoonery on full display, and this is happening because you have many in the mainstream media who are constantly mischaracterizing the President and his agenda. Along with others politicians on the left pushing for confrontation. And now, there are children involved. But we should be surprised, because this is not the first time. This has been going on since the very beginning, if you followed 2016 campaign, you saw Trump supporters get attacked violently outside some of these rallies. And now the media and the politics making this worse.

MCSHANE: Now the President's detractor said that he plays some role in it, based on that during the campaign as well, this his language, insights people on the other side to be aggressive against people who disagree with him, you think, there are two sides on this or just one side?

PEARSON: Well, I think that, you can take anything that you don't like, any policy that maybe does not work in your favor call it whatever you like. The President never encouraged people to go out in publicly confront individuals, and if he was abrasive in any tone it was in defense of his own supporters that were being violently attacked. And so this kid in San Antonio, you know Brad Parscale is from San Antonio, he is the Trump campaign 2020 campaign manager and he tweeted today that he would like to send this young guy a signed hat, give him a brand new MAGA hat with President's signature, because we all stand with Trump supporters all across the country.

MCSHANE: Coming up lined up tonight in Montana, they will hear the President speak at the top of the hour. Katrina, good to see you, thank you for coming on tonight. We appreciate it.

PEARSON: Great to be here. Thank you.

MCSHANE: All right. With this rally set to begin, we will keep our eye on it. Of course, the warming up of the crowds seems to -- just about been completed. The motorcade will be on its way over to the venue in Great Falls, Montana. Live at the Fox Business Network when it begins.

Also tonight, growing concern over smart TV, this is going to vacuuming people's data right out of their living rooms. Sometimes it happens without their full knowledge, details on that story coming up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCSHANE: Breaking News in the State of Montana, left and right of the scree, Air Force One, obviously on the left side of the screen with the stairs out, the President set to leave the plane, and head to the motorcade, and then he will by the power of that beast motorcade make his way over to the arena in Great Falls where the presidential lectern is set up for him to begin this rally.

That is top of the hour, Fox Business live coverage, we'll keep an eye on both of those live pictures. And we will have the president's arrival and then we will have his remarks at the top of the hour as well.

Now, before last break we promised to talk about this crazy story involving smart TV's that might be keeping track of more than just what you are watching, there is some concern growing over personal data being misused by big tech giants, Facebook alike and also by the smartphone companies, but people's data is being taken right from their living room TV, and sometimes it happens without them knowing about it. Because what happens is, you have to opt in as user agreement, but the language is confusing. We have it up on the screen, right now. Reading in part, interact with your favorite TV shows, get recommendation base on the content you love, connect your devices for exclusive content special offers. Our Susan Li is here this evening with a little bit more on this, this is confusing. What is the company again that is doing this?

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESSES: Well, there are several companies. The largest one that we're focusing on is Samba TV.

MCSHANE: Samba TV, right.

LI: Samba, I know it sounds very festive.

MCSHANE: Yes.

LI: But really it is kind of different. But that policy is 4,000 words, can you believe that, the opt in is 6500 words, do you read through them.

MCSHANE: No. There are a lot of times in my (inaudible) as all kinds of things we sign our life away, you know, these contracts come up, agree, agree.

LI: Right. You just want to get it over with. Make your life a lot easier. But OK. This is what Samba TV does, you know, 45 percent of Americans have smart television. In their living rooms according to IHS. I have one, I am a little scared now. And so what Samba TV does is it vacuums the info off your smart television, and this era of the internet things, your TV connected to the internet, which is then connected to your speaker, possibly to your phone as well. So what Samba TV does, it takes pixel by pixel, it understands what you are watching second by second.

MCSHANE: And then, that could be used, you know, obviously, you know, privacy experts are concern about, but it could be used for good.

LI: OK. So they can't directly sell the data, so what they do is they see what you are watching whether it is conservative or even liberal media. That is something that they also keep track of, and then they use -- they target ads to your other devices.

MCSHANE: Just like what happens on the internet.

LI: So you are wondering, you are watching, let us say you are watching "Game of thrones."

MCSHANE: Right. What is that ad?

LI: And then all of the sudden something pops up on your Facebook thing. Where did that come from? How did they know where they listening?

MCSHANE: I mean, companies in TV have wanted to do this forever, they have been jealous of the internet for doing it, but now it is really happening, but at the same time obviously, the obvious concerns come up, people say, well, I did not know this is going on.

LI: Well, yes, so the thing is, the opt in rate for Samba TV, 90 percent according to one executive.

MCSHANE: Those people have no clue. They don't know what they are clicking on.

LI: And a big investors are getting involved with Samba TV, as well. Mark Cuban, putting in money, we also have Liberty Media, and Time Warner as well.

MCSHANE: Now you mentioned they can't sell, so what are the restriction, real quick.

LI: They can't directly sell the data, that is single restriction, but there are big companies are working with them, like Citi and JetBlue in the past, Expedia, Spell Advertisers with Samba TV, as well.

MCSHANE: Sad world.

LI: Yes, this is the world it is, you want to target ads, you want them to be effective, I mean, the one that get the right eyeballs.

MCSHANE: Yes, that is it. You have to give up something to get it I guess. Good to see you, Susan.

LI: Good to see you.

MCSHANE: Thanks, Susan Li.

All right. President Trump will be speaking here, just a few minutes really at this campaign rally, see the crowd gathered behind the lectern with the Presidential seal on it in Montana. Remember, he won big out there, 20 plus points in the election and the idea is you go in the state where you won if you are President Trump that represented by Democrats in this case John Tester, in the Senate and you target that state. Kayleigh Mcenany is here, she will weigh in on that more. Coming up next from the RNC.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCSHANE: News alert out in Montana. Once again, moments away from the president at this rally in a State carried by 20 plus points. Let's bring in Kayleigh Mcenany in from the RNC as we set you up for President's rally this evening. Good to see you, Kayleigh. A couple of things we are wondering about.

KAYLEIGH MCENANY, REPUBLICAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE SPOKESPERSON: Good to see you.

MCSHANE: Obviously about the Supreme Court, whether we will get any hint. The president spoke briefly on Air Force One on the reporters about that and some other topics. I think he has it down to three possibly two is what he is saying. But, your thoughts on some of these picks? I mean, we have Judge (inaudible), they are all appeals court judges. He is appointed by President Bush, await away 51 years old. You have two other picks Judge Kavanagh, again, kind of a lot of Gorsuch comparisons there for Judge Kavanaugh who is appointed by President Bush as well, so that is somebody that could be considered and there is supposedly one other person in the running as well, Judge Amy Coney. So, if those are the three picks, can't go wrong from your point of view or how do you view this?

MCENANY: that is right. You cannot go wrong it is important to remind everyone that these three individuals all come from that list of 25 Judges that was put together during the campaign that was a list put together by Trump in consultation with a guy name Leonard Leo, who is the head of the Federalist Society and a member of the Federalist Society during my time in Harvard law school This organization is all about finding strict constitutionalist to interpret the words on the page as they should mean and their original context when put together by the founders. All three of these judges, Kavanaugh, and Coney they all -- Barrett, I should say Coney Barrett, you know they all have pass this test at the Federalist Society, and I think that that you can't go wrong.

MCSHANE: I am sorry, the President made some sort of remark on Air Force One, that any of the 25 on his list would have been terrific. But to the point of view of conservatives that is probably true, because it is going to that mold that you are talking about, the Federalist Society Consultant on the entire list which we knew that going in.

MCENANY: That is right. Make no mistake, each and every one of these men and women on the list, will be demonized, the left right now is coming up with a playbook to attack all of them, it does not matter who the nominee is, they will say that they are going to overturn Roe v. Wade and they will say this is rolling back the civil rights it is nonsense, but it does not matter what the name is, you can imagine the same line of attack that are going to come.

MCSHANE: No doubt. Less of a minute left actually, this just came out, we just got pull a report from Air Force One, the President threatening another 300 billion in tariffs on the Chinese, with the 30 plus billion going into effect tonight, we're in a trade war here, Kayleigh, aren't we?

MCENANY: You know, I think trade war, we can use that term or we can used a grand negotiation is how I see it.

MCSHANE: OK.

MCENANY: Because I think, as the President has said China has more to lose than we do, in fact they are the ones with a trade surplus. We are the ones with the deficit. So, I hope there is an opening salvo of what will be a long negotiation and one that will be better off for the American worker in the long run.

MCSHANE: All right Kayleigh, we cut it short, I want to get the president on time at the top of the hour. Thanks a lot as always for coming on tonight, we appreciate it.

MCENANY: Thank you, Connell.

MCSHANE: All right Kayleigh Mcenany, from the RNC. The president's rally will be getting just moments from now, Great Falls, Montana. We'll come back and have it live for you on Fox Business in just a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCSHANE: As we wait for the President to begin this rally in Montana. We said it in a number of times this evening that anything can and will happen at this rallies. The President talked about the resignation of his EPA chief, Scott Pruitt on Air Force One, saying there is really no final straw when it came to Pruitt. He called him a terrific guy, but at the end he said it was his decision to resign. So, we will look for that and his comments on the Supreme Court. And all the other breaking news of the day, but we thank you for joining us this evening. It's Charles Payne now with "Making Money." Take it away Charles.

END

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX NEWS HOST: The EPA administrator Scott Pruitt under fire for months is finally out. He resigned a short time ago. We all found out about it from a presidential tweet. Tonight we have the details as we know them, and we'll tell you what it might mean for business and regulation.

Also tonight, President Trump gearing up to take on Democrats in states he won. He's about to speak at a campaign rally in Montana. Tonight, his target the Democratic Senator Jon Tester. We're live at that event in Montana when the president begins.

Plus, barring some sort of last minute reprieve, the trade war is on. We're now just hours away from $34 billion in U.S. tariffs going into effect on everything from Chinese machinery, to auto parts, to medical devices. China now saying it is ready to respond immediately.

It's money and politics, we deliver the debate behind tomorrow's headlines. I'm Connell McShane in for Elizabeth MacDonald. The Evening Edit starts right now.

On Wall Street today the Dow shaking off trade some of the war angst, ending a 180 plus points higher after the Fed minutes were released and ahead of the monthly jobs report out tomorrow, it's 182 gain by the time the day ended on Wall Street 24,357 for the Dow. More on that in just a moment.

But first, this breaking this evening. The EPA administrator, a man of many scandals has resigned. President Trump a short time ago, tweeting that he accepted Pruitt's resignation.

Edwards Lawrence, live for us in Washington with the very latest. Edward?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, Connell, the president accepted the resignation letter from Scott Pruitt about 3.30 this afternoon Eastern Time. The president announcing the resignation as you said on Twitter, then tweeting about what's next.

President Trump said that Andrew Wheeler will assume the acting administrator duties of the EPA. Saying, "I have no doubt that Andy will continue on with our great and lasting EPA agenda. We have made tremendous progress and the future of the EPA is very bright."

Now Pruitt steps down amid multiple allegations against him of abusing power, misusing taxpayer money. Some of the issues spending $43,000 on a sound-proof phone booth in his office spending more than $100,000 on at least one trip with private tours the Vatican in Europe, first class travel. It was on and on.

The reaction is coming in from Congress. Senator Bernie Sanders says, quote, "Scott Pruitt was the worse EPA administrator in the history of the agenda -- history of the agency not only has he acted time and time again, an unethical manner but he has lead the agency in the wrong direction."

Senator Chuck Grassley saying the president did the right thing in taking the resignation letter. Now in the resignation letter Pruitt says that it's effective tomorrow.

And he adds that "It is extremely difficult for me to see serving you in this role first because I count it a blessing to serve you in any capacity, but also because of the transformative work that is coming out. However, the unrelenting attacks on me personally, my family are unprecedented and have taken a sizable toll on us."

Several ethics investigation have been open into Pruitt. In fact, some lawmakers on Capitol Hill have even asked the inspector general to get involved. Now it's unclear what happens to all of those probes. Connell?

MCSHANE: That's the thing. I mean, it could be some legal issues down the line and the rest of it. Edward, thanks. Edward Lawrence in D.C.

Straight to Bush 43, deputy assistant Brad Blakeman joins us this evening. And we're looking as well at the countdown to midnight which I talk about it a few minutes on the trade war fears. But Brad, let's get straight now to the breaking news on the resignation of Scott Pruitt.

As Edward talked about, you know, there are all kinds of scandals, right, by some counts it could be a dozen or more of them. So the obvious first question would be, in a situation like this what took so long?

BRAD BLAKEMAN, FORMER PRESIDENT GEORGE W. BUSH'S DEPUTY ASSISTANT: Absolutely, this guy should have been gone a long time ago, but I'm glad the president cleaned the air at the EPA as far as administration is concerned. The good news is the acting administrator Wheeler will do a fantastic job. And we're not going to hear the baggage and the drama that came with Pruitt.

MCSHANE: Right.

BLAKEMAN: He is a guy who is well-known in Washington, very respected environment attorney and energy lobbyist. He is somebody with a long history while serving the nation and also serving the private sector. So I expect nothing will change. The president I think will have a better opportunity to pass his agenda without the -- without the constant headline.

MCSHANE: That's kind of what makes this all the more puzzling or intriguing or whatever you want to call it, is that you are probably right, nothing will change which goes back to the first question, what took so long. Because if the president knows that. I would presume he does, or that is indeed the case, you know, wouldn't you wanted to -- wouldn't you have wanted to do this much, much sooner at least put it behind you if the policies are going to remain the same. He probably will.

BLAKEMAN: Yes, I think that the president probably in case was loyal to a fault.

MCSHANE: Yes.

BLAKEMAN: He was maybe too loyal to somebody who didn't deserve it. But clearly it's the right decision now, and I think it will be welcomed within the EPA.

MCSHANE: Now the thing about this story for, you know, our audience, our business audience, to think matters the most is what does that mean for business, what does it mean for regulation.

You're making the point that Pruitt's deputy, the acting administrator will continue with the same policies. Anything down the line, you know, in terms of he's already been confirmed by the Senate, right. So he come to any type of hurdles that could come in to play here where the administration's, you know, policies come up against it or just status quo.

BLAKEMAN: Well, the question is, how long will he serve as an acting administrator. Will the president nominates somebody to replace him or will he be actually elevated to the administrator of the EPA.

My hope is that the president will elevate him. Because he's a known commodity, he's well-known, he's well-respected. And again, I think he is in tune with the president' feeling of deregulation and giving more power to the private sector. And if you want that done then I think this guy probably should be elevated.

MCSHANE: Right. Because the idea, and that's what, you know, Democrat like Bernie Sanders which was the statement was read by Edward that the -- that this was the worst administrator of all-time, that he'd been leading the agency in the wrong direction. I mean, that's a political point of view but that won't change because of this. I mean, this whole deregulatory agenda continues pretty much--

(CROSSTALK)

BLAKEMAN: Right. Bernie Sanders is against the guy, I can assure you he is probably doing the right thing, so we're not looking for any endorsements by Bernie Sanders.

MCSHANE: It's kind of interesting but again, the scandals some of them were downright silly, I think that, you know, that were brought up, but some of these other things that somebody in this position would allow themselves to have endured. I mean, the $40,000 phone both for one.

BLAKEMAN: Crazy.

MCSHANE: I mean, it doesn't make any sense, though. It would go on and on. And then the other thing that, and the president campaigned on this of draining the swamp. I mean, you got a guy in here, let's be honest, asking his own age allegedly to go out and help his wife get like a 200 grand a year job and all that kind of thing was going on, you know, that's not exactly draining the swamp.

BLAKEMAN: Well, there is an illness in Washington that can affect cabinet members and low level staffers, that is Potomac River.

MCSHANE: Yes.

BLAKEMAN: When you get it, it's deadly. I've seen it happen to people. And here Pruitt was an outsider, former attorney general of Oklahoma, he should know better but he came to Washington, and he caught it. And it's fatal.

MCSHANE: There's no -- right. There's no known cure that we know of.

BLAKEMAN: Nope.

MCSHANE: Other than getting out which he will now do. Now I want to get you on a couple of other topics, or at least this big one tonight. We have the countdown clock on, right, so midnight. And the U.S. is said to impose these tariffs. It's $34 billion on imported Chinese machinery, automakers, and medical devices.

And as we would expect the Chinese have said they are going to come right back at us respond immediately. So the markets we didn't see much today. I mean, there were some reports that trade deals might be worked with the Europeans might have help stocks a bit. But this is certainly an issue.

Our own Maria Bartiromo spoke about all of this with the president recently. Let's listen then we'll come back and talk about it. Here it is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We have -- we don't have a trade deal with China, we have a deal. Nobody bothered to make a deal, and they'll charge 25 percent for a car, and we use 2.5 percent. And you'll be using those numbers on your show so I don't want to bore people. But we have a -- some of the worst trade deals in the world. We are losing money with everybody.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: This might be the one area, Brad, immigration maybe as well. But this probably the one area that this president has really changed the thinking of the Republican Party certainly different than it was when you were serving in President Bush's administration. What do you make of the moves?

BLAKEMAN: I think the president is absolutely right, China is a schoolyard bully who has been, you know, knocking us around, and either you can take it or you can stand up to the bully. And we have $400 billion deficit with China. That is just crazy.

We're the strongest most powerful economy in the world, and we're letting China and others, friend and foe, take advantage of us. I think the president is smart. Now it may cause us a little pain initially, but the gains are going to be well worth what we'll have to go through.

China like most bullies I predict will back down. They can't afford to go to war with America.

MCSHANE: Right.

BLAKEMAN: Those countries can't. And look, I think the president is going to make the best deal he can for the American people, we should be dealing bilaterally not with through this multilateral negotiations because it erodes our power and leverage.

MCSHANE: To some extent though, Brad, the question is, say you are right that they do back down, the question is when, and how long are the Chinese willing to kind of let this play out for, because that to your point does, you know, lead us into a situation where we might have to deal with maybe more pain than many Americans know they're going to have to deal with now.

And many of those Americans by the way supported the president when he ran for office. Think about farmers, think about people he's speaking to tonight at this rally in Montano. These policies he is putting in place could hurt people that supported him, right.

BLAKEMAN: Well, we're getting screwed, to a tune of almost half a trillion dollars. That's unacceptable. And what is Trump trying to do is he's trying to stand up for American jobs. We have to be behind the president. This is thinking long-term.

You know, I have a new word that diagnosis America's problems, it's called a momentarium. Living in the moment. Great leaders provide for the moment but they plan for our future. Trump is not only looking to take care of us today but he's looking to safeguard us for tomorrow.

urn:contentItem:5VFR-5SP1-F0K1-N3X7-00000-00EPC SUPPORTS CALL FOR STATUTORY REGULATION OF TECH PLATFORMS: EU VOLUNTARY CODE ON DISINFORMATION IS INADEQUATE2019-02-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:46ZLexisNexisEPC SUPPORTS CALL FOR STATUTORY REGULATION OF TECH PLATFORMS: EU VOLUNTARY CODE ON DISINFORMATION IS INADEQUATE

Brussels -- The European Publishers Council (EPC) welcomes the UK Parliament's newly-published report "Disinformation and 'Fake News' by the Digital, Culture, Media Sport (DCMS) Committee which calls for clear legal liabilities to be established for tech companies to act against harmful or illegal content on their sites.



In the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal and hot on the tail of the Cairncross report that calls for statutory regulation for the tech platforms, this report proposes a new definition for tech platforms that is neither "publisher" nor "tech platform" but that is subject to an independent regulator, setting out what constitutes harmful content and with the statutory power to monitor relevant tech companies.

EPC's Executive Director Angela Mills Wade said: "The damning findings of this report, after months of forensic and rigorous investigation, demand immediate action and statutory intervention if our fundamental freedoms and democracy are to be protected. Reliance on voluntary codes, such as the one at EU level on Disinformation, is no longer an option. This report proves beyond doubt that legal liabilities are needed urgently so that tech companies, whose predatory and unscrupulous behaviour threatens the future of our independent press as well as society at large, act against harmful or illegal content on their sites."

The report calls for:

Compulsory Code of Ethics for tech companies overseen by independent regulator

Regulator given powers to launch legal action against companies breaching code

Government to reform current electoral communications laws and rules on overseas involvement in UK elections

Social media companies obliged to take down known sources of harmful content, including proven sources of disinformation

The report also concludes that:

Electoral law is 'not fit for purpose'

Facebook has intentionally and knowingly violated both data privacy and anti-competition laws

Angela continued: "This report is a damning indictment of the internet wild west. Society needs to comprehend the harm that is being done to our fundamental freedoms and democracy, and governments need to act to protect them. We join Damian Collins, MP, in calling for urgent action to tackle the monopolistic tech giants to prevent electoral fraud, protect our privacy and protect the vulnerable from online harm".

In a statement, Damian Collins MP, Chair of the DCMS Committee says:

"Our inquiry over the last year has identified three big threats to our society. The challenge for the year ahead is to start to fix them; we cannot delay any longer.

"Democracy is at risk from the malicious and relentless targeting of citizens with disinformation and personalised 'dark adverts' from unidentifiable sources, delivered through the major social media platforms we use every day. Much of this is directed from agencies working in foreign countries, including Russia.

"The big tech companies are failing in the duty of care they owe to their users to act against harmful content, and to respect their data privacy rights.

"Companies like Facebook exercise massive market power which enables them to make money by bullying the smaller technology companies and developers who rely on this platform to reach their customers.

The Committee calls for the Government to include concrete proposals for action in its forthcoming White Paper on online harms.

For further information, please contact Heidi Lambert on Tel: +44 1245 476 265 or Angela Mills Wade on Tel +44 1865 310 732

The final report can be found here:   https://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/commons-select/digital-culture-media-and-sport-committee/news/fake-news-report-published-17-19/

For further information about the work of the DCMS Committee:

  https://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/commons-select/digital-culture-media-and-sport-committee/
