urn:contentItem:5HTD-D5N1-JB20-G40F-00000-00Equinix Inc at Citi Internet, Media & Telecommunications Conference - Final2016-01-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:46ZLexisNexis010616a5892931.731Equinix Inc at Citi Internet, Media & Telecommunications Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Steve Smith

Equinix, Inc. - CEO, President

* Katrina Rymill

Equinix, Inc. - IR

Conference Call Participants

* Michael Rollins

Citigroup - Analyst

Presentation

MICHAEL ROLLINS, ANALYST, CITIGROUP: Maybe just to kick us off in this new year, if you can give us a sense of what your key strategic and operating priorities are for 2016 after a very busy 2015.

STEVE SMITH, CEO, PRESIDENT, EQUINIX, INC.: Yes, happy to do that, and happy new year to everybody and thanks for joining us.

I guess, Mike, it starts with continuing at the top of our agenda to press our advantage. We have got a lot going on with the Telecity and the acquisition of Bit-isle in Japan. Our gameboard continues to -- we continue to stay active, looking at the market.

I would tell you, though, on top of those two activities, we are going to be pretty busy in 2016 integrating and making those two acquisitions part of the Equinix family.

But at the top of our agenda every year is looking for opportunities to, number one, press our advantage in the market. Secondly, there is a lot going on to capture the enterprise customers, and we have talked a lot about that today in our one-on-ones. So everything we are doing today is to enable us to go capture the enterprise. So all the work we are doing with the cloud providers, on top of the network activity we have done in the last 17 years, is to put those two capabilities together to make them very attractive assets to capture more and more of our definition of the enterprise, all the other industry verticals, such as pharmaceutical, healthcare, manufacturing, et cetera.

We're prosecuting that a little differently in each country. As you would expect, in a Germany we are looking deeper into the manufacturing segments. In a UK, we're in healthcare and pharmaceutical. In the US, it might be a handful of other verticals.

But we're working hard to get success stories and use cases built so we can figure out how to go after that. Now that takes investment to go after this. This is much different than the last 17 years, where the networks and the digital media companies and the financial services electronic companies knew what they wanted and they came to us because we enabled it.

This is more of creating demand now, so there is marketing investment. There is sales investment. There is indirect channel investment. There are service offering investments. So there is quite a bit of investment to go after this. But the size of the opportunity and the hundreds of thousands of enterprises that exist in the world today that would look like a prospect to us is a big number.

And so, we have roughly 6,700, 6,800 customers today. We will layer in another 2,000 plus with Telecity and another 300, 400 with Bit-isle, so call it 8,000, 9,000 customers that we would have today with these acquisitions. There is no good reason in the next five to 10 years that Equinix couldn't have 20,000, 30,000, 40,000, 50,000, 60,000 customers if we figured out how to go prosecute the enterprise -- I should say when we figure out.

A couple of other things that are always high priority for us every year, we have about six or seven initiatives that -- and those were two of them. We're always looking how to see the next ecosystem, and the couple of areas that look prominent for us, obviously cloud is enabling interconnection in a pretty big way. I don't know if we would declare it as robust an ecosystem as the network to network is and the digital media to network is and as the electronic trading is, but it's well on its way.

But electronic payments look very promising. We are starting to see the early stages of the Big Data transition to the Internet of Things. With all the sensors and the devices and the screens deployed around the world today, there is a lot of information that companies are trying to monetize, and so we see opportunities to help companies do this.

The connected car, the connected refrigerator, the connected device, you name it. Everything is getting connected, and we're having lots of requirements coming to us to help them think through that.

And then underneath all this, there is a lot of work to do to scale this Company, so we are growing fast, so scaling people, organizations, systems, and processes is always on the agenda. We have turned on our quote-to-cash process around the world. It is live everywhere in the world. And we are in that stage now where we are making customers comfortable with interacting with us in a new way.

But once you get that level of automation in, as you look in the out years you should require less human hiring when you have more automation in the company, so we are trying to push hard on that.

And the last two things I would mention is we're trying to be great capital allocators. We have mentioned to you that you should expect that our capital allocation will still be in the same buckets as it has been in the past, with dividends at the top of that list now, but followed closely by organic and inorganic growth, and then debt repayment and buying assets where we see feasible. And then, share repurchase will remain on that list, but it is less likely at this point with all the other activities we have.

But I would tell you that being great capital allocators is high on the priority. What you see at the high end of our CapEx forecast for this year is what you should think about as a starting point as you think about going forward. We have an earnings call on February 18 where we will bring more color to the guidance around all those things on the 18th.

And then, lastly, we have become pretty big corporate social responsible players in the markets around the world. We are driving the Company to 100% renewable energy, so we are investing pretty big in wind power, solar power, fuel cells, and so we are driving the Company to 100% renewable energy consumer over the next couple of years around the world. There is a lot of focus on that.

And then -- I think those are the critical areas, Mike.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: Thanks. Maybe it will be helpful to think about -- as we think about 2016, what you just accomplished in 2015, and based on the guidance that you gave off of the third-quarter results, you increased the organic revenue growth from at least 12% almost a year ago from now to 16%. So can you give us a little bit more color about what drove that outperformance and then how that might play into your momentum for 2016?

STEVE SMITH: Sure. It starts with, of course, bookings, gross bookings, which is the target that all sales people care about. And we had very good performances last three quarters, as we have reported to you, of greater gross bookings than we anticipated, mostly driven by the cloud enterprise thesis, but we are still seeing very good growth on all the core verticals.

So the one benefit we have -- we are still seeing 80% to 85% of our bookings coming from the installed base, so that tells you that not only are the cloud players trying to go service the -- everybody is trying to service the enterprise. So everybody is scaling and building more capability and more capacity to go service the enterprise because everybody believes that 80% of the enterprise's spend is in house and it is going to come out to the market and everybody wants to go help them service that.

So it starts with gross bookings. Our churn was at the low end. I think you have all seen our churn has been bouncing around the 2% the last five quarters. We still want to maintain that 2% to 2.5% guideline. There will be a quarter here and there that will bump up a little bit, but generally speaking, the move we made a few years ago to really make sure we are bringing the right applications in the front door so that it didn't churn at the end of the term is really starting to take hold, because they are more interconnected. They are more mission critical. They are more global in nature, and so that is starting to -- that investment and bet is starting to pay out for us.

So churn, I think, is going to remain at the lower end of that range, and, again, we might see a quarter or two where it might bump up. You are still going to have occasionally a customer that grew with you for several years. They get to a certain size and they determine they need to build their own data center or they want to move some of that work to a wholesale provider. That dynamic is still going to be with us I think forever.

And then, lastly, that all cascades down to net bookings, which has been stronger than we expected, and ultimately our sales force has done a very good job preserving price. So our yield has been firm around the world, and if you look at the combination of those four things, it has presented very good results.

And the last thing I would say, Mike, is we are very fortunate that the secular trends are blowing a hard wind behind us, and so we are definitely playing off the trends, the tech trends that are happening in the industry today. There is no question.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: So one of the things I thought about in terms of the 2015 performance is you had better bookings that you describe. You also had better nonrecurring revenue, and I think the original thought process of it coming down when you guided was that some of the larger deals early in 2015 wouldn't continue.

So, is there a story to tell around the size of deals where maybe you had some incremental larger size wins over the course of 2015 that really helped? And this comes back to what you were describing on cloud deployments and some of your big customers deploying more with you. Is there a story within that to try to describe some of the upside and to think about how you came to those benefits?

STEVE SMITH: Yes, let me try to provide some color on that. So, I think our expectations coming into the year were clearly around betting big on the big three infrastructures or service providers -- Microsoft, Google, and AWS -- and that has played out as we expected.

So, we spend a lot of time with those three. We have done a lot of development inside of our centers and behind the cloud switches that we put in place in 21 markets, giving them the functionality they wanted to have, higher security, higher performance, and better latency when you wanted to connect to Office 365 at Microsoft or Azure or Google Apps or AWS.

And so the last 12 to 18 months, there has been a lot of technical development with their technical development teams, putting higher functionality so that when you buy a port on one of our cloud exchanges, on the other side when you see the cloud provider you are trying to connect to, it is at a -- it is a higher security. It is more private. It's all the things I just talked about.

So we spent an inordinate amount of money and time and effort to try to get those three stood up. I think we decided to bet on those three, and it has paid off for us because today the largest application that an enterprise wants to get to is Office 365 today. And so, the highest demand we see inside of our data centers is to get to Office 365. But all the other apps we are enabling, you can see it starting to unfold.

So there were some larger deployments that we won, but I think all three of those providers know where we stop and where we will end on a negotiation on price. They have gotten to learn very well that we are not interested in wholesale deployments or interested in stuff that is going to help the pullthrough and the magnetic effect of an ecosystem. So they are getting really good at deciding what to offer to us to bid on and not even offering us the stuff that is down in the wholesale pricing range.

So that was a factor, and there was quite a few wins that we did this year and I think you are seeing the effect when you look at what's happened with other big tech companies. You look at HP, you look at IBM, you look at Dell, EMC, NetApp; all these companies are feeling the effect of the brush of these three big players. And now, you also see other big players selling data center assets around the world.

So, the cloud is having a big impact on a lot of companies. We're enabling a lot of that and we get a lot of questions from investors that say, why isn't it affecting you? Well, we're in a position to enable these companies, and it is not just these three, but a lot of the activity out of the gate these last 18 months has been to connect to the three.

We have over 500 cloud providers as customers in our data center, so there is a lot of midsize companies, smaller companies, all trying to put their stuff in place, connecting to our cloud exchanges, trying to enable this private connectivity in the market.

So our thesis is let's keep doing these smaller, midsize deals. Occasionally, we're going to take a larger footprint. It could be up to 0.5 megawatt of requirement of power, even up to 1 megawatt, but it will have to be very magnetic and have pullthrough effect.

And we're going to go create this environment where you can come into Equinix and you can connect to the networks and move whatever traffic you want to move publicly through the public Internet. Now you can also connect privately through the cloud exchange to move private applications to the cloud providers, and that's a pretty attractive multi-cloud, hybrid cloud environment that most of the conversations we are having with any CIO in the world is what they're looking for.

Certain parts of their application workload, they want them to get to the cloud because of the cost performance and latency benefit. And that's what's happening. There isn't a conversation we have today where any company is not trying to connect to one or all three of those providers.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: When you take a step back and look at the marketplace, how would you evaluate where market growth is? Has that gotten better as well?

STEVE SMITH: General market growth for our industry?

MICHAEL ROLLINS: Yes, for your industry, yes.

STEVE SMITH: I still think we believe it is in the high single-digit range, and when we build an annual plan, we always build a plan to grow faster than the current growth rate.

So when we started out at 12% last year, Mike, we felt like the growth rate for network neutral retail colo globally was in the 8%, 9%, 10%, more towards the 8%, 9%. So we built a plan that was to take share. We know we are spending more capital than any of our competitors and we know we are taking share.

It is very hard to judge that because nobody really can calculate it. It is not done very well in this industry segment, but we know we are taking share just because of the anecdotal evidence and the amount of CapEx we are spending.

So our plan is always to grow faster at or above market growth rates and that's the plan we start the year out. You notice our guidance strategy now is greater than, and I think you're going to continue to see that from us because it is very hard to predict how fast this stuff is going to happen. We're getting a lot of -- Katrina and I are getting a lot of questions today about, is the enterprise showing up as fast as you expected? It is I don't know what to expect and how fast it is going to show.

We know it is showing up. It is starting to produce all the new logos. It is starting to connect to the cloud. The thesis is proving out, but it is how fast should this go? It is very hard to predict. So we're going to do our best intelligence and I think you're going to see us continue to do what we did the last couple of years.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: What is the decision set for an enterprise? If they are looking to connect to these cloud players, is it a choice between deploying cabinets in your facilities versus buying VPN connections from a large telco or a fiber provider? What is the decision set for enterprises and how are you able to describe the value proposition for why they should be a customer or a larger customer for your Company?

STEVE SMITH: First of all, it starts with -- today, over 50% of our revenue is with customers that are in all three operating regions with us, Asia, EMEA, and the Americas. So, when you consider that our customer base is with us in multiple markets and then it is over 70% that are in multiple regions and then it is over 80% that are in multiple metros, so it is a very global connected customer base and that's the part of the conversation that we have with customers.

So we will compete locally in markets, but generally speaking, we are taking advantage of the scale and reach that we have for global applications, mission-critical activity, cloud-enabled activity, and then companies that have people, revenue, and customers globally distributed.

So if you're a customer -- and we have moved from -- I don't know what the number was a couple years ago -- now to over 110, I think it is, and it is growing; there will be more this quarter -- of Fortune 500 companies, they are coming in and they are trying us, they are landing, and we are starting to see they are starting to expand. So we believe the approach with us is going to be land and expand.

So once we get use cases and success stories built with these big Fortune 500 companies, other companies in those sectors are going to say, wow, Chevron is doing this and airline B is doing this and pharmaceutical D is doing this, and they are going to start paying attention. So, that's how the enterprise game goes with service providers. You got to get use cases and success stories built, and that's where the focus is today.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: Is there some sort of historical example that we could look at for your Company or maybe another set of similar companies that would help investors assess the synergy opportunity for the Telecity transaction?

STEVE SMITH: One thing I would tell you probably not to look at is what the Telecity interaction synergy plan was, because it will be apples and oranges, my guess is.

We will give you some color on February 18, some preliminary color of how we're thinking about it, but you should expect revenue, CapEx, OpEx, and cash flow synergies out of this combination.

But we are dealing with a global entity, Equinix Europe acquiring a pan-European entity that was running very lean and with about 400 less people than we have in our European business for roughly the same size revenue and actually running at a margin that was 1 or 2 points higher than we were -- EBITDA margin, higher than our European business.

So you are dealing with a company that is pretty well run, pretty lean, very -- the assets are great assets. We have been asked the question a lot today, why Telecity, why not Interxion? We knew both those assets very well, and when that fuse was lit, there really wasn't any debate about which one. We knew the culture, the locations they were in, the quality of the assets were the combination that we wanted to go after.

So it is all playing out as we expected. Shareholder vote is on the 11th, Monday, the 11th. They have a court hearing on Wednesday, and then we will close on next Friday, the 15th. That's the current plan for the go-forward.

There has been a lot of work going on preholiday to get the integration lined up. We've met with all the key players. We have had multiple integration meetings. Keith and I and Charles and the rest of the leadership team have visited almost all the assets and met all the people at the leadership levels. We are very comfortable with where we are and there is a great plan in place. The learnings from Switch and Data and from the other acquisitions will definitely play into getting this thing right right out of the gate.

The key is you got to keep the sales engine moving, so the bookings is the critical component. We will get these assets tethered. We will get the data center people. All that will fall into place. The real gem of this thing out of the gate is to make sure you maintain the bookings momentum, and helping their sales force learn how to sell a global platform and helping our sales force learn these new assets that we're going to pick up across these new countries.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: So as you think about investing in sales and trying to go after more customers, is one of the opportunities of the transaction, instead of integrating and optimizing the sales force, using this to create a larger sales force to push, as you said, your advantage in the marketplace?

STEVE SMITH: You mean with the Telecity sales force, Mike?

MICHAEL ROLLINS: Yes.

STEVE SMITH: That will be additive, and the one commitment I will make to everybody, we will do a hell of a lot better job this time with the sales force. I think we overengineered the sales force six, seven years ago with Switch and Data. So there will be a lot more preservation.

We're actually bringing the entire sales engine to our sales kickoff next week in Florida, which we are going to inject them into the Company and it is a big kickoff. We do it every year and it will get them completely connected culturally to the Company and to their peers, so the timing is absolutely perfect. So we are fortunate there.

But, yes, we will -- there will be more heads. I think the number, we're around 240 direct salespeople at Equinix now. There is X number coming from Telecity. I don't know the exact number off the top of my head. Katrina, do you know? I don't know.

KATRINA RYMILL, IR, EQUINIX, INC.: It is 70 to 80.

STEVE SMITH: 70 to 80 in Telecity, and then the channel, the indirect channel, which I haven't mentioned yet, is stood up now and it is in the 70 to 80 range of total people. So we are partnering now with big partners, medium-size partners, and so we have got different routes to market going.

And we feel that kind of headcount is what it is going to take to go prosecute the enterprise at the pace we want to go right now.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: And so, the other part of the Telecity transaction just to hit upon is the announced divestitures. In one of the questions -- actually, there is two questions that have really come up with this. The first one is how to think about what you are actually selling, because there is -- obviously from a selfish perspective, you might want to take some of those customers that are in other facilities of yours or Telecity and try to hold onto that, but that could affect the multiple or the value that you get for those assets.

So, what exactly are you selling and are there any limitations that you face in terms of trying to maximize the relationships that you're going to get from the transaction itself?

STEVE SMITH: There are limitations. We faced the same challenge when we sold the 16 assets in the Americas a couple years ago from the Switch and Data assets in the Tier 2 markets, so we are very versed in how you manage that.

So we have quarantined these eight assets off now. They won't be obviously part of the close. We have identified the people that will go with those assets. The partner has been picked. We have picked a bank. We did a bake-off and we picked RBC to help us through this process. They are ready to go. They were ready to go before the holidays, so we are in full speed right now.

There is no buyer upfront requirement, so we will close before this has to be done. It will take six, seven, eight, nine months to get this done properly.

There will be some rules around the customer question, Mike. We will have to be very careful. We can't just try to go after those -- many of these customers are in many sites in these countries, anyways, and there is very specific rules and limitations around going after those customers, so that will be governed very closely.

Who we dispose these assets to, the EU will have a heavy hand in that. We drive the process. Obviously, our agenda is to not create another competitor, but the EU's agenda is to make sure there is competition in each of these markets. They obviously looked at how much revenue capacity was required to be divested, how much capacity was available in these assets, and how much interconnection density was in these assets. And so, all that came into play where we landed.

Personally and the leadership team, we are very happy with where we landed on this. We knew it was going to require some amount of disposition. I think we will look back on this thing two, three, four years from now and slap each other on the back and be very happy with where we landed. Having now 64 assets around Europe, that puts us in a very strong position in that part of the world.

And we will dispose of these eight assets, and everybody that you can imagine is at the table interested in them. These are very critical assets and I think we will have no problem picking and choosing who we want to dispose these assets to.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: How did you decide to use or issue equity earlier in the year to fund some of your financial needs?

STEVE SMITH: When we put the financing plan together pre-November, when Keith and I went to the market to do this, we decided that we wanted to have this balanced approach of debt and equity. And we did a term loan in Europe in local currency and we extended an operating line that we had that put about $3.2 billion of liquidity back in play for us.

So the equity was aimed at the organic growth of the business and the debt was aimed predominantly at concluding the Telecity acquisition. Just philosophically, that's how we came to the conclusion.

The equity raise did surprise many people when we came -- I mean, we are not a serial equity player, so I think that question came up a lot. But I think as Keith and I went through the discussion over the course of the week and a half we were on the road, people understood and got it when we described the growth of the business and the pace that we were going and the dividend strategy and the rest of the needs of the business.

So, this puts us in a very strong position from a balance-sheet standpoint for quite some time. We are not putting a time limit on it, but we can see that this is going to handle the dividend requirements, the organic/inorganic growth requirements, and the asset purchase and debt repayment requirements that we have in front of us.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: You used, I think, some investment in 2015 and it may have held back some of the margin performance in 2015, but your key focus this past year, of course, was the cloud and the enterprise and making progress there. How do we think about the investment initiatives in 2016 for some of the things that you described that you're going after, whether it is the Internet of Things or continuing to push more of this cloud enterprise vision? And how should investors think about margin performance in this period of investment?

STEVE SMITH: Good question. This is probably the biggest issue that we have is at the rate we are growing, it requires investment, and everybody, including us and our Board, would like to see the margin also improve along with that investment.

And our trade-offs we're making now is that we want to keep investing to grow the business as top priority. And the investments were just not 2015 investments to stand all this stuff up. There is -- as I mentioned, there is marketing, service offering, and innovation around the cloud exchanges. There is a whole bunch of investments required to put in place the capability to attract enterprises. Enterprises contract differently; enterprises want to be billed -- there is a whole different way to interact with enterprises from all of those fronts. You got to get to them through channel and direct, so there is a lot of investment to be continued there.

So we're going to continue that journey and preserve margins and at the rate that we are running at. I know that everybody in this room that knows us knows we have got this long-term operating plan, 50% EBITDA margin target that we have out there as long as I have been here, and the aspirations are to drive the Company to that or greater over a time period.

I think what we all underestimated seven, eight, nine years ago when we put that out there was the growth opportunities that we would be facing and the investment required. And I think also people don't clearly understand that, what I mentioned earlier, to grow this Company in the early days when the networks were coming at us and the digital content was coming at us and the electronic trading was coming at us didn't require the level of investment that it requires now at this stage of the game to go capture enterprises.

And so that has changed and I'm not sure everybody, including us, saw the order of magnitude of that. So our aspirations are to continue to improve margins, but our top priority today is to invest in growth.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: So would you say that's one of the greatest differentiators between you and your competitors around the world is the investment in distribution and innovation of product ecosystems?

STEVE SMITH: At the scale we are doing it, yes. I am sure many of the other competitors we have in the market are investing in these things. Everybody has got their version of a cloud exchange. Everybody is trying to enable the cloud.

The level of functionality that we have put in place with the big players, I don't think anybody is anywhere near that scale. When you look at the amount of money we invested the last 18 months behind the big three that I mentioned, I don't believe anybody -- well, you can go ask these three. They will tell you that nobody has invested at that level to create that level of functionality.

Now, the question is with the enterprises that are coming into -- looking out in the world, do they want that level of functionality? We have decided to bet on those three. We believe that they have a pretty good point of view about how the world is going to unfold. It doesn't mean we are not betting on number four, and we put IBM SoftLayer there and then we are doing a lot with VMware and EMC and Cisco and all the rest of the players.

But the big three, certainly in the Infrastructure-as-a-Service space, have really changed the game, as we all know. It has really disrupted a lot of companies.

So the heavy dose the last 18 months was getting in behind that initiative. What we are starting to see now is SaaS companies really starting to show up. So Oracle, as we told you last quarter, is now deployed in multiple markets with us and they are going big to go start serving Oracle up as a service. SAP is doing the same thing, and you're going to see a lot more of the SaaS activity, I believe, in 2016, similar to what we saw with the big Infrastructure-as-a-Service players.

The Platform-as-a-Service still exists, the category, but they are all morphing between SaaS and infrastructure players. And it is -- we are still -- if you look inside of our pipeline today, there is still a lot of cloud players coming in, trying to enable their offerings in our data centers, can't afford to put capacity around the world that we have, and that's what's driving the need for us to spend the capital to go facilitate them to set up shop and do their thing around the world.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: So when you make the decision to greenlight the new project, expansion, new facility, and day of opening you are there, what is the kind of time frame you are seeing or now expecting in terms of fully booking that facility and then getting full revenue utilization, however you want to define that? Is it a three-year, five-year? How do we think about the timing of that? And then, maybe you can contrast that to what you saw two years ago, for example.

STEVE SMITH: Yes, it's stayed pretty consistent, Mike, but it really depends on the size of the phase that we are opening. So, we like to go cash flow positive in six to 12 months, but it depends on the size of the phase. But the fill rates are as high as they have ever been, and so we are seeing the big markets, because of the cloud initiative, fill rates are as high as we have ever seen them. So that's why you see capital up at the upper end of our range.

So, the dynamics that we have talked about always about when we go cash flow positive, when we fill it up, it is hard to answer when we fill it because it depends on how big of a phase it is, whether it is a -- and we tend to phase everything now. But it is as robust as it has been because of the demand that we have.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: How many markets would you say you are tight in terms of available capacity to sell? Are there some key highlights?

STEVE SMITH: Less than a handful.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: Okay.

STEVE SMITH: Yes, less than a handful, but we have a couple isolated situations where because of local laws or regulation issues where we are at capacity, not constrained yet, but we will be constrained in 2016.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: Do the mergers help with those markets?

STEVE SMITH: Yes, yes, they help in a couple of those situations.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: And if we just move over to some of the cash flow side of the equation, you had a dividend this past year. Presumably there is some level of financial performance growth in 2016, but you also put more assets into the REIT during 2015. You made another distribution in the fourth quarter. Is there a way that investors should think about the dividend growth in 2016, given those two pieces to the equation?

STEVE SMITH: The key ingredient for dividend growth, it will be organic and inorganic growth, followed by moving more assets from the nonqualified, the T, the TRS to the QRS.

And so, we have got obviously Telecity. We have got the Bit-isle assets, and we have got assets in Brazil and a couple other places that are not in the qualified REIT subsidiary.

So the finance team, Keith and his team and the tax team are evaluating how we want to prosecute through that through 2016. He will provide a little bit of color on February 18 on our earnings call about how we are thinking about a growing dividend. And so, we'll give you the pieces of the puzzle how we are thinking about that as we move through 2016.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: The business has gone through a series of migrations, right? You digested virtualization. You digested greater power density. You have digested larger customers moving to wholesale.

Are there some other digestions thematically that you have to go through, whether it's customers taking a 10-gig crossconnect and putting 100-gig equipment on it so they might not need as many crossconnects? Or are there other things that you are mindful of as a management team that we should be mindful of and watch over?

STEVE SMITH: Great question. There is a couple at top of mind that I think about that won't be big global initiatives, but one, for example, is Safe Harbor.

So Safe Harbor won't affect us directly, but it is going to affect all of our customers that have deployments in Europe. And our guess is that more and more companies, because of the privacy laws now, will probably end up putting more local instances in Europe to protect the privacy of data in some of these facilities, which is going to cause them to put more server infrastructure and storage arrays to do that. That goes in data centers, so we'll probably -- our thesis is we will probably benefit from that, as we did with other trends like that, like regulation in the electronic trading space. When the flash traders and the high-frequency traders got regulated, it caused them to put more server infrastructure in. That went into our facilities and we ended up benefiting.

The 10-gig to 100-gig transition with moving traffic around the world, we made that transition years ago when we went from 1 gig to 10 gig. We will manage the same thing when we go from 10 gig to 100 gig. It will probably -- there will be some grooming of crossconnects when people take advantage of this.

We told you on the last earnings call that we are starting to see 100-gig switching be deployed. It is going to take a while for the peering architectures to absorb that and catch up with it, but the architecture's jumped from 10 to 100 gig now and we're starting to see 100-gig traffic.

And the number one thing, as I said earlier, that drives this Company's business is one word, traffic, so the more traffic we see, the faster we grow, and the more interconnected it is, the higher the margins.

So, we like this. Yes, there will be some management required, but I think we will manage through it, just like we did going from 1 gig to 10 gig, so those are two I am thinking of.

There is another thing that is coming up. A lot of you are asking us about Flash storage. Is that going to affect your business? I think that technology shift is happening and I think it will be along the lines of the virtualization phenomenon.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: And as you look at your other core segments, so we spent a lot of time on cloud and enterprise today, but you have got financials, you have got networks. Are you seeing anything trend-wise that is noteworthy, whether it is acceleration or deceleration, in those other segments?

STEVE SMITH: It is predominantly -- we are very fortunate that all of these segments are continuing to grow with us, but as I said earlier, they're all also chasing the great old enterprise. And so, networks are upgrading their traffic -- or their switch fabrics. Digital media is trying to push more content around the world to answer all this Big Data and Internet of Things activity that we are benefiting from it because the installed base is still growing with us.

I remember when we decided to point the Equinix machine at the enterprise four or five years ago, and everybody started asking us, well, does that mean the networks and the digital media companies and the financial services are slowing down? No, but we didn't really know what was going to happen and then cloud showed up.

So we are very fortunate that the core verticals are continuing to grow because they are chasing the same thing we are. But we just know that when you have 350,000 enterprises in the world that are over $10 million in sales and have at least 500 people, that's a prospect. And when you see the whole world going more and more digital and more and more interconnected, you see the opportunity to go help them do that.

And the simple equation is they can take advantage of the network variety that we have and density that we have in these facilities, and the cloud variety, to get to the multi-cloud hybrid cloud environment that is the current paradigm shift in computing, and that is at the heart of our thesis.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: What are the key markets for you there on your radar for geographic expansion?

STEVE SMITH: China is at the top of that list right now. We've put our toe into Shanghai and there is -- even with all the noise in China today, there is a huge opportunity for us to partner up to get the licenses we need to go further into the Chinese market. Obviously, the next major step would be Beijing. So we are working very hard on that. It requires a partner and so there is more to come there.

India has always been on our radar, but it is a very tough place to -- you have to pick the right partner to get in there and we just haven't made that happen, but that will remain on the radar screen. South Africa is starting to see a fair amount of demand. I could see us in that market over time. South Korea is always on the radar screen.

The Americas were pretty much done, I would say. There might be opportunity in Latin America to go deeper beyond Brazil. Someday Russia may settle down and clear up. That's a big -- that's like Brazil and China, and so India and Russia will remain on the radar screen.

Those are the kind of top-of-mind places, Mike, that we stare at, but it is all going to be driven by customer demand that would pull us there, and we would go in with a big player or two before we would ever invest in one of those big markets.

Questions and Answers

MICHAEL ROLLINS: Just a reminder if you have a question, just hit the button on your microphone.

So, and then just, lastly, has the ship sailed on wholesale/retail for you under one roof or is that still something that you expect to dabble further into?

STEVE SMITH: Has the ship sailed? I think if -- the possibility of putting together the biggest wholesaler and the biggest retailer probably got pushed sideways when the Telex acquisition was completed, just because of the US regulator point of view on that ever being able to -- you could divest, I guess, to make that happen.

But we are not spending any time thinking about how to move into wholesale. It is a different business model, services a different part of the customer architecture. I personally think both are going to continue to perform very well.

Our relationship with Digital continues to be good. It is more complex now, but we are in many of their facilities, so we need to maintain a relationship there. We're building more hybrid facilities in our new assets, so we learned a lot from this business suite product that we built in the DC area. And so, we are not building any more pure business suites, but we are building more hybrid facilities in some of our new locations to handle these larger footprints of these cloud magnetic deployments that we expect to still come in in the coming years, because we understand the benefit of having a magnetic engine that could be 0.5 megawatt, 1 megawatt.

So there are still larger deals, but far and few between, but we will accommodate those and we're building to accommodate those.

MICHAEL ROLLINS: Great. Thanks for the insights and your time today. Thanks very much.

STEVE SMITH: Thanks, Mike. Appreciate it.

urn:contentItem:5V1R-9YY1-JDVW-N25R-00000-00Equities extend losses as government shutdown concerns weigh on Wall Street2018-12-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:46ZLexisNexisExclusiveEquities extend losses as government shutdown concerns weigh on Wall StreetAyesha Hassan

Wall Street is set to open in the red after the S&P 500 dipped 1.58% yesterday amid concerns of a looming government shutdown and tensions between the U.S. and China.

Wall Street set to drop further at the open after yesterday's selloff.

Asian, European equities extend losses.

Treasurys stable, dollar gains ahead of U.S. economic data.

Brent crude oil, gold fall.

Wall Street's selloff looks set to continue today, amid concerns of a looming government shutdown and tensions between the U.S. and China.

The U.S. House of Representatives passed a spending bill that includes funds designated for President Donald Trump's proposed border wall with Mexico, in an attempt to keep the government running. "However, we expect the proposal to be rejected by the Senate before Friday's midnight deadline, increasing the chance of a partial federal government shutdown," Danske Bank Research said in a note.

Meanwhile, tensions between the U.S. and China reignited after Washington indicted two people associated with China's Ministry of State Security on claims that they stole data from the U.S. government and companies across the world. China's foreign ministry rejected the allegations of economic espionage and urged the U.S. to reverse its stance.

Overnight, the S&P 500 fell 1.58%, led by losses in the energy and technology sectors, while the Nasdaq Composite closed 1.63% lower. Futures for the S&P 500 were down by 0.43% and for the Nasdaq 100 by 0.51% as of 6:30 a.m. ET.

Asian markets tracked losses on Wall Street, with the Shanghai SE Composite losing 0.79% and Japan's Nikkei 225 index down 1.11%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index closed 0.51% higher, with Tencent Holdings Ltd.'s shares gaining 4.51% after Chinese regulators reportedly approved some new games for sale in the country, lifting an approval freeze in place since March.

In Europe, the Euro Stoxx 50 index shed 0.69%, the FTSE 100 fell 0.37% and Germany's DAX index was down 0.36%.

"Heading as we are to potentially the worst monthly December performance for U.S. equity markets since the 1930's it would be easy to think that we could well be heading for further heavy declines," wrote Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK.

Yields on 10-year U.S. Treasurys hovered near 2.80%, while the dollar regained momentum, with the index tracking the currency's performance against a basket of peers rising 0.29% to 96.55. Investors await data on the U.S. economic growth and inflation today.

The euro lost 0.16% against the dollar, while the Japanese yen rose 0.12%. The pound gained 0.13% as U.K. GDP growth in the third quarter was confirmed at 0.6%.

Brent crude oil slid 1.69% to $53.43 per barrel on the ICE Futures Exchange. Gold fell 0.42% to $1,262.60 per ounce.

urn:contentItem:5HWD-4H41-JDJN-628R-00000-00Equity crowdfunding not just about money says guru Medved2016-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:46ZLexisNexisEquity crowdfunding not just about money says guru Medved

By David ShamahCrowdfunding guru Jon Medved (photo credit: Courtesy)

Investing in money-making ventures has been a traditional route to making more money – and for decades, the vehicle of choice for that kind of investing has been via buying shares in public companies traded on stock markets. But stock markets aren't what they used to be. Returns are generally flat these days, even negative – and even on their best days, stock markets return just a fraction of what the "real" investors in a company make.

That's bad for investors – and for society. The middle class in countries around the world, and especially the United States, is being squeezed not only by a lack of employment opportunities, but a lack of investment opportunities. Where in the past stock market investors had an opportunity to realized significant returns from stock investments, that has changed radically over the past decade – closing off yet another income-earning channel for the middle class, contributing to its erosion, and to ever-increasing income disparities between the top and bottom, many experts say.

But there's a new investment vehicle in town – one that promises to democratize investing, in the sense that it distributes the proceeds of successful companies much farther and wider than traditional investment vehicles. "Equity crowdfunding is finally going mainstream," according to Jon Medved, the CEO of OurCrowd, the Israeli investment firm that invented crowdfunding as the world knows it today. "Done right, it works. And it is changing the landscape of investing. Ordinary people with only tens of thousands of dollars to invest now have the same opportunities for major returns that were exclusively reserved for well-heeled venture and angel investors."

Call it the democratization of venture capital, said Medved at a press event announcing outlining a report on the firm's 2015 activity. "For the first time, ordinary people with $10,000 to $150,000 to invest have a shot at the enormous potential riches from investing in private companies. Crowdfunding is a way for millions of ordinary investors to get into the game and to realize some of those outsized returns from private companies. This new way is called equity crowdfunding. It promises to democratize the world of innovation finance and create a new model for building companies."

That crowdfunding is the new way to get rich is evident in the numbers, Medved said. "Venture capital and merger/acquisition activity was great in 2015, and crowdfunding, OurCrowd's specialty, 'arrived' last year as well. That's in contrast to investments in public companies, where the returns are much less, if not stagnant."

Medved is talking not about "regular returns" from investments – on average, blue chip stocks have provide a ten percent return annually over the past several decades, taking into account the ups and downs of the market – but about the "killer" investments, the ones that in the past could make a stockholder rich, if the investor "got in" early enough. If you bought Apple stock in 1980 and held on to it, for example, you would 400 times your investment today; if you got in on the Amazon IPO when it was first issued in 1997, you would have about 350x your initial investment now.

Those companies received financing not only on public exchanges, but also from private equity investors – the venture capitalists who put up X amount of money in exchange for a portion of the profits, if not the company itself. The VCs who invested in Apple saw their money grow 600 times since 1980; for Amazon it was 200 times. In some tech companies, like Oracle, the returns were much better for stock market investors than private equity investors (350x vs 50x). As long as average investors could get in on the party as well, everything worked out fine for everyone.

A changing equation

But in recent years that equation has changed dramatically. Almost all the returns for big tech companies that went public after 2000 – including Google (2004), Facebook (2012), and Twitter (2013) – have accrued to private equity investors. "IPOs are messy, because you have to comply with a lot of regulations and issue public reports and the like," said Medved. "If you can raise $60 billion without going public – that's the current valuation of Uber – then why would you want to go public? There are currently about 140 billion dollar-plus valuated tech companies that are still not public – and all the value those companies create are going to private investors."

And that group is an extremely limited one. Only an estimated 300,000 people have made at least one angel investment in the last two years in the US, according to the report. "That's a tiny number compared to the more than 130 million Americans who own stocks, or the estimated 10 million American accredited households with more than $1 million of investable assets, or $200,000 in annual income," Medved said.

"Suddenly, the estimated 130 million ordinary Americans who buy stocks and bonds (and scores of millions more around the world) have been shut out of the greatest current opportunity for building wealth. Instead, the gains are going only to a few thousand people who are rich and well connected enough to be private investors," he said.

Enter crowdfunding, the system whereby investors pool resources to reach the sum a start-up or more mature firm is seeking in a funding round. A crowdfunding platform essentially creates a venture capital fund with not just a few rich members' money, but with funds supplied by hundreds or thousands of individuals.

Breakdown of returns in capital market (gray) vs. private equity (orange) tech investments in recent years (OurCrowd/Xconomy)

Recent rule changes in the US and other countries allow accredited investors (who have at least a specific minimum net worth) to join a fund that lets them invest relatively modest sums in promising tech companies, instead of the millions of dollars that angels or venture capital funds invest in tech companies. While there was some debate in the US Securities and Exchange Commission about whether crowdfunding was a viable investment method – or a safe one, given that shysters could pose as entrepreneurs and relieve widows, orphans, and other vulnerable investors of their life savings – the numbers prove the case for crowdfunding, according to Medved.

As the Start-Up Nation, Israel has played an important role in building the world's tech economy – and a crucial role in developing crowdfunding as a way for ordinary investors to get in on the VC money-making party. Medved's OurCrowd was one of the first crowdfunding platforms in the world, established in 2012 just after the SEC in the US implemented rules allowing it.

In just two years, OurCrowd has invested over $200 million from accredited investors in 91 Israeli tech firms, "making us one of the largest investors in the Israeli tech ecosystem and one of the largest equity crowdfunding platforms globally. We are driving the democratization of venture capital, opening the door to tens of thousands of accredited investors who want to invest in the next generation of tech leaders," said Medved.

That democratization offers a way for those ordinary Americans – and ordinary people around the world – to benefit from the enormous profits generated by investments in tech firms, said Medved. " "We are still in the very early days of equity crowdfunding. While we are excited by the rapid progress to date, I think most of us are still unaware just how big this opportunity can ultimately become. I think we will all be surprised by the eventual size, importance and acceptance of equity crowdfunding. As access to capital is flattened around the globe, as deal flow is democratized, and as huge amounts of new money flow to great entrepreneurial companies,I think equity crowdfunding will take its rightful place as the fourth pillar of innovation finance —joining together with corporate finance, venture capital, and angel investment."

S&P Global Market Intelligence's daily overview of essential Financials news in the Middle East and Africa.

TOP NEWS

* Kenya-based Equity Group Holdings PLC's first-half profit declined 24% year over year to 9.1 billion shillings from 12.0 billion shillings, as loan-loss provisions increased to 7.7 billion shillings from 500 million shillings in the year-ago period.

* Russia's Sberbank of Russia is looking to open an office in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, Vedomosti reported. The office, which could be launched by the end of 2020, will help Sberbank clients implement Islamic finance projects and cooperate with funds, banks and companies in the Middle East.

As 'big tech' dominates cloud use for banks, regulators may need to get tougherBanks rely heavily on a small number of "big tech" players for cloud infrastructure. Industry insiders say a concentration of power in the hands of just a few providers creates risks for the financial sector.

Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan top gainers in strong Q2 i-bank trading The leading global investment banks had another strong trading quarter, with fixed income, currencies and commodities driving most of the revenue gains, S&P Global Market Intelligence data shows. U.S. banks continued to outperform European peers.

BANKING

* Capital Bank of Jordan said Eyas Khawaja has resigned as COO of the company, effective Sept. 10. The Jordan-based lender, meanwhile, appointed Manar Aabidi as the chief credit officer.

* Egypt-based Beltone Financial Holding SAE, a subsidiary of Orascom Investment Holding SAE, will set up three new nonbanking subsidiaries in September as part of its plan to return to profit in 2021, Reuters reported. The subsidiaries will offer consumer finance, financial leasing and venture capital services, CEO Ibrahim Karam told the news wire.

* Nigeria-based Guaranty Trust Bank PLC said dividend payments to holders of the bank's global depository receipts have been delayed as it is difficult to source U.S. dollars in the current environment, Reuters wrote.

* Kuwait International Bank KSCP received regulatory approval for the issuance of sukuk worth $750 million or equivalent in other currencies as part of a $2 billion sukuk program.

* Serge Ekué has succeeded Christian Adovelande as president of Banque Ouest Africaine de Développement, Financial Afrik reported. Adovelande is leaving the bank after nearly a decade at the helm.

FINANCIAL SERVICES

* Qatar Islamic Insurance Group QPSC and Allianz International Ltd. and its associates in insurance operations signed an exclusive agreement in health insurance.

* Al Ramz Corp. Investment and Development PJSC appointed Sameer Kamal al-Ansari a member of its board.

POLICY AND REGULATION

* Angola's central bank issued new rules against capital flight and foreign exchange fraud, Portuguese news agency Lusa reported. From now on, banks will have to carry out checks to ensure the validity of invoices issued by overseas companies requiring payments in U.S. dollars or euros. It is the latest move by the regulator to stem demand for foreign currency, which is in short supply due to a slump in oil export revenue.

* Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune said the country will let its private sector establish banks, air and sea transport companies for passengers and goods to cut spending, as it aims to tackle financial problems caused by a fall in energy export revenues, Reuters wrote.

INDUSTRY NEWS

* South Africa's Treasury warned that a default or fiscal crisis could see the economy lose roughly 2 trillion rand by the end of the decade, Moneyweb reported.

* Mali's political crisis deepened Aug. 18 as military forces staged a mutiny and arrested government officials including President Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta, who has been under growing pressure to step down, news wires reported. One of the soldiers' leaders and a regional official confirmed to Agence France-Presse and The Associated Press that Keïta had been detained along with Prime Minister Boubou Cissé. Finance Minister Abdoulaye Daffe was also arrested in the mutiny, which fueled fears of a military coup.

* Zimbabwe's Treasury and banks are in dispute over relief payments offered to civil servants and pensioners amid the coronavirus pandemic, Bloomberg News wrote. The government had agreed to refund banks for administrative charges relating to a foreign-currency allocation totaling $36 million per month, but the Treasury said the lenders should not get reimbursements, according to the report.

* Nigeria's foreign-currency crisis is triggering an increase in business owners' demand for bitcoin, Nigeria's Business Day wrote.

urn:contentItem:558Y-XNG1-JD35-239K-00000-00Equity markets: A whole new bourse game2012-03-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:46ZLexisNexisEQUITIESEquity markets: A whole new bourse gameElliot Wilson Elliot Wilson

More Chinese companies repatriate; Shanda Interactive 'to list subsidiary'

Shanda Interactive's shareholders did more than pave the way for the privatization of one of China's leading web-and-gaming companies when they voted overwhelmingly on February 16 to back a $750 million management buyout - they also marked the end of an era.

For more than a decade, China's tech titans made pilgrimages to New York, in search of capital, credibility and - through Nasdaq stock listings - a critical mass of knowledgeable investors.

Now, disillusioned by soggy valuations and tighter US regulations, many are considering making the trek home, delisting from New York and relisting in Hong Kong or Shanghai - bourses that guarantee higher valuations, bustling retail-investor communities and light-touch regulators.

Analysts point to a long-term process of repatriation - one implicitly encouraged by authorities in Beijing - as Chinese companies opt to return to the mainland, with others choosing never to leave home in the first place.

"This is part of a general and ongoing trend," says Dick Wei, a technology analyst at JPMorgan Chase in Hong Kong. "Valuations in China and Hong Kong are higher. And as far as listing requirements go, they are far less vigorous in Hong Kong or the mainland than [they are in] the US."

Then there is the sheer amount of capital within the mainland. China is not yet as wealthy as the US, but its population boasts a large savings pool desperate to invest in solid, reliable blue chips - and in the People's Republic, former US-listed big tech firms are as close as you get to corporate royalty.

"This market [the process of delisting in the US and relisting in China] is being driven by China's huge savings pool"David Wolf, Wolf Group Asia
"This market [the process of delisting in the US and relisting in China] is being driven by China's huge savings pool," says David Wolf, president and CEO of Beijing-based corporate consultancy Wolf Group Asia. "There's more than enough capital in the mainland market to support some big IPOs by China's leading tech entrepreneurs. This is a process that has only just begun."

The news is worrying for executives at Nasdaq and NYSE Euronext, owners of the New York Stock Exchange. At the end of 2011, 174 Chinese stocks were listed in the US, represented by the USX China Index. This roster includes internet firms NetEase and Sohu, and search website Baidu, all of which turned their founders into overnight billionaires after New York listings.

Yet some US investors might not miss an outflow of China stocks. Jialong Shi, a tech analyst at CLSA in Hong Kong, says US investors, burnt by profits warnings and ropey governance, "tend to price in a discount on Chinese companies".

Statistics appear to bear this out. The USX China Index is trading at around 12 times earnings, compared with 20 times for Hong Kong's Hang Seng Composite Information Technology Index.

And looking at the valuations of single stocks, Perfect World, China's fourth-largest online gaming firm, trades at around 4.5 times its estimated earnings in New York, while its smaller rival, NetDragon Websoft, is trading at just shy of 60 times earnings in Hong Kong. Such valuations, analysts says, give tech firms greater impetus to relocate back home.

Many believe a trickle from west to east could become a flood. And it's not just tech firms seeking to return home. Sixteen mainland corporates have announced plans to delist from the US since 2010, including Funtalk China Holdings, which delisted from the NYSE in August, and property data provider China Real Estate Information. Funtalk's senior vice-president, Francis Wan, subsequently refused to rule out a relisting in Shanghai or Hong Kong.

Analysts highlight several Chinese tech firms frustrated by their own rock-bottom valuations. "I'd look at [online game developers] Changyou and Giant Interactive Group," says one Hong Kong-based analyst, who declined to be named. "Those are the [type of] companies that would benefit from [relisting in] China."

Another points to Ninetowns Internet Technology, an online provider of international trade solutions. Changyou, as of February 21, was trading at 5.5 times estimated earnings, with Giant trading at 7.1 times and Ninetowns at just shy of 13 times.

Most mainland firms depart the scene quietly and with a modicum of grace, but not all. Harbin Electric chief executive Yang Tianfu, after delisting his firm from the NYSE in November, said he was "tired of the US", and he could "easily" complete a listing in Shanghai or Hong Kong. US short-sellers, including Citron Research, had alleged the firm was being run fraudulently; Yang, in turn, complained he "couldn't communicate with investors".

Not all corporates will simply swap one stock market for another. Shanda Interactive, for instance, is likely to follow a more nuanced route. Since Beijing bans Chinese firms from having dual mainland listings at group and subsidiary level, Shanda Interactive co-founder Chen Tianqiao is expected to pursue the listing of one or more of his subsidiaries.

This could include web-based gaming firm Aurora, or Cloudary, an online literary platform, which has flirted with its own New York listing. (Shanda Interactive also owns 72% of another Nasdaq-listed subsidiary, Shanda Games.) This, notes CLSA's Shi, will leave Chen free to complete a mainland listing of Shanda Interactive at a later date.

Either way, this is a process that has just started. When 87.3% of Shanda Interactive's shareholders voted on February 16 to escape from New York, one era ended and another began.

Chinese entrepreneurs might still list shares in New York, to keep their fortunes far from Beijing's prying eyes, but the Big Apple is no longer the promised land it once was.
