urn:contentItem:5X1T-3D41-JB20-G48M-00000-00Equity Residential at Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Real Estate Conference - Final2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:46ZLexisNexis091019a12721356.756Equity Residential at Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch Global Real Estate Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Mark J. Parrell

Equity Residential - President, CEO & Trustee

Conference Call Participants

* Jeffrey Alan Spector

BofAMerrill Lynch, Research Division - MD and Head of United States REITs

* Shirley Wu

BofAMerrill Lynch, Research Division - Research Analyst

Presentation

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR, MD AND HEAD OF UNITED STATES REITS, BOFAMERRILL LYNCH, RESEARCH DIVISION: (technical difficulty)

Residential. I'm Jeff Spector. I'm here with my colleague, Shirley Wu. And this is webcast. And speaking for Equity Residential today is Mark Parrell. Mark is President and CEO.

Mark, if you don't mind providing maybe 5-plus minutes of comments about the company. It's a broad group of investors. So some people are familiar with the company. Some people may not be as familiar.

And then we'll be happy to get into Q&A. We'd like to make this as interactive as possible. So if you have a question, feel free to raise your hand, and Shirley and I will choose on you to ask the question. Otherwise, Shirley and I will moderate.

With that, Mark, please go ahead.

MARK J. PARRELL, PRESIDENT, CEO & TRUSTEE, EQUITY RESIDENTIAL: Right. Well, first, thanks to our friends at BofA, Jeff and Shirley, for including us in this event. I'm Mark Parrell, the CEO. Just a little briefer, primer on Equity Residential.

So we own 80,000 apartments throughout the United States. Those apartments are in Boston, New York, Washington, D.C., Southern California, San Francisco, Seattle and an emerging presence in Denver. We tend own apartments that are predominantly urban, so in the dense centers of cities that differentiates us from some of our competitors and dense suburban areas. So we'll be in both of those areas in cities, and we're looking for a high-quality customer.

Our average rent is about $2,800 a month. Our average household income of our resident is $122,000 a month. They pay us about 21% of their income in rent. So they're a very affluent subsector to be tied to. They have been getting raises. They've been doing well as customers. We talk a lot about customer quality at Equity Residential.

We also have a development presence. We have development projects particularly in Boston, a few things in California and Seattle going on. We've made that presence smaller over time. We're probably 2% of our capital in development now. But we have developed more in the past. As prices of construction went up and as rents grew less quickly, that put us in a position where we didn't think that was an advantageous place to invest our capital.

We've been putting money into things like renovations throughout the portfolio. So we put about $50 million a year into the portfolio in terms of kitchen and bath redos and things like that. We find it's terrific returns on that, 10% to 15% cash-on-cash returns. We also do that to keep competitive with some of the new supply in our markets.

We've also, I think, benefited greatly from the continuing very strong demand across our markets. So right now, we are 96.5% occupied. We were 96.4% occupied this week last year. So we said on the earnings call 6 weeks ago that if in this period of time because we're heading as a seasonal business towards the end of the year, our transaction volume goes down. People are less likely to move in the fourth quarter and the first quarter than the second and third. So there's just less activity. But as we head into this time of the year, we try to hold occupancy and we indeed are holding occupancy.

We're seeing good demand across the whole system. Supply pressure, particularly in New York, is considerably less. We do see supply pressure increasing in Los Angeles. We've spoken about that on the call. And we told all of you our numbers in Los Angeles will be lower in the second half of the year than the first. But we're holding in there. New lease rates in New York -- in Los Angeles are flat. But occupancy is great at 96.8%, and we feel good about that market at this point.

Talking a little bit about investments. There have been some interesting shifts in the last couple of months. As rates have declined significantly as they've declined, as people's interest in hard assets has increased, we have seen a decline in cap rates across all our markets. I'm going to put New York aside for a moment, and I'll talk about that in a moment. But across our other 6 markets, we see that because there's just more people in the auction tent. There's more folks that want to own our kind of high-quality product as well as the value-add stuff that we want to sell.

So we often are sellers of $500 million to $1 billion or so of our assets a year, just stuff that's become obsolete. And I'll tell you, the value-add bid is extremely strong for that product right now. And our ability to recycle that into better, newer assets is improved. So you should expect to see us sell more and buy more to sort of match over the next couple of years if that pattern continues. The last time these were so close, and by so close, I mean A and B assets in the same market having such close cap rates, was in the '06 to '07 period. That was back in that era that was because of an excess of debt in the system. Now it's just everyone chasing yield.

So we again believe absolute cap rates have declined. Values have gone up. In our markets in New York, we don't know what's happened. It's post the rent control. So we have not seen meaningful transaction activity in New York on our kinds of assets. So those are $100 million-plus, large, high rises in Manhattan or Brooklyn that are either under the rent stabilization regime or under the -- we have -- about half of our units are not rent controlled at all. So those are market rates. So we just haven't seen a trade. So I can't speak to value here. I have no reason to believe it's gone either direction significantly, but I just don't have an input on that.

So I'll stop there, Jeff, and throw it back to you, guys.

Questions and Answers

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: Thanks, Mark. Maybe at a high level, I'm not sure if you -- how long have you been in the CoC now? A year plus?

MARK J. PARRELL: It feels like that. It's been 9 months.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: 9 months. So I saw Martin in Chicago recently, and he said it's the old team but the new -- new team but the old team. I guess first, just how are you enjoying the role? Was there any strategy shift or anything that you and the Board are thinking about now that you've been in the role, let's say, for 9 months? And how is the new -- how is the team running?

MARK J. PARRELL: Great. So I've been at the company 20 years. I was the CFO for the 11 years preceding, getting this role in January of this year. So the strategy is ours. The whole executive team owned it together, this urban, dense, suburban strategy. So prior to taking the job, I did spend some time doing a strategy review. We've typically done that with new CEOs and really looked hard at the portfolio. But again, I wouldn't suggest there is any big changes because I'm a product of the system.

I believe in the strategy of owning dense urban and dense suburban product, of having high-wage renters, of not having concerns about things like people buying single-family homes. Very few of our folks move out to buy single-family homes. Our capital spending -- so an important thing for you journalists in the room to think about is CapEx.

So what does it cost a company like ours to maintain their assets as is and have them be attractive to renters? And for us, that's about 8% or 1 month's rent per year. For all our competitors except one, who owns a portfolio similar to ours, that number is twice as high. So they have -- because they own suburban product, they have a lot more capital maintenance requirements. Refrigerators cost the same, whether you're putting them in a unit that is getting $3,000 a month rent or whether it's getting to $1,200 a month rent.

So we have a real advantage in owning the portfolio we own because we don't suffer from competition from single-family housing to the same extent, because we have lower capital cost, because we think our markets are more vibrant. Places like New York do get a lot of supply on occasion, but they work through it so rapidly. So I'm very enthused about the strategy, Jeff. I remain completely committed to it and having looked at it, I think, with a pretty critical eye last year.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: And so from just one follow-up and then I'll take the question from the audience. So the current footprint, as you mentioned in your opening remarks, you mentioned your existing cities plus emerging market, Denver, happy with the footprint and thinking about that in terms of recession. We can ask a lot about recession scenarios, As versus Bs, coastal versus Sunbelt, again, where the portfolio is today. Are you happy with that footprint?

MARK J. PARRELL: Sure. So there's a couple of different questions in there. So maybe to talk just about where we've allocated our capital. So I think you should expect and you've seen us already move our capital a little bit within markets. So for example, in the Washington, D.C. area, we bought an asset in Rockville, Maryland. So that is a close-in suburban location. The average household income there was about $110,000. The average income in our portfolio is about $120,000. So it's a good fit. Those are folks that drive to their jobs, probably the National Institutes of Health and that cluster of biotech jobs that surrounds it in Bethesda.

So those are good residents for us. So you'll see us be in there, not just to be in the District of Columbia but to be in some of these suburbs that have similar customer characteristics. But we're not interested in being in the further out suburbs. We're either taking a lower-quality customer or a customer that's going to be very attracted to a single-family housing lifestyle.

So you'll see us do that a little bit of a rotation in the system. We bought a couple of suburban assets in Denver as well as the 4 urban assets we have. So again, a little bit more balanced between dense suburban and urban. We're about 25%, 35% suburban already. So it's just a little bit of a shift there within the markets and to be a little less concentrated in some places like Northwest D.C. and the Upper West Side of New York, where we just had a big concentration. We'd stay in other urban submarkets, but we'll just spread out a little bit more.

In between the markets, we're about 1% of our NOI in Denver. I'd like to see that number and the Board would to be more in 4% and 5% range. That will happen over time. I think some of that capital will come from a variety of markets. We have older assets again to sell. You may see our total exposure to Washington, D.C. decline a little over time. That's been a market that's been very supplied and will continue to be very supplied, we think. It does have pretty good results at the current time. So I think those are the sort of things that the group has been thinking about in the last year or so.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: Thank you. I think we have a question over here.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. Just on the comment regarding your client cap rates. Just the magnitude of what you're seeing cap rates decline and over what time period are we talking about. Are you talking about as recent as past 2 months? Is it something that's been occurring throughout the year?

MARK J. PARRELL: I'd say since the big shift down in rates, so call it the last 2 months. I mean -- and again, you're doing smaller sample sizes, right? I mean I'm giving you a feel for what we're seeing. We see product pricing. And there's a lot for sale right now. A lot of merchant builders who started building 5, 6, 7 years ago, they have funded deadlines so they need to sell. Or frankly, they just look at the conditions and the price and they want to sell.

So there's a lot of product out there to be bought. And so we see that Denver, we see significant cap rate declines. We've seen in some of the other markets as well. And then in the New York again, we just don't have a sample to speak to.

SHIRLEY WU, RESEARCH ANALYST, BOFAMERRILL LYNCH, RESEARCH DIVISION: Great. So now moving on to some of your markets. You mentioned this a little bit earlier where you're talking about L.A. But could you highlight some markets that are doing a little bit better than expected, worse than expected, call it, through this peak, end of this peak leasing season? And San Diego is doing a little bit worse. How do you see some of those markets performing into, let's say, 2020?

MARK J. PARRELL: Well, I'm just a bit hesitant. I think a lot of that color belongs to the earnings call. I appreciate the question though. I will say again, we feel terrific about demand across the portfolio and the physical occupancy we have. We talked a little bit on the call about L.A. I gave you a little bit of color on L.A., which is a market we just keep an eye on. So I guess I'm going to kind of demur on that question, if I could. Nice try.

SHIRLEY WU: Okay. I got to try. I think we have a question in the back.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: I may be dating myself or I may be wrong, but didn't EQR exit Denver in [2016]? And if so, why is it now back in Denver?

MARK J. PARRELL: Great. So the question was did EQR own Denver before and why did it exit it and why are we back more or less, right? So we did exit it. We sold it to the Starwood organization as part of a big sale in 2016. We own almost entirely garden product at that point. So all of what we owned in Denver effectively was older garden product. So we always like Denver. And at that time, we said it was a portfolio, not a market exit. So we've actually owned Denver since the IPO in 1993 all the way through January of 2016. We sold the portfolio to Starwood. And we said we'd go back and we just look for an opportunity to go back. So we like everything about Denver.

So again, just to check that list, good, high-wage job growth and a good number of high-wage jobs to begin with, relatively high single-family housing costs, barriers to entry into the market in terms of construction. That's really in the form in Denver being an expensive -- a more expensive place to build over time. Denver has a lot of new supply. I mean they need to build out their downtown, and we'll feel that competition. But we underwrote the deals with relatively low near-term rent growth, and we're doing well in Denver. We're very happy with the 6 assets that we own. So yes, good memory.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: Maybe we can focus on demand year-to-date. As you said, it's been a strong year, better than a lot of people expected. Can you talk about your current renter a little bit more, the profile and then what you might see from next 5 years plus, let's say, on how that renter may change? And who's coming in and out of the portfolio?

MARK J. PARRELL: That's a great question. Most important thing we think in our business is demand. That's likely unsolvable problem. Supply comes and goes. But if you don't have demand, then you don't have a place you want to invest your capital, we think. So we look at our -- as part of this, again, transition in just our periodic process of looking at the strategy, we did some additional demographic research. So our average resident is 33 years old. The average -- the biggest cohort of baby -- excuse me, millennials is 28. So we have tailwinds still. We have more people entering the pool of people that will want to rent with us.

We also have done a lot of research, and a lot of folks that end up leaving apartment living do so because they've had their second child. And if you look at the age at which people get married and the age at which college-age women tend to have children, those are all increasing. We think the period of time from when people graduate from college to when they have their second child is an increasing period of time. So we both think we have more customers and we have them for longer as we go forward, Jeff.

So as we think about our demographic, we're very excited. We think this group of people and the attractiveness in our markets -- of our markets to college graduates, to young people, to just everyone of every age group who's interested in living in these exciting cities with these great-paying jobs and these good careers mean it's just a real magnet. And we still see great demand.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: And maybe one follow-up on the markets in Denver. I guess is the common thread tech? Is that what's driving this? And are there other tech markets that you're excited about? Or again, these are the markets you're most focused on?

MARK J. PARRELL: Well, we're looking for high-wage job growth. We don't necessarily chase the tech folks around. A lot of our high-wage job growth in this country has been tech, right? But we do look for that growth in the areas in here in New York, new media. Certainly, we love the biotech cluster up in Cambridge, which I think when you talk about tech, you need to be careful because it's not like the auto industry. The auto industry, and I lived in Detroit, is one thing. And there's not a way that all of it can thrive and it kind of all moves together so to speak. Tech is so large that the social media part of it, I would argue, could do poorly. But the biotech clusters in South San Francisco, San Diego and Cambridge can do great or vice versa.

So we don't worry about being tied to tech as much as one company. Being tied to a single employer in a market is concerning. So to be in a city where it was just all about one company, that would be concerning to us. But when you look at New York, for example, the financial services bust was certainly significant. But because of the built-in advantages here of having a great university system, a great quality of life, a great attractiveness to this demographic, this city has repopulated itself.

Financial services, less relevant. Technology and new media, more relevant. Our markets have those characteristics. So if Amazon isn't big in Seattle anymore, somebody else will be. And Microsoft waxed and waned and Boeing waxed and waned and Seattle kept growing. So those are the kind of markets we want to be in.

SHIRLEY WU: So why don't we talk a little bit about policy? So rent regulation is becoming such a significant issue around the country, with first New York but now more conversations around California with AB-1482. So could you give us a little bit more color on what's happening in California and maybe some of the new dialogues that's happening in New York as well and maybe even a little bit on the [rent stabilization] act of New York City?

MARK J. PARRELL: Sure. So just that comment on New York because again, I know some of you have listened to all our calls and some of you don't. So we have 9,500 units in the New York metro area. Of those 9,500, 3,000 are outside the city of New York, so not subject to this conversation. They're mostly in North New Jersey. Of the 6,500 that remain, 3,500 of those units are rent-stabilized and 3,000 are market rate. The market rate units have no controls on them from this law effectively, and we can continue to price them as we see fit. For the 3,500 units, there are new rules about renewals.

And to sum it all up basically, we were charging 4% to 4.5% for renewals, and now we're charging about 3.5% for renewals. The total impact on us of that change over an entire year is something on the order of 20 or 30 basis points for New York and something on the order of 4 basis points negative for the whole portfolio. So not a particularly material impact to the company.

I would also point out that this is bad policy. This is a bad idea for New York even though it didn't hurt us at that much. It's going to restrict the amount of supply. And because it's going to restrict the amount of supply by deterring people from building because of these rent regulations, those market rate units we own -- and by the way, the 3,500 that I told you were rent-stabilized, every year, certain restrictions expire and they move into the market rate pool. So those 3,000 market-rate units will get bigger by about 150 to 200 units a year every year for us through 2028.

So as I said on the call, I'm excited about New York's demand, and you heard me speak of it. But I'm really excited about the supply constraint that this rule -- these new rules create because the incentive to build in New York has been diminished, and so we're going to have a little lower renewal growth for a while. But I wonder if we're not going to do pretty good on these market rate units. I also wonder about what our leasing and advertising and turnover costs are going to be because our properties are going to have longer stays. So if I give you a smaller renewal increase, you'll stay at the property longer. So my retention will increase. So my advertising cost will go down. And the turnover cost every time someone leaves, we incur 21 days or so on average of vacancy. We have to clean the unit. Those will go down, too.

So we haven't seen much of an impact from the New York rules. But again, I think it's a bad idea. And I think the city and the state will see that. And I think some policymakers have already made comments to that effect.

California is voting today. So switching to the state of California. The state Senate is voting right now on AB-1482, which is the rent control Bill in the state of California. It provides for a CPI plus 5% cap on renewals, CPI as defined by the local area CPI. So for places like San Francisco, that number is often 3%, not the 1% to 2% we think of as national CPI. But in any of that, that's probably creating a 7% to 8% cap on renewals in California. It doesn't do anything to new leases.

So it doesn't -- it allows vacancy the control. It provides certain additional eviction protections, just cause eviction protections for residents. It sunsets in 10 years. It has a 15-year new construction exemption where properties 15 years or younger aren't subject to any of these rules. And it also importantly prevents local regulation. So it preserves Costa-Hawkins, which is the existing state law, and prevents local regulation of housing.

So that's great. So that laws come down. As an industry, we think rent regulation is a bad idea. We think these bill is a bad idea. But we decided through the California Apartment Association, which is the industry organ on these matters, not to oppose it. So I will tell you again, I think it will restrict the number of units built on the market. I think Governor Newsom has pushed hard for more production. I think this will lead to less. But I'll also say that for us and for some of our other competitors that I think operate within the rules now, it's not likely to be all that significant, but we have to see what the Legislature passes. If it passes the Senate, it has to go back to the Assembly. The Governor has said he would sign it.

So I'm not sure if it will get done and in what manner exactly. But again, we feel like the quality of the conversation in California has been great. Tenant advocates have been in there. The industry has been in there. And the New York deal was cut in the dark at night. There were mistakes in the statutes. It's hard to understand. It's very, very complicated.

So you asked, I think, Shirley, about just administering in New York. Administering New York is a full-time job. But in California, we feel like it's been a much more open and public conversation and that the law is likely to make a lot more sense. But we'll see what actually comes out.

SHIRLEY WU: I know it's only been like 2 months now. But have you seen any marginal changes in, let's say, consumer behavior in New York, so maybe like lower turnover? Are you seeing that in the consumer?

MARK J. PARRELL: Too early. Yes, it's too early.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: Can you explain -- I think the key difference you were saying between California and New York, California, I think you said that 15 years, new construction excluded versus -- are we saying -- you're saying in New York, I think New York would be the most impacted by less incentives to build because in New York, there is no carve-out?

MARK J. PARRELL: So in -- I'm sorry, in New York, to really build in New York, it's very hard because you're competing against hospitality. We used to compete against condo as well. To get land is difficult in New York. So most people use the old 421a, now called Affordable New York Program. The Affordable New York Program is a good program but not as good as 421a from a developer point of view. So it hasn't encouraged as much construction already. These rules that are going to cover these limitations on renewals are more problematic. They create another reason not to do Affordable New York. And that, in our opinion, will reduce supply even more. It also does create regulatory uncertainty in the market. That's also bad for capital allocation.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: And then just to clarify to make sure everyone understands, in California, if this does pass, then this is it, local municipalities will follow it? It's a state law, at least it seems like you would be done for the next 10 years?

MARK J. PARRELL: From your lips to God's ears, so what I'd say is what's going to happen next is if the law passes and it's not in any way, shape or form assured, there was a proposition on the ballot in California called Proposition 10 in June of -- excuse me, November of 2018. That was a proposal that would have allowed local regulation and a lot of other things that we thought, as an industry, were really bad for California. It's really going to be an impediment to affordability and certainly bad for our industry, and we fought it. And we spoke to policymakers. We spoke to the public. And we won that battle by 20 percentage points.

So the people in the state of California resoundingly rejected Proposition 10. Every single county except San Francisco County voted against it. That proposal, a variant of it, is likely to be on the ballot again in November 2020. And I can assure you, the industry will oppose it just as vigorously as it opposed it the last time because it's just plain a bad idea.

It's going to reduce again the amount of housing that's built. It's going to lower the quality of the housing that exists in this market. And if Governor Newsom was a 3 million units built, I guarantee you that's going to cause that not to be the case. So we're hopeful we can have that conversation again with the public and the policymakers, but it's going to be at least a 2-step process.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: And if there are these limits, I guess, in place, is there any investment opportunity for a public REIT or EQR to get involved in something like this where I guess from an ESG standpoint, it's a nice check the box but also, of course, from an investment return standpoint?

MARK J. PARRELL: So by that, you mean in the conversations with policymakers?

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: No, but like if there is a limit on new affordable, is there anything out there you're seeing as an opportunity for EQR to get involved in from a return standpoint?

MARK J. PARRELL: So again, we have 80,000 units. About 3,000 of them are affordable. I mean we have properties here in New York where the prevailing rents are $3,700 a month on a unit and the affordable rent is $700. So I mean we're trying to be constructive in this process. I think when you create programs like Affordable New York and do it right in the 421a program, when you do zoning reform like New York did with Long Island City, we will respond to incentives. And the private sector, I think, should be mobilized by the government to build more units.

That's the answer to a lack of affordable housing. It doesn't reducing the price. It's encouraging a supply. So I guess I'd answer it by saying we've got to be in the dialogue. I mean if we all put our money together, all the public REITs, and created $1 billion fund to build housing, that's just not that many units in any one of our markets.

I don't know what any one entity can do to change things. I think it's the government changing some of the rules. And again, that relates to zoning, regulatory costs, incentives to build new housing. That's where the action is on the public policy side. For us, to do some of those things are great. We already do them, and we're very active philanthropically in our markets, but that's a hard way to move the needle.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: Okay. Maybe we could turn to supply. In latest marketing meetings, that's been the hot question. Our data source has changed. So even ourselves, we're trying to get through the answer for supply for 2020. Can you comment on 2020 at this point?

MARK J. PARRELL: Yes. So in our investor materials, which are on our website, we talk about supply by markets. So just a word about our process because there's so many different data sources. I should be clear about this. So in every market, we draw boundaries.

So for example, in New York, we look at where our residents move because we see their forwarding addresses, and we try to figure out what the competitive set is. And for us, that's all of Manhattan, that's Long Island City, other parts of Queens, almost -- a good part of Brooklyn, North New Jersey, but not places like Westchester County, Central New Jersey or Connecticut where we don't have material operations and where we don't see our residents moving. That doesn't compete with us in our opinion.

So then we look at those areas. And we have people on the ground in every market, and they drive market or subway the market and look around and see what's for sale -- or what's being built, pardon me. And we keep track of all of that. We then check it against one of the big recognized data sources, and that's our number.

So we see the number next year lower in 2020, New York considerably so, Los Angeles considerably so. We think Boston will be up year-over-year and will be more in the center of Boston. So that will be more impactful to us because we have a lot of properties in the center of Boston. We see D.C. is about the same. So in our footprint, about 12,000 units again. So D.C. is just a market that just as consistently had pretty high supply. Seattle, about the same, though again a little bit more in the central district, business district, less in the suburbs. And you may feel it a little bit in Seattle. San Francisco, about the same. And again, that's such an underhoused market. We won't feel it. Lower in L.A., lower in Orange County, lower in San Diego. So we like the supply picture go into next year. And I think Los Angeles, as I told you, is going to feel it at the end of this year. But you'll start feeling better about it because the supply will abate next year.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: That supply pressure, does it continue into '20? Or in New York and L.A., is it enough of a -- it was a big decrease, I know, in New York this year. It sounds like even lower next year. L.A., lower. So for New York at least, does that start to really fade, that supply pressure?

MARK J. PARRELL: Yes. I mean one of the reasons we like New York is we think supply has been -- by the regulations and just by the cost here to build been really effective and that there'll be less built for a while in the market. So yes.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: Okay. Great. One follow-up I had on just thinking about, again, A versus B popular question at the conference and latest meetings has been on recession. I may have asked this earlier, but I don't know if we answered it. I guess how should we think about A rents versus B rents? And a lot of the feedback to us during our meetings is just the thought process that A would get hit the most during a recession. Is that true? I know you're focused on your -- the affluent customer. But technically, I don't know if EQR is charging A rents on average in markets. Or maybe you are.

MARK J. PARRELL: If the challenge is that we're not charging enough rent, I think we're up for it. So just if the question is like customer kind of quality, durability in a recession...

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: People -- conceptually, I guess, people think that A rent will get hit the most during a recession. And people will trade down to B. B would be the most resilient.

MARK J. PARRELL: -

Well, we can use New York as an example. What typically happens at this point in the cycle is rents in Manhattan are starting to go up. People will start to cycle to New Jersey, and we have some great assets in New Jersey, and they're doing pretty well. When rents go down in these A assets and these A locations, the people in the B properties and the B locations will move to the A assets.

So if you kept your job and you're happy and you feel secure and you can live somewhere where you couldn't afford to live before, you'll move in. So if my rents come down and crowd the B assets, there's a reason those assets were less preferred than ours. So those people will move out and move to our assets, and the B rents will decline. This is a big interrelated ecosystem. One variable doesn't move without the other.

So I don't see how it's likely that in the same geography, you can have just A rents damaged and B rents are okay or vice versa really. I think it all kind of goes together. If A rents collapse, they'll collapse on top of B. The B renters will move into A. The B rents will collapse to C. The whole system will move down.

SHIRLEY WU: So why don't we talk a little bit more generally then on the apartment sector as a whole? What happened last time with the recession and what's different now? And if we were to go into recession now, what could happen?

MARK J. PARRELL: Yes. I'm going to go out on a limb and say rents will go down if we have a recession. So what's different? The last recession was extreme. I mean they called it the Great Recession for a reason. We've had to 2 pretty extreme recessions lately, right, the big tech bust in the early 2000s and what happened in 2008. So I'd argue those were pretty extreme recessions. A lot of the conversations that we've had have been maybe the next recession is a little more traditional recession, inventory-based or otherwise and not as severe, in which case again, we wouldn't struggle as much.

But I guess in a recession, our rents will cycle. When you're capitalized like we are, some recessions can provide opportunities. So we bought a lot of good, inexpensive assets, including here in New York, in the height of the recession. So if there's an opportunity to purchase in a recession, our balance sheet with our low leverage, our A rating, A- credit rating, that will give us, Shirley, some ammunition. So again, we don't like going through recessions, but they are points where we have opportunity, and we do look at them in both ways.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: Is your technology different today in how you're running the portfolio? So from an operational standpoint, you might be able to do a better job than 10 years ago? Or is it about the same?

MARK J. PARRELL: No, I think it's better. I think some of the tools haven't changed. We still use, pardon me, LRO, our lease rent optimizing system, which is a revenue management system. So we still use some of these systems that have been around, but we know how to use them better. And we have adjuncts we put on top of them. We know what operating -- we have more experience. Our Chief Operating Officer has been doing it 20 years. He used to run revenue.

So we just have a lot of experience. So I would hope, Jeff, we do better every one of these experiences both as a company and as an industry because we have more experience with the tools. We're probably with the Internet a little bit more aware of changes in, for example, demand. We can see the number of inquiries for New York apartments versus Los Angeles apartments on the Internet. We have more demand transparency. And if we saw something collapse, we probably see it earlier.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: Maybe we can tie that into and conclude on the balance sheet, where it stands today. And we've seen Simon do some long-dated paper at very good rates. Just what are your thoughts at this point?

MARK J. PARRELL: Yes. Certainly, the reduction in rates presented an opportunity for everyone. So EQR did a 2.5% coupon, 2.5% for 5% yield, which was the lowest yield any REIT has ever done on a 10-year security. So I'm very proud of that. We just saw the opportunity and we took it. It was actually -- we have this debt sitting on our commercial paper facility, and it was cheaper to term it out and to leave it in our commercial paper. So it's actually accretive to term it out than to leave it short term. That tells you how The Street or how the rate market is thinking about short-term rates, right? The rates are going to go down a fair amount. So in any event, we did that.

The balance sheet is in the best condition it's ever been. I mean we cover our debt service for 4.5x and we got terrific liquidity. I mean if there is -- again, we don't hope for a recession, but our balance sheet is both the shield and the sword. And if an opportunity came to use it, we wouldn't hesitate to use it. We have capacity to issue debt without issuing equity to buy assets if we saw fit to do that. And we wouldn't hesitate again if we saw assets worth buying.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: I should have asked. Any concern on GSE reform change or privatization?

MARK J. PARRELL: Yes. So a lot of news about GSE reform. I don't know how much will actually get done given how close, I guess, we are to the election and the fact that Congress needs to act on most of it. Because we sold most of our assets that were in, for example, suburban Denver that were predominantly financed by the GSEs, we have less risk than most do as it relates to GSEs. When we sell assets in our big markets, we're usually selling them to a cash buyer. So we're not as concerned with our buyer needing to be financed by the GSEs. But I think it behooves the government not to be disruptive in reordering the capital markets in the apartment business because I think they operate pretty effectively and Fannie and Freddie do a pretty good job. But again, I think single-family is the main story. I don't -- there were some stuff in that piece I read from Treasury about multi, but it was 95% about single-family.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: And then just to conclude, we have 3 rapid-fire questions, just very quick answers. BofAML's U.S. economists now estimate a 1 in 3 chance of a recession within the next 12 months. Are you and your Board discussing recession more during recent meetings, the same as earlier in the year or not at all?

MARK J. PARRELL: I'd say about the same.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: With macro risk rising, are you seeing any signs of a slowdown or pullback from your tenants in the last couple of months?

MARK J. PARRELL: I just don't feel comfortable answering that question.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: Okay. Which of the following sector do you think could surprise expectations the most for being defensive in the next recession, industrial, retail, office or residential?

MARK J. PARRELL: I'm going to vote residential, a shocking development.

JEFFREY ALAN SPECTOR: Great. Thank you.

MARK J. PARRELL: Thank you.

SHIRLEY WU: Thank you.

urn:contentItem:5Y0D-NW11-F021-632H-00000-00Era of self-regulation online is coming to an end;Platform providers are set to face new rules as the government tries to assert control of the internet2020-01-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:46ZLexisNexisNEWSVersion:1Era of self-regulation online is coming to an endPlatform providers are set to face new rules as the government tries to assert control of the internetMichael Drury and Julian Hayes

There is little sign that the government will address some of the more fundamental concerns in

its crusade

to make the UK the "safest place in the world to be online". But whatever is achieved, we are seeing the end of the era of online self-regulation.

This gets under way this month when the Home Office is set to issue its response to the

online harms

white paper consultation that closed last year. After receiving more than 2,000 submissions, including from big tech companies, think tanks and child protection charities, it is expected that ministers will temper some of the more draconian proposals.

By imposing a rigorous duty of care on platform providers backed by swingeing powers to be wielded by Ofcom, the proposals take aim at a multitude of social ills. They range from widely understood scourges, such as terrorist content, to less clearly defined phenomena such as "trolling".

The proposals are part of a worldwide shift towards greater regulation of the online sphere driven by incidents such as the

Christchurch mosque shootings

, online threats to democracy and a perceived lack of accountability by dominant tech giants.

The proposals are a controversial assertion of governmental control of the internet, a position that has hitherto been ceded to arguably unwilling and ill-prepared platform providers.

When first published, the proposals included eye-catching punitive sanctions, with the power, in the worst cases, to order internet service providers to block websites and apps from use in the UK.

The government's imminent response, though, is believed to drop such extreme measures. Freedom of expression concerns also appear to have been acknowledged by Boris Johnson, who in his recent address to the UN general assembly about emerging technologies, highlighted the need to find the right regulatory balance between liberty and control.

It remains to be seen whether the government will address other fundamental issues raised regarding the proposals. For example, when much of what we view on social media is dictated by unseen algorithms, an alternative approach might be to clarify and regulate their use.

In addition, the precise definition of some of the harms also remains a problem, for example, "disinformation" and "excessive" screen time, as both harms are in the government's sights.

Regulating the amount of time individuals spend online risks seeming arbitrary and Orwellian. For some critics, the government's enthusiasm for algorithmic methods of tackling online harms, though well intentioned, has drawbacks, imposing prohibitive costs on smaller start-up tech companies and promoting an unrealistic expectation of security.

Notwithstanding such misgivings, with the government's parliamentary majority and the backing of the opposition, the draft legislation is certain to pass into law, marking a further step towards the end of the era of online self-regulation.

Michael Drury and Julian Hayes are partners at London law firm BCL Solicitors

urn:contentItem:44G6-0SJ0-00MP-T26D-00000-00Eric Gillin and Chris Edmonds Chat on Yahoo!2001-11-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:46ZLexisNexisPERSONAL FINANCE; Martini ChatEric Gillin and Chris Edmonds Chat on Yahoo!By Eric Gillin and Christopher Edmonds, Staff ReportersNovember 16, 2001 7:06 PM ET

Eric Gillin and Chris Edmonds chatted on Yahoo!, Thursday, Nov. 15 at 5 p.m. EDT. For an audio transcript of the event click here. 

Eric Gillin: It's Thursday -- 5 p.m. on the East Coast, 2 p.m. on the West, time once again for TheStreet.com Martini Chat. 

Good afternoon, I'm your host Eric Gillin coming to you live from the world headquarters of TheStreet.com on Wall Street. Joining me from TheStreet.com's Atlanta bureau TheStreet.com Contributing Editor and RealMoney columnist Chris Edmonds. 

Chris, other than the energy complex, what a week on Wall Street. Good news on the war front seems to trump any questions about the economy. Does the resilience surprise you? 

Chris Edmonds: In some ways it does, but psychology is a powerful weapon and good psychology, especially in the form of military might, is a power aphrodisiac for the market. 

The economic underpinnings remain questionable and, so, I expect to see some chop along the way, but the momentum is clearly on the bullish side. 

Glad you mentioned energy, by the way. This OPEC meeting was an absolute disaster. I'm not ready to declare OPEC dead quite yet, but the power Russia and Norway are holding over the cartel sure make you question the impact OPEC can have on prices going forward. 

Someone said this morning that it was quite possible that Russian President Putin and President Bush were likely setting oil prices over a bowl of Texas chili in Crawford this morning. How's that for imagery. 

Eric Gillin: Interesting analysis and we'll have more on the markets in our weekly Roundtable later in the show. 

We have another packed show this week. We'll tackle everything going on in the air and on the ground at least around airports -- with Holly Hegeman, TheStreet.com's own airline analyst and publisher of PlaneBusiness.com. 

We'll look at the financial health of the airlines and explore the ramifications of Monday's crash on American Airlines as well as the latest developments on the airport security front in Congress. 

Then we'll delve into the mystery of why all of you knock that little white ball around the yard with sticks as we look back on the PGA Tour with two seasoned golf journalists -- Bryan Katrek of PGA Tour Radio and John Steinbreder of Golfweek. 

Finally, we wrap up with our Markets Roundtable with a special Thanksgiving twist -- a look at stocks to be thankful for and a look at a turkey or two along the way. All that, the Five Dumbest Things on Wall Street and the latest news headlines. 

But first, a toast. 

Eric Gillin: New York State Attorney General Eliot Spitzer railed against the Red Cross this week, demanding that the organization distribute every cent of the $543 million received in its Liberty Fund to the loved ones of victims and the victims of September 11. 

This was in response to the Red Cross saying that part of the funds would go to those affected by future attacks. Spitzer cried foul and said that the Red Cross misled people who donated money thinking it'd go solely to those impacted by September 11. 

Essentially, Spitzer wanted more accountability for what happens to the $1.4 billion in donations given to all charities. 

While such a demand is commendable, I'm not raising a glass to Spitzer. He was doing his job. He gets paid to watchdog. For the same reason, I'm not raising a glass to the Red Cross or to any of the other charities. They're also doing their jobs, with some, clearly, performing better than others. 

Instead, I toast the charitable. 

It's not their jobs to be charitable. In fact, some of those who gave to the Liberty Fund don't even have jobs! Even though times are tough, people have opened their wallets and purses. 

Recession be damned, America has kicked open the floodgates. Wrap your brain around this: 

On September 10, the Red Cross received $1,024 in donations via its web site. The next day, while chaos reigned in New York, another $1,013,235 came in. The Liberty Fund raised $543 million since the attack -- an average donation of $100 every second. Before Thanksgiving, half of the $93 million raised by the Twin Towers fund will go to the families of the 406 uniformed personnel killed in the attack. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani says that the average check will be $114,000.
 
* The September 11 Fund's star-studded telethon, featuring Bruce Springsteen, Billy Joel and Stevie Wonder added $150 million, upping the money raised to $337 million. $50 million has already been given out.
 
* It's happening everywhere. In Chamblee, Georgia, students of Dunwoody High held a bowl-a-thon at the AMF Bowling Lanes on Savoy Drive. This is in addition to the ribbons sold at the homecoming dance and the $1-a-ticket girls' football game held last week. In total, the high school raised $3,100.
 
* Recent polls show that 73% of the adults in this nation say they've donated something in the past two months, either it be money, blood or their time and services. 

All across this country -- from towns, to cities, to states -- the spirit of giving is strong. 

And yet, amid this wellspring of generosity, rankled a controversy. The Red Cross wanted to withhold $300 million of the Liberty Fund for future victims. Critics howled. But don't get mad at the Red Cross. It listened to the critics and released a statement yesterday saying that all of the money in the fund will go to those affected by September 11. 

My heart goes out to the Red Cross, stung by complaints and bad press. The organization must have been overwhelmed by America's generosity. After years of begging people to donate blood, The Red Cross suddenly had lines around the block. The organization went from $1,000 a day in donations to $1 million. 

Just nine weeks after the attacks, it might have struggled to figure out who precisely needed the money. We tend to look at things 5,6.7 years out.

And, of course, we'll take a look at the markets, the Five Dumbest Things on Wall Street and Yi-Ping and the news. 

Until then, thanks to all of our guests and Chris, thanks to you. See you next week. 

Chris Edmonds: Look forward to it. Happy Thanksgiving to all and to all a good night. 

Eric Gillin: Excellent. Happy Thanksgiving to all as well. Until November 29, Cheers.

ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

DECEMBER 18, 2017

SPEAKERS: ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES

LISA ABRAMOWICZ, BLOOMBERG NEWS

DAVID WESTIN, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] DAVID WESTIN, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Joining us now is Eric Hippeau, from Lerer Hippeau Ventures. He's the management partner and RebelMouse chairman. He's also the Former CEO of the "The Huffington Post" and was an early investor in companies including Warby Parker, Casper, and Refinery29. He's got quite a track record I think is per se.

Eric, welcome back to Bloomberg (ph). Good to have you here.

ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES: Good morning.

WESTIN: So let's start with this tax reform, tax overhaul. Supposedly, a lot of money is going to be coming back into this country, particularly on the tech companies. What are they going to do with it?

HIPPEAU: Well, they can continue to buy back shares as they've been doing. But more likely, they're going to start really investing it in areas that might be a little bit like frontier technology that's a little bit outside of their core domains. Google has been doing it already. Apple has a good track record of this.

LISA ABRAMOWICZ, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: I'm sorry to cut you off. But a lot of people say that these companies, Google, and Amazon, they've already brought a lot of money back to the bond market. They have as much cash that they could possibly imagine. Why would they need this money to come back for to do some of these moves?

HIPPEAU: Well, probably just because they are under attack. They're under attack in the United States. They're certainly under attack in Europe. And there's a growing backlash against big tech. And it's got to do with the Russian thing, the fact that they don't know what's happening on their platforms, they have no controls. This whole privacy issue is starting to hit home, that we are looking at Equifax.

So it would be smart for them to start making investments that bolster their image, that cater better to privacy and security and things of that nature.

WESTIN: And yet when you look at some big deals, you see things like Amazon buying whole foods, which is, if anything, the opposite direction. That's not going into privacy of things. That's going to bricks-and- mortar. I mean, should we expect to see more of that tech really move into bricks-and-mortars or the reverse for that matter?

HIPPEAU: I think you certainly mentioned some of the companies that we've invested in, like Warby Parker. Warby Parker now has over 20 stores. They're doing very well. Casper, another one of our businesses is opening stores. So you're starting to see digital native companies understand that consumers like to touch the product. The interaction is necessary. So they're going into the retail business.

ABRAMOWICZ: So when you talk about the regulatory pushback and sort of the under attack aspect of tech right now, do actually think that politicians are going to take regulatory action or is this just sort of going to goad the big tech companies try to insulate themselves?

HIPPEAU: I don't think politicians really understand what's going on. So it's very unlikely that they will take action. If they take action, it will be a rear guard action that won't have much of an effect. I think it's mostly the users. There's definitely science that young people are moving away from the big social platforms. Older Americans, older people are posting less personal things. There's clearly a sign that what you post will come back and haunt you in the future. So this is a big change that's coming from the users themselves

WESTIN: So you're known as being a very astute investor in the digital space, particularly in the early stages. What does that tell you about where you should be look for opportunities, so then other people should be look at opportunities in tech?

HIPPEAU: Well, these days we look for opportunities predictably in artificial intelligence, smart apps, smart systems. We're big believers that the robotics world is changing dramatically. The cost of robots is going down at really furious pace. And all the values according to the software layer which is becoming more and more intelligent. These are not necessarily robots or AI that's going to replace workers. It's in fact going to enhance the workforce. It's going to make the workforce more productive.

ABRAMOWICZ: What tech company are people not talking about today that they will be at the end of 2018?

HIPPEAU: Oh, boy. That's an interesting question. I'd have to think about this a little bit more. Sorry.

ABRAMOWICZ: Or is there a company that we're talking about right now, the reverse, that we're not going to be talking about?

HIPPEAU: Well, I think your previous segment mentioned that. I think the Chinese companies are all going to come to the United States or a lot of them are going to come to the United States. You should see the valuations in China, talk about bitcoin as a high valuation, all of the valuations in China, all the deals you hear about china, are made with hundreds of billions of dollars evaluation. Alibaba, 10 Cent, all of these companies are going to be look at the United States.

ABRAMOWICZ: Wait. So you think that Alibaba could actually present a serious competitive threat to, say, Amazon in the U.S.?

HIPPEAU: I'm not sure they will go directly into the end user, consumer, retail sector but they will be in the infrastructure. The commerce is already in China. All of these companies offer payments, offer communications on a single platform. We don't do that very well in the United States.

WESTIN: Well, I was going to ask exactly that question. Is 10 Cent just way ahead of us in terms of payments? I mean, because you go to China and people do everything with WeChat. I mean basically they buy everything they communicate. They do everything. And we're way behind in that. Aren't we?

HIPPEAU: Yes, it's surprising to me. I'm not quite sure I understand why. But the fact is, that there's no reason why you can't be in the single app and do everything that you just mentioned, including making real payments as well as buying digital objects and pretty much living your life in one app. We don't do this in the U.S. There's no reason why we couldn't.

ABRAMOWICZ: So which tech company do you think is getting the furthest in creating that in the U.S.?

HIPPEAU: Apple.

ABRAMOWICZ: Apple Pay?

HIPPEAU: Yes, Apple Pay. You're going to stop to be able to make each payments with Apple Pay. So, yes, Apple is -- because it's such a stored company, and since Steve Jobs people say, "Well, Apple is not innovating as much." I actually don't believe that. I think Apple is a very strong company.

WESTIN: So when you think about internet of things broadly, when you got in the home with our Alexia, you got autonomous vehicles seem to be around the corner. When is it going to get to health care? Why don't we have a device on ourselves that monitor heart rate and things like that for diabetic sugar levels? When does that come and who's going to lead that charge?

HIPPEAU: Well, again this watch from Apple already. If I wanted to -- I don't. But if I wanted to --

ABRAMOWICZ: Like out of a know?

HIPPEAU: Yes, exactly. I could monitor some of my functions. This is getting better and better. The sensors are getting better. And the data is getting better. The problem with health care is the system of healthcare is so rigid and so impregnable that they're only touching on the margin.

WESTIN: OK, Eric Hippeau of Lerer Hippeau Ventures. Thanks so much for being here, Eric.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

DECEMBER 18, 2017

SPEAKERS: ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES

LISA ABRAMOWICZ, BLOOMBERG NEWS

DAVID WESTIN, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] DAVID WESTIN, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Joining us now is Eric Hippeau, from Lerer Hippeau Ventures. He's the management partner and RebelMouse chairman. He's also the Former CEO of the "The Huffington Post" and was an early investor in companies including Warby Parker, Casper, and Refinery29. He's got quite a track record I think is per se.

Eric, welcome back to Bloomberg (ph). Good to have you here.

ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES: Good morning.

WESTIN: So let's start with this tax reform, tax overhaul. Supposedly, a lot of money is going to be coming back into this country, particularly on the tech companies. What are they going to do with it?

HIPPEAU: Well, they can continue to buy back shares as they've been doing. But more likely, they're going to start really investing it in areas that might be a little bit like frontier technology that's a little bit outside of their core domains. Google has been doing it already. Apple has a good track record of this.

LISA ABRAMOWICZ, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: I'm sorry to cut you off. But a lot of people say that these companies, Google, and Amazon, they've already brought a lot of money back to the bond market. They have as much cash that they could possibly imagine. Why would they need this money to come back for to do some of these moves?

HIPPEAU: Well, probably just because they are under attack. They're under attack in the United States. They're certainly under attack in Europe. And there's a growing backlash against big tech. And it's got to do with the Russian thing, the fact that they don't know what's happening on their platforms, they have no controls. This whole privacy issue is starting to hit home, that we are looking at Equifax.

So it would be smart for them to start making investments that bolster their image, that cater better to privacy and security and things of that nature.

WESTIN: And yet when you look at some big deals, you see things like Amazon buying whole foods, which is, if anything, the opposite direction. That's not going into privacy of things. That's going to bricks-and- mortar. I mean, should we expect to see more of that tech really move into bricks-and-mortars or the reverse for that matter?

HIPPEAU: I think you certainly mentioned some of the companies that we've invested in, like Warby Parker. Warby Parker now has over 20 stores. They're doing very well. Casper, another one of our businesses is opening stores. So you're starting to see digital native companies understand that consumers like to touch the product. The interaction is necessary. So they're going into the retail business.

ABRAMOWICZ: So when you talk about the regulatory pushback and sort of the under attack aspect of tech right now, do actually think that politicians are going to take regulatory action or is this just sort of going to goad the big tech companies try to insulate themselves?

HIPPEAU: I don't think politicians really understand what's going on. So it's very unlikely that they will take action. If they take action, it will be a rear guard action that won't have much of an effect. I think it's mostly the users. There's definitely science that young people are moving away from the big social platforms. Older Americans, older people are posting less personal things. There's clearly a sign that what you post will come back and haunt you in the future. So this is a big change that's coming from the users themselves

WESTIN: So you're known as being a very astute investor in the digital space, particularly in the early stages. What does that tell you about where you should be look for opportunities, so then other people should be look at opportunities in tech?

HIPPEAU: Well, these days we look for opportunities predictably in artificial intelligence, smart apps, smart systems. We're big believers that the robotics world is changing dramatically. The cost of robots is going down at really furious pace. And all the values according to the software layer which is becoming more and more intelligent. These are not necessarily robots or AI that's going to replace workers. It's in fact going to enhance the workforce. It's going to make the workforce more productive.

ABRAMOWICZ: What tech company are people not talking about today that they will be at the end of 2018?

HIPPEAU: Oh, boy. That's an interesting question. I'd have to think about this a little bit more. Sorry.

ABRAMOWICZ: Or is there a company that we're talking about right now, the reverse, that we're not going to be talking about?

HIPPEAU: Well, I think your previous segment mentioned that. I think the Chinese companies are all going to come to the United States or a lot of them are going to come to the United States. You should see the valuations in China, talk about bitcoin as a high valuation, all of the valuations in China, all the deals you hear about china, are made with hundreds of billions of dollars evaluation. Alibaba, 10 Cent, all of these companies are going to be look at the United States.

ABRAMOWICZ: Wait. So you think that Alibaba could actually present a serious competitive threat to, say, Amazon in the U.S.?

HIPPEAU: I'm not sure they will go directly into the end user, consumer, retail sector but they will be in the infrastructure. The commerce is already in China. All of these companies offer payments, offer communications on a single platform. We don't do that very well in the United States.

WESTIN: Well, I was going to ask exactly that question. Is 10 Cent just way ahead of us in terms of payments? I mean, because you go to China and people do everything with WeChat. I mean basically they buy everything they communicate. They do everything. And we're way behind in that. Aren't we?

HIPPEAU: Yes, it's surprising to me. I'm not quite sure I understand why. But the fact is, that there's no reason why you can't be in the single app and do everything that you just mentioned, including making real payments as well as buying digital objects and pretty much living your life in one app. We don't do this in the U.S. There's no reason why we couldn't.

ABRAMOWICZ: So which tech company do you think is getting the furthest in creating that in the U.S.?

HIPPEAU: Apple.

ABRAMOWICZ: Apple Pay?

HIPPEAU: Yes, Apple Pay. You're going to stop to be able to make each payments with Apple Pay. So, yes, Apple is -- because it's such a stored company, and since Steve Jobs people say, "Well, Apple is not innovating as much." I actually don't believe that. I think Apple is a very strong company.

WESTIN: So when you think about internet of things broadly, when you got in the home with our Alexia, you got autonomous vehicles seem to be around the corner. When is it going to get to health care? Why don't we have a device on ourselves that monitor heart rate and things like that for diabetic sugar levels? When does that come and who's going to lead that charge?

HIPPEAU: Well, again this watch from Apple already. If I wanted to -- I don't. But if I wanted to --

ABRAMOWICZ: Like out of a know?

HIPPEAU: Yes, exactly. I could monitor some of my functions. This is getting better and better. The sensors are getting better. And the data is getting better. The problem with health care is the system of healthcare is so rigid and so impregnable that they're only touching on the margin.

WESTIN: OK, Eric Hippeau of Lerer Hippeau Ventures. Thanks so much for being here, Eric.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
