ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

SEPTEMBER 19, 2017

SPEAKERS ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES

BOBBY FRANKLIN, CEO, NATIONAL VENTURE CAPITAL ASSOCIATION

SARAH FRIER, BLOOMBERG NEWS

MIKE RILEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

ALEX WAYNE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG HOST: Joining me now to discuss, Bobby Franklin, the CEO of the group leading the suit, the National Venture Capital Association.

And Eric Hippeau, managing partner of Lerer Hippeau Ventures, our guest host for the hour with me here in the studio.

Also, Alex Wayne, who covers the White House for Bloomberg news. Alex, I'm going to start with you. What do you make of this?

ALEX WAYNE, BLOOMBERG HOST: It's an interesting lawsuit. You know, a lot of previous test case it's really -- because this isn't the only rule that the Trump administration -- excuse me, Obama era rule, the Trump administration has stuck to delay, and then eventually get rid of.

The suit, as I understand it, challenges whether the Obama -- the Trump administration can do this without opening in a comment period first.

Now, I think, it's kind of a weird rule that the Trump administration is trying to resend, it seems like it would normally fit in to like sort of category of immigrants that the president would like to see more of in the United States.

He's advocated for a merit-based immigration system. But, I think, what's happening here politically is twofold.

One, Trump is really trying to establish his legacy as erasing Obama's legacy including just about every rule that Obama issued late in his presidency.

And two, there are -- there are serious immigration restrictions within this administration. People who think there should be lower legal immigration overall.

And so by repealing this rule, those folks are probably trying to achieve some of their goals.

CHANG: Bobby, why file this suit? What do you hope to accomplish?

BOBBY FRANKLIN, CEO, NATIONAL VENTURE CAPITAL ASSOCIATION: Well, we hope to get the rule enacted, we hope to make sure that DHS is in a position to accept applications.

Emily, this is about a competition that the U.S. is in with the rest of the world. In other countries are literally rolling out red carpets.

You look at Canada, you look at Great Britain, France, Singapore, all across the globe, they recognize that there are talents in entrepreneurs.

They're trying to attract them to their country to start and grow this new company on their soil.

And what are we doing, we've got red tape. It's not a partisan issue, it's not against President Trump, it's not against President Obama.

In fact, both of them have talked about the importance of bringing international entrepreneurs that can frankly get capital anywhere across the globe.

Bringing them here to our country and making sure that we grow U.S. jobs in the economy.

CHANG: Eric, you are an immigrant, you're an entrepreneur, you're an investor. What's your take?

ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES: Well, my take is that foreign-entrepreneurs coming in to the United States is a very desirable thing to do.

About half of our companies have at least one member of the original team, the founding team, who is an immigrant. I'm an immigrant.

And these are people who make huge contributions to our economy, to our society. And I don't see why we would make it difficult for them to come.

And as Bobby just mentioned, they can go elsewhere. They can go to Canada, they can go to France, they can go to other places. We are competing with other nations.

CHANG: Obviously, President Trump's, you know, explanation here is creating U.S. jobs, making sure that U.S. workers have a place to work.

Bobby, what about the idea this is -- that this is merely a stop gap measure in any way when immigration reform in general is broken?

FRANKLIN: Well, it is broken. And we've been working on this issue for many years. Back in 2013, we had the opportunity to get a start of these passed through the U.S. senate.

But it didn't make it all the way in to law. Each year, we work with congress to try to get them to pass legislation.

There are bills in this congress introduced by both Republicans and Democrats that would create a start of these that would make it easier for these entrepreneurs to come here and start companies.

But in the absence of legislation, making it in to law, we have to do what we can.

And DHS promulgated the rule, they went through comment, and noticed, and we had a rule ready to take effect July 17th.

And one week before that, DHS decided to resend that, we don't think they follow proper procedure under the administrator procedures act.

And it's the only thing that we have to go on right now to try to get more entrepreneurs here in our country.

CHANG: Now, Alex, obviously, there have been conflicting messages from the administration when it comes to this, when it comes to DACA, when it comes to immigration reform, in general.

What are the next legislative steps that we actually expect to see in the coming days and weeks when it comes to, you know, taking action on what the president has signaled?

WAYNE: So the priority in the immediate future is to do something about DACA, the so-called Dreamers, these young immigrants brought to the country illegally by their parents.

Democrats say they struck a deal with Trump to deal with -- to handle that issue and resolve that issue.

I have not heard anything, any kind of a legislative resolution of this issue, entrepreneur, immigrants.

So I would not expect that to be tackled by congress in the near future if it all -- perhaps, it could be part of a comprehensive immigration bill.

But that's the way in the future, that's not even under consideration right now.

CHANG: So, Eric, have any of these moves impacted your entrepreneurs in any way? I mean, are people nervous or are they changing their plans?

HIPPEAU: Well, by definition, we back people who are here legally, who are with a visa or because they were, you know, they're here -- were under weather reforms.

So -- but the community is nervous, the community is saying, "You know, I was welcomed when I came here and this is my dream. My dream is the United States that's' why I'm here."

"Why is this changing, why am I not, you know, part of this, you know, great community?" So this is a great degree of anxiety within the community.

CHANG: Right. Bobby, any response to the lawsuit so far?

FRANKLIN: Not yet, but, you know, we'll take the next steps. We'll likely file an injunction to try to get DHS to move forward, you know, stay tuned.

CHANG: All right. Bobby Franklin, CEO of the National Venture Capital Association, Alex Wayne of Bloomberg News. Thank you both for joining us.

Eric Hippeau, managing partner of Lerer Hippeau Ventures and my guest host for the hour, you are sticking with me.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHANG: Still with us, Eric Hippeau, managing partner at Lerer Hippeau Ventures, we have to talk about this, of course, because we're in New York today.

What do you think the likelihood of that -- of Amazon ending up here?

HIPPEAU: Well, we would love it, obviously, 50,000 tech workers or quasi- tech workers in Brooklyn that would be fantastic.

I think the chances are pretty low. New York is a very expensive place to set up a business.

And we -- in the current administration, New York is not particularly business-friendly. So I'm not even sure that New York is bidding.

CHANG: Where is business-friendly under the current administration?

HIPPEAU: Well, I was talking about the local administration, but, you know, but I think that New York should be looking for those kinds of opportunities.

Because those are the kinds of jobs at a higher-paying, that are, you know, information-based essentially that we need is that -- but I don't know that the City of New York is actually even active in looking at attracting them.

CHANG: So what do you -- I mean, what do you think Amazon should be looking for in their second headquarters since they can't -- they can't build out its headquarters in Seattle their capacity. What should they be looking for elsewhere?

HIPPEAU: I think it needs a city or a place where there's a lot of higher education, a lot of young people that who are looking for the jobs of the new economy, and a business-friendly environment.

CHANG: We do have some (INAUDIBLE) from the mayor of Philadelphia, obviously, a lot of cities competing for this now. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MAYOR JIM KENNEY, PHILADELPHIA, PENNSYLVANIA: We've gotten criticism, you know, about corporate tax breaks and that alike. This is too big of a deal, and it's too many jobs and too great of a company for us not to go after it. And we would love to have it here.

We have a lot of folks who could use the work and we have a lot of IT startups and tech companies that have come into Philadelphia recently.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHANG: So Philadelphia throwing their hat in the ring as well. How does the city benefit?

HIPPEAU: Well, you do have to give them some tax breaks, I imagine. But on the other hand, you're providing 50,000 really good paying jobs, there are people who will pay taxes themselves and who will buy local products and services.

So it's a -- it's a definite plus for the city. New York just opened the Cornell Tech, and Bloomberg is very much involved with that.

So it would actually go really well with attracting the headquarters or the second headquarters of a big tech company.

CHANG: And I wonder if New York would do a good job of attracting younger talent, I mean, who doesn't want to live in New York, right?

HIPPEAU: Exactly, New York -- New York, well, that's why, I mean, New York, most of my companies are here. It's a great place for startups and most people love to be in New York.

There's a lot of diversity and a lot of things to do. But the city needs to have a plan in place to be able to attract a company like Amazon.

CHANG: How would you describe evolution of New York's tax scheme? I mean, obviously, it's always been -- it's always placed second to Silicon Valley to a certain extent, though, you know, many of the big tech companies have offices here as well and the scene is changing. You know, how much closer is Silicon Alley to Silicon Valley these days?

HIPPEAU: Well, today, Silicon Alley of New York is the second largest center of technology in United States, one of the largest in the world.

And what New York does when it's good at. New York is good at software development, New York is good at applications and services.

We're not going to be reinventing the plumbing of the Internet, we're not going to create the next generation of routers.

However, we're starting to see robotics companies, we're starting to see, you know, all kinds of companies and all kinds of sectors because we have access in New York to the same technology that people in Silicon Valley have.

CHANG: When is that 10 billion dollar company going to be coming out in New York, that 10 billion dollar tech company?

HIPPEAU: Hopefully, it's in the pipeline. There's a whole number of companies which have to reach the billion dollar, at least, in the private market valuation that, I think, have the potential to be one of those companies.

CHANG: All right. Eric Hippeau, Lerer Hippeau Ventures, you are sticking with me. Thank you

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHANG: Joining me now to discuss the latest in this ongoing saga, Bloomberg's Mike Riley and still with us, Eric Hippeau, managing partner at Lerer Hippeau Ventures.

Eric, you are shaking your head. Mike, it is so hard not to read these stories and not get incredibly angry.

It just gets worst and worst. What do we know about this new breach and how much they knew before they told the public?

MIKE RILEY, BLOOMBERG HOST: We don't know a lot because they're not being particularly clear about what they knew. But we do know a couple of important things.

One is that they had a major invest -- security investigation going on starting in March and going through May.

They hired Mandiant, the same cyber security firm that they've brought back in July.

And they were doing a pretty extensive investigation for three months. Now, company like Mandiant, that's a pretty expensive prospect.

But the most interesting thing if you look at their timeline of the July incident, the one that they found out about July is the hackers, even though, they found out about the theft of, you know, this data in July.

When they did the investigation, when Mandiant came back in, they discovered that that data was stolen in May, which would have put it right in the middle of this earlier investigation.

So there's a question of like why that wasn't found, how do you get of a company like Mandiant examining your networks and other things, and just missed the presence of a -- of a hacker in your network, and the theft of this kind of data.

It also raises this questions about, you know, what the executives knew when -- whether they knew that the company was having multiple security problems at the time they did trades in May and in late July, early August.

So, again, it raises just all sorts of questions. And one of the things that's clear is, you know, when a data breach like this, you want to get to be as transparent with the public as possible and you want to do it as early as possible.

And we just keep getting a trickle of new information really almost daily now.

CHANG: It feels like a mess and it feels like they're not being transparent at all. I mean, Eric, you probably have a credit card, right? You probably among the 143 million people just like everyone else?

HIPPEAU: Well, that -- it's shocking to me that, first of all, the CEO the company is still the CEO of the company. I don't understand what the board of directors is going.

But, I think, what we're realizing here is that our data is ending in this credit service bureaus without us knowing about it.

I mean, we suspect, of course, we got a credit score and all that. But they collect a very sensitive information about us without really our authorization.

So the least you would expect is that the most important job that they do is to maintain that data safe.

And if you have information on the majority of the American citizens, you have to expect that there's a whole hacking world is going to come after you.

CHANG: Right, that's their one job, it's to make sure --

HIPPEAU: That's your one job.

CHANG: -- it's protected.

HIPPEAU: And as your colleague just pointed out, if there's any kind of breach and you need full transparency because how are we possibly going to be able to trust this people again.

CHANG: So, Mike, you know, we are getting -- you are getting new information about the motivation of these hackers, potentially, that they're interested in getting in to the big things. You know, what do we - - what more do we know about the end goals of these attacks?

RILEY: Well, again, we don't know a lot because the company doesn't telling us a lot. But keep in mind that one of the things we just know is that if you have hackers in your system, in a system like Equifax, they're probably not just going to look for one thing even something as valuable as social security numbers and birth dates on a hundred and forty-three million U.S. consumers.

Because Equifax serves a really keep a part of the financial infrastructure of the country in general. It has direct links between its system and the bank systems through APIs.

And one of the things we did find out is that there is evidence that the hackers, some hackers used those APIs to get in to at least one major bank in Canada.

Now, that raises all sorts of questions about like what else the hackers did with their time in Equifax. I mean, keep in mind, again, that by their own timeline they discovered the breach at the end of July.

But the hackers had been in there since at least middle of May. What were -- and when they took the big stash of data, what were they doing over the next four months, that's the real question.

CHANG: Equifax did announced the retirement of a couple of senior executives but if there's still a lot of questions surrounding the share sales, this executive share sale that happened, I mean, how is this fitting in to the timeline of what we think they knew when?

RILEY: Well, it raises some really interesting question. And their time - - and their timeline is very specific, but it doesn't have much bigger room.

What -- basically, what they're saying is they learned about the hack on July 29th. The share sales, like one group of share sales happened at the beginning of August.

But there's a handful of days, two or three days between the time they learned and the time of that sale occurred.

They are basically saying that the executives didn't know about the hack in the span of those three days.

And even the people we talked to who work at Equifax say, "That just seems really unlikely."

I mean, a company like this has a protocol for what they do when they're hacked. And that protocol entails briefing the executives within a short period of time and certainly not three days.

So it does raise a lot of questions, we do know that the U.S. prosecutors have opened an investigation in to those sales because they want to find out what those executives knew when and whether or not they violated insider trading laws.

CHANG: And so that -- last question, so what is the recourse for consumers here?

RILEY: Well, so keep in mind, this is -- this is a very different tact -- attack that they target because credit card numbers is a temporary thing that you can just cancel and reissue.

What these hackers potentially got was very specific data that's at the center of our confidential identities, birth dates, social security numbers, and other things.

This is something that could be used to steal our identity, you know, any time over the next -- in the next decades over our lifetime.

So consumers can do short-term things, they can get credit monitoring that Equifax is offering for free, they can also try and freeze that access to their credit reports which is typically a hard thing to do in a short-term measure.

But what'll they do two years from now or five years from now or 10 years from now when this data is still being used to steal identities.

CHANG: Devastating. All right. Bloomberg's Mike Riley, thanks. Can't wait to see the scoop you bring up tomorrow. Eric Hippeau, my guest host for the hour of Lerer Hippeau Ventures, you are sticking with me.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHANG: Still with us, Eric Hippeau, managing partner at Lerer Hippeau Ventures, who was CEO of the Huffington Post, four times. So what do you think, will we see more media M&A and if so, where?

HIPPEAU: Well, for sure, because the traditional media companies need a bigger additional footprint, bigger additional platforms.

They need to acquire technology. They're basically not technology companies.

And for the native media technology companies, to be part of a bigger group, it gives them more resources, it gives them more opportunity to distribute their content. So it's a win-win for both. So it's just --

CHANG: So do you see a big consolidation happening?

HIPPEAU: I do see -- I don't know how much of a consolidation, but if you look at the deceleration of subscribers on cable, I think, this is motivating a lot of people to say, "Wait, did this uncapping of the cable world is happening a lot faster than we expected. We better prepare -- as we are cash (INAUDIBLE) we better prepare for the future."

CHANG: All right. Eric Hippeau, you are sticking with me.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHANG: For more, I want to get straight to our Bloomberg Tech reporter, Sarah Frier, who covers Twitter and Facebook.

And still with us, Eric Hippeau of Lerer Hippeau Ventures. So, Sarah, you know, what do you make of this? What do we know?

SARAH FRIER, BLOOMBERG HOST: So, Burr, basically saying is -- if Facebook says they don't have much to hide if they want to be transparent and cooperative, how about do it in the public.

So although a date we're hearing hasn't been set, this is something that is very important to the senators.

Obviously, Facebook, we know have given more information about the odds related to the Russian spending to Mueller's Commission, the special commission looking in to this.

So we're very much looking forward to anything that we can hear in the public eye.

CHANG: So does this mean we could see Mark Zuckerberg or Sheryl Sandberg testifying before congress?

FRIER: Yes, absolutely. I think that that could be a possibility. We could also see, perhaps, Facebook head of security.

Anyone who might have more specific information about how this looks, maybe that they're looking in to it on a -- on a granular level. I -- but, nothing has been confirmed yet.

CHANG: Eric, what's your take on this story?

HIPPEAU: Well, my take is that the issue is actually bigger than just the Russian hack or whatever. I think, we're actually in a new relationship with our big tech companies.

We, for years, have left them alone. It was completely less unfair attitude because we want them to grow and want them to innovate.

But in (INAUDIBLE) on the eyes of society as users and of government that this -- that they're really not transparent. They're not -- they're not telling us what they're doing.

They change the algorithms without any start or any other expectations. They deal with our data in ways that for instance, they -- we just learned that they allowed people to target races and white supremacies.

How is that possible? So they hide in some ways behind this notion that they're just a utility. That they're not responsible for the content, they're not responsible for how the platform is being used.

And, I think, that society as users and of government, we're not saying, "That can't be true." You know, you have to have responsibility, you have to take charge of what's going on in your own platform.

CHANG: Sarah, another story that just crossed European regulators are going to be telling tech companies that they are going to be fined if they don't take down terrorist-related content in a matter of hour, which I wonder, A, is that -- is that possible and what might the reaction be?

FRIER: I think that's absolutely going to be something that the company will say, "It's very difficult." Of course, Twitter today announced that it had removed a few 300,000 accounts from ISIS --

CHANG: 300,000?

FRIER: -- about 20 percent --

CHANG: 300,000 accounts that they removed? That's a lot.

FRIER: That's a lot, it's 20 percent less than this time last year. But maybe that means that they're doing something to address the issue.

The problem the European Regulator say is that they want the company to address this content within two hours and when it goes up.

That is very difficult for something, you know, Facebook has more than two billion users now, and it's very difficult for them to possible that content.

What the UN wants new is get these companies and start thinking about this, the technological level. Is there a way that they can address this issue at scale without having to hire thousands of contractors support through this or is that just in impossibility?

CHANG: And yet, it's a problem, obviously, they've known about for a long time. Eric, do you think it's fair for them to say, "We can't do it. It's too big."

HIPPEAU: No, no, it's not. And they -- and (INAUDIBLE) the measures that they've taken so far and they seemed to be working that well.

Facebook has added 2,000 curators, there's more technology, et cetera. But they're not doing enough. And they're certainly not reassuring us that they're doing enough for -- on this matter.

CHANG: Facebook though did say that they are hiring 3,000 extra workers to --

FRIER: And, Emily --

CHANG: -- flag the content. Go ahead, Sarah.

FRIER: I see --

CHANG: (INAUDIBLE) 30 seconds.

FRIER: -- I see that 3,000 workers cited in every post from Facebook on a problem they're trying to address. Those 3,000 workers are dealing with Ad fraud, fake news, hateful content, violate video, all these things. It's very interesting how much they're able to cope with.

CHANG: Well, they have a lot on their plate, apparently. Sarah Frier of Bloomberg News. I know you'll keep us posted on all these stories.

Eric Hippeau of Lerer Hippeau Ventures, thank you so much for joining us today.

HIPPEAU: Yes, my pleasure.

CHANG: Great to see you here in New York.

HIPPEAU: Thank you.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Eric Hippeau discusses politics and technology.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

SEPTEMBER 19, 2017

SPEAKERS ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES

BOBBY FRANKLIN, CEO, NATIONAL VENTURE CAPITAL ASSOCIATION

SARAH FRIER, BLOOMBERG NEWS

MIKE RILEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

ALEX WAYNE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG HOST: Joining me now to discuss, Bobby Franklin, the CEO of the group leading the suit, the National Venture Capital Association.

And Eric Hippeau, managing partner of Lerer Hippeau Ventures, our guest host for the hour with me here in the studio.

Also, Alex Wayne, who covers the White House for Bloomberg news. Alex, I'm going to start with you. What do you make of this?

ALEX WAYNE, BLOOMBERG HOST: It's an interesting lawsuit. You know, a lot of previous test case it's really -- because this isn't the only rule that the Trump administration -- excuse me, Obama era rule, the Trump administration has stuck to delay, and then eventually get rid of.

The suit, as I understand it, challenges whether the Obama -- the Trump administration can do this without opening in a comment period first.

Now, I think, it's kind of a weird rule that the Trump administration is trying to resend, it seems like it would normally fit in to like sort of category of immigrants that the president would like to see more of in the United States.

He's advocated for a merit-based immigration system. But, I think, what's happening here politically is twofold.

One, Trump is really trying to establish his legacy as erasing Obama's legacy including just about every rule that Obama issued late in his presidency.

And two, there are -- there are serious immigration restrictions within this administration. People who think there should be lower legal immigration overall.

And so by repealing this rule, those folks are probably trying to achieve some of their goals.

CHANG: Bobby, why file this suit? What do you hope to accomplish?

BOBBY FRANKLIN, CEO, NATIONAL VENTURE CAPITAL ASSOCIATION: Well, we hope to get the rule enacted, we hope to make sure that DHS is in a position to accept applications.

Emily, this is about a competition that the U.S. is in with the rest of the world. In other countries are literally rolling out red carpets.

You look at Canada, you look at Great Britain, France, Singapore, all across the globe, they recognize that there are talents in entrepreneurs.

They're trying to attract them to their country to start and grow this new company on their soil.

And what are we doing, we've got red tape. It's not a partisan issue, it's not against President Trump, it's not against President Obama.

In fact, both of them have talked about the importance of bringing international entrepreneurs that can frankly get capital anywhere across the globe.

Bringing them here to our country and making sure that we grow U.S. jobs in the economy.

CHANG: Eric, you are an immigrant, you're an entrepreneur, you're an investor. What's your take?

ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES: Well, my take is that foreign-entrepreneurs coming in to the United States is a very desirable thing to do.

About half of our companies have at least one member of the original team, the founding team, who is an immigrant. I'm an immigrant.

And these are people who make huge contributions to our economy, to our society. And I don't see why we would make it difficult for them to come.

And as Bobby just mentioned, they can go elsewhere. They can go to Canada, they can go to France, they can go to other places. We are competing with other nations.

CHANG: Obviously, President Trump's, you know, explanation here is creating U.S. jobs, making sure that U.S. workers have a place to work.

Bobby, what about the idea this is -- that this is merely a stop gap measure in any way when immigration reform in general is broken?

FRANKLIN: Well, it is broken. And we've been working on this issue for many years. Back in 2013, we had the opportunity to get a start of these passed through the U.S. senate.

But it didn't make it all the way in to law. Each year, we work with congress to try to get them to pass legislation.

There are bills in this congress introduced by both Republicans and Democrats that would create a start of these that would make it easier for these entrepreneurs to come here and start companies.

But in the absence of legislation, making it in to law, we have to do what we can.

And DHS promulgated the rule, they went through comment, and noticed, and we had a rule ready to take effect July 17th.

And one week before that, DHS decided to resend that, we don't think they follow proper procedure under the administrator procedures act.

And it's the only thing that we have to go on right now to try to get more entrepreneurs here in our country.

CHANG: Now, Alex, obviously, there have been conflicting messages from the administration when it comes to this, when it comes to DACA, when it comes to immigration reform, in general.

What are the next legislative steps that we actually expect to see in the coming days and weeks when it comes to, you know, taking action on what the president has signaled?

WAYNE: So the priority in the immediate future is to do something about DACA, the so-called Dreamers, these young immigrants brought to the country illegally by their parents.

Democrats say they struck a deal with Trump to deal with -- to handle that issue and resolve that issue.

I have not heard anything, any kind of a legislative resolution of this issue, entrepreneur, immigrants.

So I would not expect that to be tackled by congress in the near future if it all -- perhaps, it could be part of a comprehensive immigration bill.

But that's the way in the future, that's not even under consideration right now.

CHANG: So, Eric, have any of these moves impacted your entrepreneurs in any way? I mean, are people nervous or are they changing their plans?

HIPPEAU: Well, by definition, we back people who are here legally, who are with a visa or because they were, you know, they're here -- were under weather reforms.

So -- but the community is nervous, the community is saying, "You know, I was welcomed when I came here and this is my dream. My dream is the United States that's' why I'm here."

"Why is this changing, why am I not, you know, part of this, you know, great community?" So this is a great degree of anxiety within the community.

CHANG: Right. Bobby, any response to the lawsuit so far?

FRANKLIN: Not yet, but, you know, we'll take the next steps. We'll likely file an injunction to try to get DHS to move forward, you know, stay tuned.

CHANG: All right. Bobby Franklin, CEO of the National Venture Capital Association, Alex Wayne of Bloomberg News. Thank you both for joining us.

Eric Hippeau, managing partner of Lerer Hippeau Ventures and my guest host for the hour, you are sticking with me.

CHANG: Still with us, Eric Hippeau, managing partner at Lerer Hippeau Ventures, we have to talk about this, of course, because we're in New York today.

What do you think the likelihood of that -- of Amazon ending up here?

HIPPEAU: Well, we would love it, obviously, 50,000 tech workers or quasi- tech workers in Brooklyn that would be fantastic.

I think the chances are pretty low. New York is a very expensive place to set up a business.

And we -- in the current administration, New York is not particularly business-friendly. So I'm not even sure that New York is bidding.

CHANG: Where is business-friendly under the current administration?

HIPPEAU: Well, I was talking about the local administration, but, you know, but I think that New York should be looking for those kinds of opportunities.

Because those are the kinds of jobs at a higher-paying, that are, you know, information-based essentially that we need is that -- but I don't know that the City of New York is actually even active in looking at attracting them.

CHANG: So what do you -- I mean, what do you think Amazon should be looking for in their second headquarters since they can't -- they can't build out its headquarters in Seattle their capacity. What should they be looking for elsewhere?

HIPPEAU: I think it needs a city or a place where there's a lot of higher education, a lot of young people that who are looking for the jobs of the new economy, and a business-friendly environment.

CHANG: We do have some (INAUDIBLE) from the mayor of Philadelphia, obviously, a lot of cities competing for this now. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MAYOR JIM KENNEY, PHILADELPHIA, PENNSYLVANIA: We've gotten criticism, you know, about corporate tax breaks and that alike. This is too big of a deal, and it's too many jobs and too great of a company for us not to go after it. And we would love to have it here.

We have a lot of folks who could use the work and we have a lot of IT startups and tech companies that have come into Philadelphia recently.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHANG: So Philadelphia throwing their hat in the ring as well. How does the city benefit?

HIPPEAU: Well, you do have to give them some tax breaks, I imagine. But on the other hand, you're providing 50,000 really good paying jobs, there are people who will pay taxes themselves and who will buy local products and services.

So it's a -- it's a definite plus for the city. New York just opened the Cornell Tech, and Bloomberg is very much involved with that.

So it would actually go really well with attracting the headquarters or the second headquarters of a big tech company.

CHANG: And I wonder if New York would do a good job of attracting younger talent, I mean, who doesn't want to live in New York, right?

HIPPEAU: Exactly, New York -- New York, well, that's why, I mean, New York, most of my companies are here. It's a great place for startups and most people love to be in New York.

There's a lot of diversity and a lot of things to do. But the city needs to have a plan in place to be able to attract a company like Amazon.

CHANG: How would you describe evolution of New York's tax scheme? I mean, obviously, it's always been -- it's always placed second to Silicon Valley to a certain extent, though, you know, many of the big tech companies have offices here as well and the scene is changing. You know, how much closer is Silicon Alley to Silicon Valley these days?

HIPPEAU: Well, today, Silicon Alley of New York is the second largest center of technology in United States, one of the largest in the world.

And what New York does when it's good at. New York is good at software development, New York is good at applications and services.

We're not going to be reinventing the plumbing of the Internet, we're not going to create the next generation of routers.

However, we're starting to see robotics companies, we're starting to see, you know, all kinds of companies and all kinds of sectors because we have access in New York to the same technology that people in Silicon Valley have.

CHANG: When is that 10 billion dollar company going to be coming out in New York, that 10 billion dollar tech company?

HIPPEAU: Hopefully, it's in the pipeline. There's a whole number of companies which have to reach the billion dollar, at least, in the private market valuation that, I think, have the potential to be one of those companies.

CHANG: All right. Eric Hippeau, Lerer Hippeau Ventures, you are sticking with me. Thank you

CHANG: Joining me now to discuss the latest in this ongoing saga, Bloomberg's Mike Riley and still with us, Eric Hippeau, managing partner at Lerer Hippeau Ventures.

Eric, you are shaking your head. Mike, it is so hard not to read these stories and not get incredibly angry.

It just gets worst and worst. What do we know about this new breach and how much they knew before they told the public?

MIKE RILEY, BLOOMBERG HOST: We don't know a lot because they're not being particularly clear about what they knew. But we do know a couple of important things.

One is that they had a major invest -- security investigation going on starting in March and going through May.

They hired Mandiant, the same cyber security firm that they've brought back in July.

And they were doing a pretty extensive investigation for three months. Now, company like Mandiant, that's a pretty expensive prospect.

But the most interesting thing if you look at their timeline of the July incident, the one that they found out about July is the hackers, even though, they found out about the theft of, you know, this data in July.

When they did the investigation, when Mandiant came back in, they discovered that that data was stolen in May, which would have put it right in the middle of this earlier investigation.

So there's a question of like why that wasn't found, how do you get of a company like Mandiant examining your networks and other things, and just missed the presence of a -- of a hacker in your network, and the theft of this kind of data.

It also raises this questions about, you know, what the executives knew when -- whether they knew that the company was having multiple security problems at the time they did trades in May and in late July, early August.

So, again, it raises just all sorts of questions. And one of the things that's clear is, you know, when a data breach like this, you want to get to be as transparent with the public as possible and you want to do it as early as possible.

And we just keep getting a trickle of new information really almost daily now.

CHANG: It feels like a mess and it feels like they're not being transparent at all. I mean, Eric, you probably have a credit card, right? You probably among the 143 million people just like everyone else?

HIPPEAU: Well, that -- it's shocking to me that, first of all, the CEO the company is still the CEO of the company. I don't understand what the board of directors is going.

But, I think, what we're realizing here is that our data is ending in this credit service bureaus without us knowing about it.

I mean, we suspect, of course, we got a credit score and all that. But they collect a very sensitive information about us without really our authorization.

So the least you would expect is that the most important job that they do is to maintain that data safe.

And if you have information on the majority of the American citizens, you have to expect that there's a whole hacking world is going to come after you.

CHANG: Right, that's their one job, it's to make sure --

HIPPEAU: That's your one job.

CHANG: -- it's protected.

HIPPEAU: And as your colleague just pointed out, if there's any kind of breach and you need full transparency because how are we possibly going to be able to trust this people again.

CHANG: So, Mike, you know, we are getting -- you are getting new information about the motivation of these hackers, potentially, that they're interested in getting in to the big things. You know, what do we - - what more do we know about the end goals of these attacks?

RILEY: Well, again, we don't know a lot because the company doesn't telling us a lot. But keep in mind that one of the things we just know is that if you have hackers in your system, in a system like Equifax, they're probably not just going to look for one thing even something as valuable as social security numbers and birth dates on a hundred and forty-three million U.S. consumers.

Because Equifax serves a really keep a part of the financial infrastructure of the country in general. It has direct links between its system and the bank systems through APIs.

And one of the things we did find out is that there is evidence that the hackers, some hackers used those APIs to get in to at least one major bank in Canada.

Now, that raises all sorts of questions about like what else the hackers did with their time in Equifax. I mean, keep in mind, again, that by their own timeline they discovered the breach at the end of July.

But the hackers had been in there since at least middle of May. What were -- and when they took the big stash of data, what were they doing over the next four months, that's the real question.

CHANG: Equifax did announced the retirement of a couple of senior executives but if there's still a lot of questions surrounding the share sales, this executive share sale that happened, I mean, how is this fitting in to the timeline of what we think they knew when?

RILEY: Well, it raises some really interesting question. And their time - - and their timeline is very specific, but it doesn't have much bigger room.

What -- basically, what they're saying is they learned about the hack on July 29th. The share sales, like one group of share sales happened at the beginning of August.

But there's a handful of days, two or three days between the time they learned and the time of that sale occurred.

They are basically saying that the executives didn't know about the hack in the span of those three days.

And even the people we talked to who work at Equifax say, "That just seems really unlikely."

I mean, a company like this has a protocol for what they do when they're hacked. And that protocol entails briefing the executives within a short period of time and certainly not three days.

So it does raise a lot of questions, we do know that the U.S. prosecutors have opened an investigation in to those sales because they want to find out what those executives knew when and whether or not they violated insider trading laws.

CHANG: And so that -- last question, so what is the recourse for consumers here?

RILEY: Well, so keep in mind, this is -- this is a very different tact -- attack that they target because credit card numbers is a temporary thing that you can just cancel and reissue.

What these hackers potentially got was very specific data that's at the center of our confidential identities, birth dates, social security numbers, and other things.

This is something that could be used to steal our identity, you know, any time over the next -- in the next decades over our lifetime.

So consumers can do short-term things, they can get credit monitoring that Equifax is offering for free, they can also try and freeze that access to their credit reports which is typically a hard thing to do in a short-term measure.

But what'll they do two years from now or five years from now or 10 years from now when this data is still being used to steal identities.

CHANG: Devastating. All right. Bloomberg's Mike Riley, thanks. Can't wait to see the scoop you bring up tomorrow. Eric Hippeau, my guest host for the hour of Lerer Hippeau Ventures, you are sticking with me.

CHANG: Still with us, Eric Hippeau, managing partner at Lerer Hippeau Ventures, who was CEO of the Huffington Post, four times. So what do you think, will we see more media M&A and if so, where?

HIPPEAU: Well, for sure, because the traditional media companies need a bigger additional footprint, bigger additional platforms.

They need to acquire technology. They're basically not technology companies.

And for the native media technology companies, to be part of a bigger group, it gives them more resources, it gives them more opportunity to distribute their content. So it's a win-win for both. So it's just --

CHANG: So do you see a big consolidation happening?

HIPPEAU: I do see -- I don't know how much of a consolidation, but if you look at the deceleration of subscribers on cable, I think, this is motivating a lot of people to say, "Wait, did this uncapping of the cable world is happening a lot faster than we expected. We better prepare -- as we are cash (INAUDIBLE) we better prepare for the future."

CHANG: All right. Eric Hippeau, you are sticking with me.

CHANG: For more, I want to get straight to our Bloomberg Tech reporter, Sarah Frier, who covers Twitter and Facebook.

And still with us, Eric Hippeau of Lerer Hippeau Ventures. So, Sarah, you know, what do you make of this? What do we know?

SARAH FRIER, BLOOMBERG HOST: So, Burr, basically saying is -- if Facebook says they don't have much to hide if they want to be transparent and cooperative, how about do it in the public.

So although a date we're hearing hasn't been set, this is something that is very important to the senators.

Obviously, Facebook, we know have given more information about the odds related to the Russian spending to Mueller's Commission, the special commission looking in to this.

So we're very much looking forward to anything that we can hear in the public eye.

CHANG: So does this mean we could see Mark Zuckerberg or Sheryl Sandberg testifying before congress?

FRIER: Yes, absolutely. I think that that could be a possibility. We could also see, perhaps, Facebook head of security.

Anyone who might have more specific information about how this looks, maybe that they're looking in to it on a -- on a granular level. I -- but, nothing has been confirmed yet.

CHANG: Eric, what's your take on this story?

HIPPEAU: Well, my take is that the issue is actually bigger than just the Russian hack or whatever. I think, we're actually in a new relationship with our big tech companies.

We, for years, have left them alone. It was completely less unfair attitude because we want them to grow and want them to innovate.

But in (INAUDIBLE) on the eyes of society as users and of government that this -- that they're really not transparent. They're not -- they're not telling us what they're doing.

They change the algorithms without any start or any other expectations. They deal with our data in ways that for instance, they -- we just learned that they allowed people to target races and white supremacies.

How is that possible? So they hide in some ways behind this notion that they're just a utility. That they're not responsible for the content, they're not responsible for how the platform is being used.

And, I think, that society as users and of government, we're not saying, "That can't be true." You know, you have to have responsibility, you have to take charge of what's going on in your own platform.

CHANG: Sarah, another story that just crossed European regulators are going to be telling tech companies that they are going to be fined if they don't take down terrorist-related content in a matter of hour, which I wonder, A, is that -- is that possible and what might the reaction be?

FRIER: I think that's absolutely going to be something that the company will say, "It's very difficult." Of course, Twitter today announced that it had removed a few 300,000 accounts from ISIS --

CHANG: 300,000?

FRIER: -- about 20 percent --

CHANG: 300,000 accounts that they removed? That's a lot.

FRIER: That's a lot, it's 20 percent less than this time last year. But maybe that means that they're doing something to address the issue.

The problem the European Regulator say is that they want the company to address this content within two hours and when it goes up.

That is very difficult for something, you know, Facebook has more than two billion users now, and it's very difficult for them to possible that content.

What the UN wants new is get these companies and start thinking about this, the technological level. Is there a way that they can address this issue at scale without having to hire thousands of contractors support through this or is that just in impossibility?

CHANG: And yet, it's a problem, obviously, they've known about for a long time. Eric, do you think it's fair for them to say, "We can't do it. It's too big."

HIPPEAU: No, no, it's not. And they -- and (INAUDIBLE) the measures that they've taken so far and they seemed to be working that well.

Facebook has added 2,000 curators, there's more technology, et cetera. But they're not doing enough. And they're certainly not reassuring us that they're doing enough for -- on this matter.

CHANG: Facebook though did say that they are hiring 3,000 extra workers to --

FRIER: And, Emily --

CHANG: -- flag the content. Go ahead, Sarah.

FRIER: I see --

CHANG: (INAUDIBLE) 30 seconds.

FRIER: -- I see that 3,000 workers cited in every post from Facebook on a problem they're trying to address. Those 3,000 workers are dealing with Ad fraud, fake news, hateful content, violate video, all these things. It's very interesting how much they're able to cope with.

CHANG: Well, they have a lot on their plate, apparently. Sarah Frier of Bloomberg News. I know you'll keep us posted on all these stories.

Eric Hippeau of Lerer Hippeau Ventures, thank you so much for joining us today.

HIPPEAU: Yes, my pleasure.

CHANG: Great to see you here in New York.

HIPPEAU: Thank you.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

SEPTEMBER 19, 2017

SPEAKERS ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES

BOBBY FRANKLIN, CEO, NATIONAL VENTURE CAPITAL ASSOCIATION

SARAH FRIER, BLOOMBERG NEWS

MIKE RILEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

ALEX WAYNE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG HOST: Joining me now to discuss, Bobby Franklin, the CEO of the group leading the suit, the National Venture Capital Association.

And Eric Hippeau, managing partner of Lerer Hippeau Ventures, our guest host for the hour with me here in the studio.

Also, Alex Wayne, who covers the White House for Bloomberg news. Alex, I'm going to start with you. What do you make of this?

ALEX WAYNE, BLOOMBERG HOST: It's an interesting lawsuit. You know, a lot of previous test case it's really -- because this isn't the only rule that the Trump administration -- excuse me, Obama era rule, the Trump administration has stuck to delay, and then eventually get rid of.

The suit, as I understand it, challenges whether the Obama -- the Trump administration can do this without opening in a comment period first.

Now, I think, it's kind of a weird rule that the Trump administration is trying to resend, it seems like it would normally fit in to like sort of category of immigrants that the president would like to see more of in the United States.

He's advocated for a merit-based immigration system. But, I think, what's happening here politically is twofold.

One, Trump is really trying to establish his legacy as erasing Obama's legacy including just about every rule that Obama issued late in his presidency.

And two, there are -- there are serious immigration restrictions within this administration. People who think there should be lower legal immigration overall.

And so by repealing this rule, those folks are probably trying to achieve some of their goals.

CHANG: Bobby, why file this suit? What do you hope to accomplish?

BOBBY FRANKLIN, CEO, NATIONAL VENTURE CAPITAL ASSOCIATION: Well, we hope to get the rule enacted, we hope to make sure that DHS is in a position to accept applications.

Emily, this is about a competition that the U.S. is in with the rest of the world. In other countries are literally rolling out red carpets.

You look at Canada, you look at Great Britain, France, Singapore, all across the globe, they recognize that there are talents in entrepreneurs.

They're trying to attract them to their country to start and grow this new company on their soil.

And what are we doing, we've got red tape. It's not a partisan issue, it's not against President Trump, it's not against President Obama.

In fact, both of them have talked about the importance of bringing international entrepreneurs that can frankly get capital anywhere across the globe.

Bringing them here to our country and making sure that we grow U.S. jobs in the economy.

CHANG: Eric, you are an immigrant, you're an entrepreneur, you're an investor. What's your take?

ERIC HIPPEAU, MANAGING PARTNER, LERER HIPPEAU VENTURES: Well, my take is that foreign-entrepreneurs coming in to the United States is a very desirable thing to do.

About half of our companies have at least one member of the original team, the founding team, who is an immigrant. I'm an immigrant.

And these are people who make huge contributions to our economy, to our society. And I don't see why we would make it difficult for them to come.

And as Bobby just mentioned, they can go elsewhere. They can go to Canada, they can go to France, they can go to other places. We are competing with other nations.

CHANG: Obviously, President Trump's, you know, explanation here is creating U.S. jobs, making sure that U.S. workers have a place to work.

Bobby, what about the idea this is -- that this is merely a stop gap measure in any way when immigration reform in general is broken?

FRANKLIN: Well, it is broken. And we've been working on this issue for many years. Back in 2013, we had the opportunity to get a start of these passed through the U.S. senate.

But it didn't make it all the way in to law. Each year, we work with congress to try to get them to pass legislation.

There are bills in this congress introduced by both Republicans and Democrats that would create a start of these that would make it easier for these entrepreneurs to come here and start companies.

But in the absence of legislation, making it in to law, we have to do what we can.

And DHS promulgated the rule, they went through comment, and noticed, and we had a rule ready to take effect July 17th.

And one week before that, DHS decided to resend that, we don't think they follow proper procedure under the administrator procedures act.

And it's the only thing that we have to go on right now to try to get more entrepreneurs here in our country.

CHANG: Now, Alex, obviously, there have been conflicting messages from the administration when it comes to this, when it comes to DACA, when it comes to immigration reform, in general.

What are the next legislative steps that we actually expect to see in the coming days and weeks when it comes to, you know, taking action on what the president has signaled?

WAYNE: So the priority in the immediate future is to do something about DACA, the so-called Dreamers, these young immigrants brought to the country illegally by their parents.

Democrats say they struck a deal with Trump to deal with -- to handle that issue and resolve that issue.

I have not heard anything, any kind of a legislative resolution of this issue, entrepreneur, immigrants.

So I would not expect that to be tackled by congress in the near future if it all -- perhaps, it could be part of a comprehensive immigration bill.

But that's the way in the future, that's not even under consideration right now.

CHANG: So, Eric, have any of these moves impacted your entrepreneurs in any way? I mean, are people nervous or are they changing their plans?

HIPPEAU: Well, by definition, we back people who are here legally, who are with a visa or because they were, you know, they're here -- were under weather reforms.

So -- but the community is nervous, the community is saying, "You know, I was welcomed when I came here and this is my dream. My dream is the United States that's' why I'm here."

"Why is this changing, why am I not, you know, part of this, you know, great community?" So this is a great degree of anxiety within the community.

CHANG: Right. Bobby, any response to the lawsuit so far?

FRANKLIN: Not yet, but, you know, we'll take the next steps. We'll likely file an injunction to try to get DHS to move forward, you know, stay tuned.

CHANG: All right. Bobby Franklin, CEO of the National Venture Capital Association, Alex Wayne of Bloomberg News. Thank you both for joining us.

Eric Hippeau, managing partner of Lerer Hippeau Ventures and my guest host for the hour, you are sticking with me.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHANG: Still with us, Eric Hippeau, managing partner at Lerer Hippeau Ventures, we have to talk about this, of course, because we're in New York today.

What do you think the likelihood of that -- of Amazon ending up here?

HIPPEAU: Well, we would love it, obviously, 50,000 tech workers or quasi- tech workers in Brooklyn that would be fantastic.

I think the chances are pretty low. New York is a very expensive place to set up a business.

And we -- in the current administration, New York is not particularly business-friendly. So I'm not even sure that New York is bidding.

CHANG: Where is business-friendly under the current administration?

HIPPEAU: Well, I was talking about the local administration, but, you know, but I think that New York should be looking for those kinds of opportunities.

Because those are the kinds of jobs at a higher-paying, that are, you know, information-based essentially that we need is that -- but I don't know that the City of New York is actually even active in looking at attracting them.

CHANG: So what do you -- I mean, what do you think Amazon should be looking for in their second headquarters since they can't -- they can't build out its headquarters in Seattle their capacity. What should they be looking for elsewhere?

HIPPEAU: I think it needs a city or a place where there's a lot of higher education, a lot of young people that who are looking for the jobs of the new economy, and a business-friendly environment.

CHANG: We do have some (INAUDIBLE) from the mayor of Philadelphia, obviously, a lot of cities competing for this now. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MAYOR JIM KENNEY, PHILADELPHIA, PENNSYLVANIA: We've gotten criticism, you know, about corporate tax breaks and that alike. This is too big of a deal, and it's too many jobs and too great of a company for us not to go after it. And we would love to have it here.

We have a lot of folks who could use the work and we have a lot of IT startups and tech companies that have come into Philadelphia recently.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHANG: So Philadelphia throwing their hat in the ring as well. How does the city benefit?

HIPPEAU: Well, you do have to give them some tax breaks, I imagine. But on the other hand, you're providing 50,000 really good paying jobs, there are people who will pay taxes themselves and who will buy local products and services.

So it's a -- it's a definite plus for the city. New York just opened the Cornell Tech, and Bloomberg is very much involved with that.

So it would actually go really well with attracting the headquarters or the second headquarters of a big tech company.

CHANG: And I wonder if New York would do a good job of attracting younger talent, I mean, who doesn't want to live in New York, right?

HIPPEAU: Exactly, New York -- New York, well, that's why, I mean, New York, most of my companies are here. It's a great place for startups and most people love to be in New York.

There's a lot of diversity and a lot of things to do. But the city needs to have a plan in place to be able to attract a company like Amazon.

CHANG: How would you describe evolution of New York's tax scheme? I mean, obviously, it's always been -- it's always placed second to Silicon Valley to a certain extent, though, you know, many of the big tech companies have offices here as well and the scene is changing. You know, how much closer is Silicon Alley to Silicon Valley these days?

HIPPEAU: Well, today, Silicon Alley of New York is the second largest center of technology in United States, one of the largest in the world.

And what New York does when it's good at. New York is good at software development, New York is good at applications and services.

We're not going to be reinventing the plumbing of the Internet, we're not going to create the next generation of routers.

However, we're starting to see robotics companies, we're starting to see, you know, all kinds of companies and all kinds of sectors because we have access in New York to the same technology that people in Silicon Valley have.

CHANG: When is that 10 billion dollar company going to be coming out in New York, that 10 billion dollar tech company?

HIPPEAU: Hopefully, it's in the pipeline. There's a whole number of companies which have to reach the billion dollar, at least, in the private market valuation that, I think, have the potential to be one of those companies.

CHANG: All right. Eric Hippeau, Lerer Hippeau Ventures, you are sticking with me. Thank you

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHANG: Joining me now to discuss the latest in this ongoing saga, Bloomberg's Mike Riley and still with us, Eric Hippeau, managing partner at Lerer Hippeau Ventures.

Eric, you are shaking your head. Mike, it is so hard not to read these stories and not get incredibly angry.

It just gets worst and worst. What do we know about this new breach and how much they knew before they told the public?

MIKE RILEY, BLOOMBERG HOST: We don't know a lot because they're not being particularly clear about what they knew. But we do know a couple of important things.

One is that they had a major invest -- security investigation going on starting in March and going through May.

They hired Mandiant, the same cyber security firm that they've brought back in July.

And they were doing a pretty extensive investigation for three months. Now, company like Mandiant, that's a pretty expensive prospect.

But the most interesting thing if you look at their timeline of the July incident, the one that they found out about July is the hackers, even though, they found out about the theft of, you know, this data in July.

When they did the investigation, when Mandiant came back in, they discovered that that data was stolen in May, which would have put it right in the middle of this earlier investigation.

So there's a question of like why that wasn't found, how do you get of a company like Mandiant examining your networks and other things, and just missed the presence of a -- of a hacker in your network, and the theft of this kind of data.

It also raises this questions about, you know, what the executives knew when -- whether they knew that the company was having multiple security problems at the time they did trades in May and in late July, early August.

So, again, it raises just all sorts of questions. And one of the things that's clear is, you know, when a data breach like this, you want to get to be as transparent with the public as possible and you want to do it as early as possible.

And we just keep getting a trickle of new information really almost daily now.

CHANG: It feels like a mess and it feels like they're not being transparent at all. I mean, Eric, you probably have a credit card, right? You probably among the 143 million people just like everyone else?

HIPPEAU: Well, that -- it's shocking to me that, first of all, the CEO the company is still the CEO of the company. I don't understand what the board of directors is going.

But, I think, what we're realizing here is that our data is ending in this credit service bureaus without us knowing about it.

I mean, we suspect, of course, we got a credit score and all that. But they collect a very sensitive information about us without really our authorization.

So the least you would expect is that the most important job that they do is to maintain that data safe.

And if you have information on the majority of the American citizens, you have to expect that there's a whole hacking world is going to come after you.

CHANG: Right, that's their one job, it's to make sure --

HIPPEAU: That's your one job.

CHANG: -- it's protected.

HIPPEAU: And as your colleague just pointed out, if there's any kind of breach and you need full transparency because how are we possibly going to be able to trust this people again.

CHANG: So, Mike, you know, we are getting -- you are getting new information about the motivation of these hackers, potentially, that they're interested in getting in to the big things. You know, what do we - - what more do we know about the end goals of these attacks?

RILEY: Well, again, we don't know a lot because the company doesn't telling us a lot. But keep in mind that one of the things we just know is that if you have hackers in your system, in a system like Equifax, they're probably not just going to look for one thing even something as valuable as social security numbers and birth dates on a hundred and forty-three million U.S. consumers.

Because Equifax serves a really keep a part of the financial infrastructure of the country in general. It has direct links between its system and the bank systems through APIs.

And one of the things we did find out is that there is evidence that the hackers, some hackers used those APIs to get in to at least one major bank in Canada.

Now, that raises all sorts of questions about like what else the hackers did with their time in Equifax. I mean, keep in mind, again, that by their own timeline they discovered the breach at the end of July.

But the hackers had been in there since at least middle of May. What were -- and when they took the big stash of data, what were they doing over the next four months, that's the real question.

CHANG: Equifax did announced the retirement of a couple of senior executives but if there's still a lot of questions surrounding the share sales, this executive share sale that happened, I mean, how is this fitting in to the timeline of what we think they knew when?

RILEY: Well, it raises some really interesting question. And their time - - and their timeline is very specific, but it doesn't have much bigger room.

What -- basically, what they're saying is they learned about the hack on July 29th. The share sales, like one group of share sales happened at the beginning of August.

But there's a handful of days, two or three days between the time they learned and the time of that sale occurred.

They are basically saying that the executives didn't know about the hack in the span of those three days.

And even the people we talked to who work at Equifax say, "That just seems really unlikely."

I mean, a company like this has a protocol for what they do when they're hacked. And that protocol entails briefing the executives within a short period of time and certainly not three days.

So it does raise a lot of questions, we do know that the U.S. prosecutors have opened an investigation in to those sales because they want to find out what those executives knew when and whether or not they violated insider trading laws.

CHANG: And so that -- last question, so what is the recourse for consumers here?

RILEY: Well, so keep in mind, this is -- this is a very different tact -- attack that they target because credit card numbers is a temporary thing that you can just cancel and reissue.

What these hackers potentially got was very specific data that's at the center of our confidential identities, birth dates, social security numbers, and other things.

This is something that could be used to steal our identity, you know, any time over the next -- in the next decades over our lifetime.

So consumers can do short-term things, they can get credit monitoring that Equifax is offering for free, they can also try and freeze that access to their credit reports which is typically a hard thing to do in a short-term measure.

But what'll they do two years from now or five years from now or 10 years from now when this data is still being used to steal identities.

CHANG: Devastating. All right. Bloomberg's Mike Riley, thanks. Can't wait to see the scoop you bring up tomorrow. Eric Hippeau, my guest host for the hour of Lerer Hippeau Ventures, you are sticking with me.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHANG: Still with us, Eric Hippeau, managing partner at Lerer Hippeau Ventures, who was CEO of the Huffington Post, four times. So what do you think, will we see more media M&A and if so, where?

HIPPEAU: Well, for sure, because the traditional media companies need a bigger additional footprint, bigger additional platforms.

They need to acquire technology. They're basically not technology companies.

And for the native media technology companies, to be part of a bigger group, it gives them more resources, it gives them more opportunity to distribute their content. So it's a win-win for both. So it's just --

CHANG: So do you see a big consolidation happening?

HIPPEAU: I do see -- I don't know how much of a consolidation, but if you look at the deceleration of subscribers on cable, I think, this is motivating a lot of people to say, "Wait, did this uncapping of the cable world is happening a lot faster than we expected. We better prepare -- as we are cash (INAUDIBLE) we better prepare for the future."

CHANG: All right. Eric Hippeau, you are sticking with me.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHANG: For more, I want to get straight to our Bloomberg Tech reporter, Sarah Frier, who covers Twitter and Facebook.

And still with us, Eric Hippeau of Lerer Hippeau Ventures. So, Sarah, you know, what do you make of this? What do we know?

SARAH FRIER, BLOOMBERG HOST: So, Burr, basically saying is -- if Facebook says they don't have much to hide if they want to be transparent and cooperative, how about do it in the public.

So although a date we're hearing hasn't been set, this is something that is very important to the senators.

Obviously, Facebook, we know have given more information about the odds related to the Russian spending to Mueller's Commission, the special commission looking in to this.

So we're very much looking forward to anything that we can hear in the public eye.

CHANG: So does this mean we could see Mark Zuckerberg or Sheryl Sandberg testifying before congress?

FRIER: Yes, absolutely. I think that that could be a possibility. We could also see, perhaps, Facebook head of security.

Anyone who might have more specific information about how this looks, maybe that they're looking in to it on a -- on a granular level. I -- but, nothing has been confirmed yet.

CHANG: Eric, what's your take on this story?

HIPPEAU: Well, my take is that the issue is actually bigger than just the Russian hack or whatever. I think, we're actually in a new relationship with our big tech companies.

We, for years, have left them alone. It was completely less unfair attitude because we want them to grow and want them to innovate.

But in (INAUDIBLE) on the eyes of society as users and of government that this -- that they're really not transparent. They're not -- they're not telling us what they're doing.

They change the algorithms without any start or any other expectations. They deal with our data in ways that for instance, they -- we just learned that they allowed people to target races and white supremacies.

How is that possible? So they hide in some ways behind this notion that they're just a utility. That they're not responsible for the content, they're not responsible for how the platform is being used.

And, I think, that society as users and of government, we're not saying, "That can't be true." You know, you have to have responsibility, you have to take charge of what's going on in your own platform.

CHANG: Sarah, another story that just crossed European regulators are going to be telling tech companies that they are going to be fined if they don't take down terrorist-related content in a matter of hour, which I wonder, A, is that -- is that possible and what might the reaction be?

FRIER: I think that's absolutely going to be something that the company will say, "It's very difficult." Of course, Twitter today announced that it had removed a few 300,000 accounts from ISIS --

CHANG: 300,000?

FRIER: -- about 20 percent --

CHANG: 300,000 accounts that they removed? That's a lot.

FRIER: That's a lot, it's 20 percent less than this time last year. But maybe that means that they're doing something to address the issue.

The problem the European Regulator say is that they want the company to address this content within two hours and when it goes up.

That is very difficult for something, you know, Facebook has more than two billion users now, and it's very difficult for them to possible that content.

What the UN wants new is get these companies and start thinking about this, the technological level. Is there a way that they can address this issue at scale without having to hire thousands of contractors support through this or is that just in impossibility?

CHANG: And yet, it's a problem, obviously, they've known about for a long time. Eric, do you think it's fair for them to say, "We can't do it. It's too big."

HIPPEAU: No, no, it's not. And they -- and (INAUDIBLE) the measures that they've taken so far and they seemed to be working that well.

Facebook has added 2,000 curators, there's more technology, et cetera. But they're not doing enough. And they're certainly not reassuring us that they're doing enough for -- on this matter.

CHANG: Facebook though did say that they are hiring 3,000 extra workers to --

FRIER: And, Emily --

CHANG: -- flag the content. Go ahead, Sarah.

FRIER: I see --

CHANG: (INAUDIBLE) 30 seconds.

FRIER: -- I see that 3,000 workers cited in every post from Facebook on a problem they're trying to address. Those 3,000 workers are dealing with Ad fraud, fake news, hateful content, violate video, all these things. It's very interesting how much they're able to cope with.

CHANG: Well, they have a lot on their plate, apparently. Sarah Frier of Bloomberg News. I know you'll keep us posted on all these stories.

Eric Hippeau of Lerer Hippeau Ventures, thank you so much for joining us today.

HIPPEAU: Yes, my pleasure.

CHANG: Great to see you here in New York.

HIPPEAU: Thank you.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
